Chapter 1
GENERAL PROVISIONS
Sec. 1-1. How Code designated and cited.
The ordinances embraced in the following chapters and sections shall constitute
and be designated the "Evergreen Park Municipal Code," and may be so cited.
(Code 1965, § 1-1)
Sec. 1-2. Rules of construction and definitions.
In the construction of this Code, and of all ordinances, the rules and
definitions set out in this section shall be observed, unless such construction
would be inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of trustees. The
rules of construction and definitions set out herein shall not be applied to
any section of this Code which shall contain any express provision excluding
such construction, or where the subject matter or context of such section may
be repugnant thereto.
   Generally. All general provisions, terms, phrases and expressions contained
in this Code shall be liberally construed in order that the true intent and
meaning of the board of trustees may be fully carried out. In the
interpretation and application of any provision of this Code, it shall be held
to be the minimum requirements adopted for the promotion of the public health,
safety, comfort, convenience and general welfare. Where any provision of the
Code imposes greater restrictions upon the subject matter than the general
provision imposed by the Code, the provision imposing the greater restriction
or regulation shall be deemed to be controlling.
   Board, board of trustees, village board. Whenever the term "board," "board
of trustees" or "village board" are used, they shall be construed to mean the
board of trustees of the Village of Evergreen Park, Illinois, which shall
consist of the mayor and trustees.
   State law reference—Board of trustees to be composed of president and
trustees, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-5.
   Circuit court or court. The term "circuit court" or "court" shall refer to
the Circuit Court of Cook County, Illinois.
   State law reference—Cook County to be one (1) judicial circuit, 705 ILCS 35/
1.
   Code. The term "Code" or "this Code" shall mean the Evergreen Park Municipal
Code designated in section
1-1 above.
   Computation of time. The time within which any act provided by this Code is
to be done shall be computed by excluding the first day and including the last,
unless the last day is Saturday or Sunday or is a legal holiday, in which case
it shall also be excluded. If the day succeeding such Saturday, Sunday or
holiday is also a holiday or a Saturday or Sunday, then such succeeding day
shall also be excluded.
   Corporate authorities. The term "corporate authorities" shall mean the board
of trustees.
   State law reference—Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/1-1-2(2).
   Corporate or village limits. The term "corporate limits" or "village limits"
shall mean the legal boundaries of the Village of Evergreen Park.
   County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean Cook County,
Illinois.
   Delegation of authority. Whenever a provision appears requiring the head of
a department or some other village officer to do some act or make certain
inspections, it is to be construed to authorize the head of the department or
other officer to designate, delegate and authorize subordinates to perform the
required act or make the required inspection unless the terms of the provision
or section designate otherwise.
   Gender. A word importing the masculine gender only shall extend and be
applied to females and to firms, partnerships and corporations as well as to
males.
   Joint authority. All words giving a joint authority to three (3) or more
persons or officers shall be construed as giving such authority to a majority
of such persons or officers.
   Keeper and proprietor. The words "keeper" and "proprietor" shall mean and
include persons, firms, associations, corporations, clubs and partnerships,
whether acting by themselves or a servant, agent or employee.
   May. The word "may" shall be construed as being permissive.
   May not. The words "may not" shall have a prohibitory effect and state a
prohibition.
   Mayor. The word "mayor" means the president of the village.
   State law reference—Village president may be referred to as mayor, 65 ILCS
5/1-1-2.1.
   Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month.
   Must. The word "must" shall be construed as being mandatory.
   Nontechnical and technical words. Words and phrases shall be construed
according to the common and approved usage of the language, but technical words
and phrases and such others as may have acquired a peculiar and appropriate
meaning in law shall be construed and understood according to such meaning.
   Number. A word importing the singular number only may extend and be applied
to several persons and things as well as to one (1) person and thing.
   Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all
cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in
such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words
"affirm" and "affirmed."
   Officers generally. Whenever any officer is referred to by title, such as
"clerk," "chief of police," etc., such reference shall be construed as if
followed by the words "of the Village of Evergreen Park."
   Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any
part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, tenant in partnership, joint tenant,
or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or of a part of such building or land.
   Person. The word "person" shall extend and be applied to associations,
clubs, societies, firms, partnerships and bodies politic and corporate as well
as to individuals.
   Personal property. The words "personal property" shall include every species
of property except real property, as herein described.
   Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following" mean next before
and next after, respectively.
   Property. The word "property" shall include real and personal property.
   Real property. The words "real proeprty" shall include lands, tenements and
hereditaments.
   Shall. The word "shall" is mandatory.
   Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean any portion of a street between the
curbline and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians,
excluding parkways.
   Signature or subscription. The word "signature" or "subscription" shall
include a mark when the person cannot write.
   State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall be construed to mean the
State of Illinois.
   Street. The word "street" shall be construed to embrace streets, avenues,
boulevards, roads, alleys, lanes, viaducts and all other public highways in the
village, and shall include all areas thereof embraced between the property
lines and dedicated to the public use.
   Tenant or occupant. The word "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building
or land, shall include any person holding a written or oral lease or who
occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, either alone or with
others.
   Time. Words used in the past or present tense include the future as well as
the past and present. If a time is given in a.m. or p.m. it shall mean Central
Standard Time except that when the village is on daylight saving time it shall
mean Central Daylight Time.
   Trustee. The word "trustee" shall mean a member of the board of trustees of
the Village of Evergreen Park.
   Village. The words "the village" or "this village" shall mean the Village of
Evergreen Park, Cook County, Illinois.
   Wholesale, wholesaler, etc. In all cases where the words "wholesale,"
"wholesaler," and "wholesale dealer" are used in this Code, unless otherwise
specifically defined, they shall be understood and held to relate to the sale
of goods, merchandise, articles or things in quantity to persons who purchase
for purposes of resale, as distinguished from a retail dealer who sells in
smaller quantities direct to the consumer.
   Written or in writing. The words "written" or "in writing" shall be
construed to include any representation of words, letters or figures, whether
by printing or otherwise.
   Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year. (Code 1965, § 1-2)
Sec. 1-3. Code an exercise of home rule power.
This Code shall be construed to be an exercise of the home rule powers granted
by art. VII, sec. 6 of the Illinois Constitution of 1970.
Sec. 1-4. Catchlines of sections; history notes, etc.; references to Code.
   (a)   The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in
boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the
section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as
any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so
deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or
reenacted.
   (b)   The history or source notes appearing in parentheses after sections in
this Code are not intended to have any legal effect but are merely intended to
indicate the source of matter contained in the section. Cross references and
state law references which appear after sections or subsections of this Code or
which otherwise appear in footnote form are provided for the convenience of the
user of this Code and have no legal effect.
   (c)   All references to chapters, articles, or sections are to the chapters,
articles, and sections of this Code unless otherwise specified.
(Code 1965, § 1-3)
Sec. 1-5. Effect of repeal of ordinances.
   (a)   When any ordinance repealing a former ordinance, clause or provision
shall be itself repealed, such repeal shall not be construed to revive such
former ordinance, clause or provision unless it shall be therein so expressly
provided.
   (b)   The repeal of an ordinance shall not affect any punishment or penalty
incurred before the repeal took effect, nor any suit, prosecution or proceeding
pending at the time of the repeal, for an offense committed or cause of action
arising under the ordinance repealed. (Code 1965, § 1-6)
Sec. 1-6. Amendments to Code.
All ordinances passed subsequent to this Code which amend, repeal or in any way
affect this Code may be numbered in accordance with the numbering system of
this Code and printed for inclusion therein, or in the case of repealed
chapters, sections and subsections or any part thereof, by subsequent
ordinances, such repealed portions may be excluded from the Code by omission
from reprinted pages affected thereby and the subsequent ordinances as numbered
and printed or omitted, in the case of repeal, shall be prima facie evidence of
such subsequent ordinances until such time that this Code and subsequent
ordinances numbered or omitted are readopted as a new Code by the board of
trustees.
Sec. 1-7. Aiding, abetting, encouraging offense.
It shall be unlawful for any person, in any way or manner, to aid, abet,
counsel, advise or encourage any other person in the commission of any of the
acts mentioned herein or in any manner encourage the commission of an offense
defined in this Code.
Sec. 1-8. Unauthorized alteration or tampering with Code.
It shall be unlawful for any person in the village to change or amend, by
additions or deletions, any part or portion of this Code, or to insert or
delete pages, or portions thereof, or to alter or tamper with such Code in any
manner whatsoever which will cause the law of the village to be misrepresented
thereby.
Sec. 1-9. General penalty.
   (a)   General penalty for violation of Code. Whenever in this Code or in any
ordinance of the village any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be
unlawful or an offense, or whenever in such Code or ordinance the doing of any
act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful, where
no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision
of this Code or any ordinance shall be punished by a fine of not less than
$65.00 nor more than $500.00. Each day any violation of any provision of this
Code or of any ordinance shall continue shall constitute a separate offense.
   (b)   Imprisonment. No complaint shall be filed under any section of this
Code punishable by incarceration in a penal institution other than the
penitentiary of not to exceed 6 months, unless the section of this Code
provides for that imprisonment. All such complaints shall state that a
conviction may result by incarceration of not to exceed 6 months and shall
require the prosecution to establish the guilt beyond a reasonable doubt.
   (c)   Citations ("P" tickets). Before a complaint in court is filed, a
citation ("P" ticket) may be issued advising the defendant of a violation of
any section of this Code and requesting payment for the amounts set forth in
this Code (such as in section
13-388 or in section
12-216), and if no amount is set forth in this Code, then in accordance with a
schedule of fines to be approved by the Mayor and made public at the Village
Hall, but the schedule of fines shall not exceed $500 for each separate
offense. For non vehicular violations, the procedures set forth in Article X of
Chapter 12 of this Code (sections
12-370 through
12-378) shall be implemented. For vehicular violations, the procedures set
forth in Article X of
Chapter 13 of this Code (sections
13-380 through
13-392) shall be implemented.
   (d)   Responsibility of corporation; joint liability. A corporation may be
prosecuted for the commission of an offense performed by any officer, agent, or
employee of the corporation where the offense is committed while the person is
acting within the scope of his office, employment or agency; the commission of
the offense is authorized, requested, commanded, performed, permitted, allowed;
or by neglect of the corporation. Am officer or any other agent who has a
position of comparable authority for the formulation of corporate policy or the
supervision of subordinate employees in a managerial capacity is legally
accountable for any offense committed in the name of or in behalf of the
corporation to the same extent as if it were performed in his own name and
behalf and may be prosecuted for violations of this chapter.
   Prosecutions for violations may be jointly, severally or in the alternative
against any of the above-named persons. Persons jointly liable for any
violations may be prosecuted under one (1) complaint.
   (e)   Cumulative remedies. The remedies or penalties enumerated in this
section are cumulative and the village may prosecute in the alternative and, in
the case of a nuisance, subject the person committing such nuisance to an
immediate arrest without the notice to abate or other procedure and may, in
addition, proceed for any other violation of any other section of this Code,
the federal and state statutes, or the common law.
(Ord. No. 32-2009 § 1, 12-7-09; Am. Ord. No. 29-2018 § 1, 11-5-18)
Sec. 1-10. Reserved.
Sec. 1-11. Severability of parts of Code.
The sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are
severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this
Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of a
court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any
of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this
Code.
(Code 1965, § 1-9)
Sec. 1-12. Ordinances, etc., not affected by Code.
   (a)   Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect
any of the following:
      (1)   Any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment
of money for the village or authorizing the issuance of any bonds of the
village or any evidence of the village's indebtedness.
      (2)   Any appropriation ordinance or ordinance providing for the levy of
taxes or for an annual budget.
      (3)   Any ordinance annexing territory to the village or excluding
territory as a part of the village.
      (4)   Any ordinance granting any franchise, permit or other right.
      (5)   Any ordinance authorizing or otherwise relating to any contract,
agreement, lease, deed or other instrument.
      (6)   Any ordinance rezoning property.
      (7)   Any ordinance dedicating or accepting any plat or subdivision.
      (8)   Any ordinance levying special assessments or providing for local
improvements.
      (9)   Any ordinance relating to the salaries of village officers or
employees.
      (10)   Any ordinance dedicating, naming, establishing, locating,
relocating, opening, closing, paving or vacating any street or public way.
      (11)   Any ordinance providing regulations for cable television.
      (12)   Any ordinance relating to railroads or railroad crossings with
streets or other public ways or relating to the conduct, duties, service or
rates of public utilities not codified.
      (13)   Any ordinance whose purpose has been accomplished.
      (14)   Any ordinance which is special although permanent in effect.
      (15)   Any ordinance which is temporary although general in effect.
   (b)   All such ordinances are recognized as continuing in full force and
effect to the same extent as if set out at length herein.
Sec. 1-13. Code does not affect prior offenses, rights, etc.
   (a)   Nothing in this Code or the ordinance adopting this Code shall affect
any offense or act committed or done, or any penalty or forfeiture incurred, or
any contract or right established or accruing before the effective date of this
Code.
   (b)   The adoption of this Code shall not be interpreted as authorizing or
allowing any use or the continuance of any use of a structure or premises in
violation of any ordinance of the village in effect on the date of adoption of
this Code.
Sec. 1-14. Provisions as continuation of existing ordinances.
The provisions of this Code, insofar as they are substantially the same as
ordinance provisions previously adopted by the village relating to the same
subject matter, shall be construed as restatements and continuations thereof
and not as new enactments.

ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 2-1. Corporate seal of village.
The corporate seal of the village shall be kept by the village clerk and shall
be designed to bear the words "Village of Evergreen Park".
Sec. 2-2. Elections.
All elections shall be held in compliance with the provisions of the Election
Code [10 ILCS 5/1-1, et seq.].
Sec. 2-3. Terms of elected office.
The terms of elected office shall commence at the second regular meeting in the
month of May following the consolidated election in April and shall continue
until a successor is elected and qualified.
Sec. 2-4. Meetings.
All meetings shall be held in compliance with the provisions of the Open
Meetings Act [5 ILCS 120/1, et seq.].
Sec. 2-5. Records.
All records shall be subject to public inspection and copying only as required
by the provisions of the Freedom of Information Act [5 ILCS 140/1, et seq.].
ARTICLE II. MAYOR AND BOARD OF TRUSTEES
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 2-26. Composition; election.
The legislative and governing body of the village shall consist of the mayor
and 6 trustees, who shall possess qualifications for office, be elected by the
legal voters of the village, take the oath of office and perform the duties as
provided by law.
Sec. 2-27. Compensation of village trustees.
The village trustee shall receive as annual compensation the sum of $14,023.80
effective with the commencement of the term of office following the 2013
consolidated election. On May 1, 2015, and on each succeeding May 1 thereafter,
the compensation to be paid to the village trustee shall be increased by 2.0%
over that paid in the previous period. Compensation shall be paid in
installments in the same manner as for other employees of the village. The
above rate of compensation does not include benefits or expenses currently
provided to village trustees.
(Am. Ord. 25-2012 § 1, 9-4-12)
Sec. 2-28. Committees.
   (a)   The board of trustees shall be organized into the following standing
committees:
      (1)   Public Safety, Police, Fire, Emergency Services.
      (2)   Public Works, Environmental, Waste Recycling.
      (3)   Finance, Capital Planning, Economic Development.
      (4)   Zoning, Village Plan, Code Enforcement.
      (5)   Citizen Services, Recreation, Youth, Senior.
      (6)   Laws, Ordinances, Village Properties, Community Engagement.
   (b)   Every committee shall concern itself with the subject matter under its
respective jurisdiction. If jurisdiction may be exercised by more than one
committee, the mayor shall decide which committee shall exercise jurisdiction.
   (c)   Each committee shall consist of 3 trustees appointed by the mayor,
with the advice and consent of the board of trustees. The mayor shall appoint
the chairman of each committee, with the advice and consent of the board of
trustees.
   (d)   Each committee shall meet at least twice per year to review the
budget, personnel and planning for future requirements, and at other such times
as are necessary.
   (e)   The board of trustees may establish special committees to handle
extraordinary matters.
(Am. Ord. 2-2022, § 1, 1-18-22)
DIVISION 2. MAYOR
Sec. 2-46. Bond.
The mayor of the village shall, before he enters upon the duties of his office,
execute a bond payable to the village as provided by law.
Sec. 2-47. Compensation of mayor.
The mayor shall receive as annual compensation the sum of $106,544.72 effective
with the commencement of the term of office following the 2013 consolidated
election. On May 1, 2015, and on each succeeding May 1 thereafter, the
compensation to be paid to the Mayor shall be increased by 2.0% over that paid
in the previous period. Compensation shall be paid in installments in the same
manner as for other employees of the village. The above rate of compensation
does not include benefits or expenses currently provided to mayor.
(Am. Ord. 25-2012 § 2, 9-4-12)
Sec. 2-48. Mayor pro tempore.
   (a)   In the event the mayor becomes incapacitated or otherwise unable to
perform the duties of his office for a period of at least 2 weeks, the board of
trustees shall elect one of its members to act as mayor pro tempore who, during
his incapacity or disability shall possess the powers of the mayor.
   (b)   During the absence or disability of the mayor, the board of trustees
shall elect one of its number mayor pro tem of the board of trustees, and he
shall act as presiding officer of the board of trustees. Where the absence of
or disability of the mayor is to be of a very short duration and no individual
is required to be granted the powers of the mayor, the board of trustees shall
elect one of its members temporary chairman. The mayor pro tern or the
temporary chairman, when acting as the presiding officer, shall vote on all
questions on which the vote is taken by " yes" and "no," his name being called
last. The mayor pro tem shall have all the powers and duties of the mayor; the
temporary chairman shall not have such powers and duties.
Sec. 2-49. Duties generally.
   (a)   The mayor shall supervise the conduct of all appointed officers and
see that they faithfully and efficiently discharge the duties of their
respective offices.
   (b)   He shall inquire into all reasonable complaints made against them and
cause all their neglects or violations of duties to be promptly corrected.
   (c)   He shall, from time to time, give the board of trustees such
information relative to the affairs of the village as he may deem proper.
   (d)   He shall recommend to their consideration any measure he may deem
expedient, tending to the well-being, security and improvement of the village.
Sec. 2-50. Sign all papers in regard to litigation.
The mayor shall sign, and is hereby authorized to sign in behalf of the
village, all instruments necessary to the prompt prosecution or defense of any
or all actions brought by or against the village, including bonds for
injunction.
Sec. 2-51. Sign licenses, commissions, warrants, etc.
The mayor shall sign all commissions, licenses, permits and warrants granted,
issued or ordered by the board of trustees, or authorized by the ordinances of
the village, except as otherwise provided herein, and may revoke any such
licenses as hereafter provided.
Sec. 2-52.    Executive clemency.
   (a)   The mayor may for good and sufficient reasons release any person
imprisoned for violation of any section of this Code or of any village
ordinance. The mayor shall cause a proper record thereof to be made, and shall
report such release with the cause therefor to the board of trustees at its
first session thereinafter.
   (b)   The mayor may compromise, settle, or nonsuit any ticket or quasi-
criminal complaint.
Sec. 2-53. Appointment power, procedure.
The mayor, by and with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, shall
appoint all officers of the village. Whenever a vacancy shall occur in any
office which the mayor is authorized to fill, he shall submit to the board of
trustees the name of his appointee to such office; pending the approval or
rejection by the board of trustees as to such appointment, he may designate
some suitable person to discharge the duties of the office if it appears that
the office had been abandoned.
(Code 1965, § 2-31)
Secs. 2-54-2-70. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. RULES OF ORDER AND PROCEDURE
Sec. 2-71. Generally.
The rules of order for conduct of village business by the mayor and board of
trustees of the village are as set out in this division.
(Code 1965, § 2-54)
Sec. 2-72. Failure to comply.
Failure to comply with this division does not invalidate any action of the
board of trustees.
Sec. 2-73. Adoption of "Robert's Rules."
The rules of parliamentary practice included in the last published edition of
"Robert's Rules of Order, Newly Revised" shall govern the board of trustees in
all cases in which they are applicable and in which they are not inconsistent
with the special rules of this board of trustees or the statutes or laws of the
state.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 44))
Sec. 2-74. Meetings generally.
The regular meetings of the board of trustees shall be held on the first and
third Mondays in each month of the year at the hour of 7:30 p.m. in the village
hall or at such other times and places as directed by the board of trustees.
(Code 1965, §§ 2-28, 2-54(rule 1))
   State law reference—Notice of regular meetings, 5 ILCS 120/2.02, 120/2.03.
Sec. 2-75. Special meetings.
Special meetings of the board of trustees may be held at any time on the call
of the mayor or any three (3) or more trustees. Such call shall be in writing,
duly signed, and shall be presented to the clerk, who shall proceed immediately
to cause notice of the same to be served upon the mayor and trustees in person.
Such notice shall describe in brief the nature and purpose of such meeting. If
the notice states an emergency exists, a one-hour notice must be given if the
notice is served in person; otherwise, a thirty-six-hour notice from the time
of mailing must be given.
(Code 1965, §§ 2-29, 2-54(rule 2))
   State law reference—Special meetings and notice thereof, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-13,
5 ILCS 120/2.03.
Secs. 2-76, 2-77. Reserved.
Sec. 2-78. Opening of meeting.
Each meeting of the board of trustees shall convene at the time appointed for
such meeting. The clerk, or someone appointed to fill his place by the
presiding officer, shall thereupon immediately call the roll of the members. If
no quorum is present, the board of trustees shall not thereby stand adjourned,
but the members present shall be competent to adjourn or recess the board of
trustees by a majority vote.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 3))
Sec. 2-79. Quorum; adjourned meetings.
A quorum to do business shall consist of the mayor and three (3) trustees, or
four (4) trustees in the absence of the mayor.
(Code 1965, §§ 2-30, 2-54(rule 6))
   State law reference—Quorum, etc., 65 ILCS 5/3-11-12.
Sec. 2-80. Presiding officer.
The mayor shall preside at all meetings of the board of trustees but shall only
have the right to vote where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie; or
where one-half of the trustees have voted in favor of an ordinance, resolution,
or motion even though there is no tie vote; or where a vote greater than the
majority is required by state statute or this Code.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 3))
   State law reference—Similar provisions, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-2, 5/3-11-14.
Sec. 2-81. Order of business.
   (a)   When a quorum is present, the board of trustees shall proceed to the
business before it, which shall be conducted in the order shown on the agenda
of the meeting prepared by the mayor. All questions relating to the priority of
business shall be decided by the chair, without debate, subject to appeal.
   (b)   The agenda shall be prepared before the meeting. Matters, including
those wishing to be heard at the citizen's hearing, not listed on the agenda
may be considered unless there is an objection raised by the mayor or a
trustee, in which case the matter shall be considered at the next meeting.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 6))
Sec. 2-82. Order and decorum.
   (a)   The mayor shall preserve order and decorum and may speak to points of
order in preference to other members, and shall decide all questions or order
subject to appeal.
   (b)   In the case of any disturbances or disorderly conduct, the mayor shall
have the power to require the chamber to be cleared.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 7))
Sec. 2-83. Duties of members.
   (a)   While the mayor is putting the question, no trustee shall walk across
or out of the council chamber.
   (b)   Every trustee previous to his speaking, making a motion, or seconding
the same shall address himself to the mayor and say: "Mr. Mayor," and shall not
proceed with his remarks until recognized and named by the chair. He shall
confine himself to the question under debate, avoiding personalities and
refraining from impugning the motives of any other trustee's argument or vote.
   (c)   When two (2) or more trustees address the chair at the same time, the
mayor shall name the trustee who is first to speak.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 8))
Sec. 2-84. Participation by department heads and staff.
Except for the time allowed for public discussion and comment, no person other
than a member of the board of trustees shall address that body, except
department heads and staff when recognized by the chair.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 9))
Sec. 2-85. Presentation of new business and deferment.
When a trustee wishes to present a communication, petition, order, resolution,
ordinance, or other original matter, he shall send it to the desk of the clerk,
who shall read such matter when reached in its proper order. Upon the request
of any two (2) trustees present, any report of a committee of the board of
trustees shall be deferred for final action thereon to the next regular meeting
of the board of trustees after the report is made.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 10))
Sec. 2-86. Debate.
   (a)   No trustee shall speak more than once on the same question, except by
unanimous consent, and then not until every other member desiring to speak
shall have had an opportunity to do so; provided, however, that the proponent
of the matter under consideration or the chairman of the committee whose report
is under consideration, as the case may be, shall have the right to open and
close debate. No member shall speak longer than five (5) minutes at any one (1)
time, except by consent of the board of trustees; and in closing debate on any
question, as above provided, the speaker shall be limited to five W minutes,
except by special consent of the board of trustees.
   (b)   While a trustee is speaking, no trustee shall hold any private
discussion, or pass between the speaker and the chair.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 11))
Sec. 2-87. Call of trustee to order.
A trustee, when called to order by the chair, shall thereupon discontinue
speaking and take his seat, and the order of the ruling of the chair shall be
binding and conclusive, subject only to the right of appeal.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 12))
Sec. 2-88. Appeals from decisions of the chair.
Any member may appeal to the board of trustees from a ruling of the chair, and,
if the appeal is seconded, the trustee making the appeal may briefly state his
reason for the same, and the chair may briefly explain his ruling; but there
shall be no debate on the appeal and no other trustee shall participate in the
discussion. The chair shall then put the question, "Shall the decision of the
chair be sustained?" If a majority of the trustees present vote "no," the
decision of the chair shall be overruled; otherwise, it shall be sustained.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 13))
Sec. 2-89. Question of personal privilege.
The right of a trustee to address the board of trustees on a question of
personal privilege shall be limited to cases in which his integrity, character
or motives are assailed, questioned or impugned.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 14))
Sec. 2-90. Precedence of motions.
   (a)   When a question is under debate, the following motions shall be in
order and shall have precedence over each other in order, as listed:
      (1)   To adjourn to a day certain.
      (2)   To adjourn.
      (3)   To take a recess.
      (4)   To lay on the table.
      (5)   The previous question.
      (6)   To refer.
      (7)   To amend.
      (8)   To defer or postpone to a time certain.
      (9) To defer or postpone without reference to time.
   (b)   Subsections (a)(2), (4) and (5) of this section shall be decided
without debate. (Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 24))
Sec. 2-91. When motion to adjourn in order.
A motion to adjourn the board of trustees shall always be in order except:
      (1)   When a voting member is in possession of the floor.
      (2)   When the trustees are voting.
      (3)   When adjournment was the last preceding motion.
      (4)   When it has been decided that the previous question shall be taken.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 25))
Sec. 2-92. Amending motion to adjourn.
A motion to adjourn shall not be subject to amendment, but a motion to adjourn
to a time certain shall be.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 26))
Sec. 2-93. Previous question.
When the previous question is moved on the main question, it shall be put in
this form: "Shall the main question now be put?" If such motion is carried by a
majority of all the trustees authorized by law to be elected, no further
amendment, motion or debate shall be allowed, and the question shall be put
without delay upon the pending amendments or motion in inverse order of
presentation, and then upon the main question.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 27))
Sec. 2-94. Motion to lay on the table—Generally.
A motion to lay a question on the table shall not be debatable; but a motion to
lay on the table with any other condition shall be subject to amendment and
debate.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 28))
Sec. 2-95. Same—Effect, amendments.
A motion to lay any particular motion or proposition on the table shall apply
to that motion or proposition only. An amendment to the main question or other
pending question may be laid on the table, and neither the main question nor
such other pending question shall be affected thereby.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 29))
Sec. 2-96. Motion to take from the table.
A motion to take any motion or other proposition from the table may be proposed
at the same meeting at which such motion or proposition was laid upon the
table, provided two-thirds of the trustees vote therefor.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 28))
Sec. 2-97. Postponement of action.
Subject to the provisions of section
2-94, considerations of a motion or other proposition may not be postponed
indefinitely. Unless a definite time is set for its subsequent consideration
and final action, a motion to defer or postpone, without any reference to time,
shall be construed as a motion to postpone to the next succeeding regular
meeting.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 30))
Sec. 2-98. Motion to refer.
A motion to refer to a standing committee shall take precedence over a similar
motion to refer to a special committee.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 31))
Sec. 2-99. Motion to amend.
   (a)   A motion to amend an amendment shall be in order, but one to amend an
amendment to an amendment shall not be entertained.
   (b)   An amendment modifying the intention of a motion shall be in order,
but an amendment relating to a different subject shall not be in order.
   (c)   On an amendment to "strike out and insert," the paragraph to be
amended shall first be read as it stands, then the words to be stricken out,
then those to be inserted, and finally the paragraph as it will stand if so
amended shall be read.
   (d)   An amendment to the main question or other pending question may be
referred to a committee and neither the main question nor such other pending
question shall be affected thereby.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 32))
Sec. 2-100. Filling of blanks.
When a blank is to be filled, and different sums or times proposed, the
question shall be taken first on the least sum or the longest time.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 33))
Sec. 2-101. Motion to substitute.
A substitute for any motion under debate or for any pending amendment to such
proposition may be entertained and notwithstanding that at such time future
amendment is admissible. If accepted by the board of trustees by vote, such
substitute shall entirely supersede such original proposition or amendment, as
the case may be, and cut off all amendments appertaining thereto.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 34))
Sec. 2-102. Reconsideration.
   (a)   A vote or question may be reconsidered at any time during the same
meeting or at the first regular meeting held thereafter. A motion for
reconsideration, once having been made and decided in the negative, shall not
be renewed, nor shall a motion to reconsider be reconsidered.
   (b)   A motion to reconsider must be made by the trustee who voted on the
prevailing side of the question to be reconsidered, unless otherwise provided
by law; provided, however, that where a motion has received a majority vote in
the affirmative, but is declared lost solely on the grounds that a greater
number of affirmative votes is required by statute for the passage or adoption
of such motion, then in such case, a motion to reconsider may be made and
seconded only by those who voted in the affirmative on such question to be
considered, so long as the issue presented is the same.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 35))
   State law reference—Restrictions on motions to reconsider, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-
20.
Sec. 2-103. Voting.
Every trustee who shall be present when a question is stated from the chair
shall vote thereon, unless excused by the board of trustees or unless he is
personally interested in the question, in which cases he shall not vote, or if
he refrains from voting and answers "present," in which case the effect will be
the same as if he voted on the prevailing side.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 15))
   State law reference—Pecuniary interests in contracts prohibited, 65 ILCS 5/
3-14-4.
Sec. 2-104. Seconding of motions required; written motions.
No motion shall be put or debated in the board of trustees unless it be
seconded. When a motion is seconded, it shall be stated by the mayor before
debate. Every motion in the board of trustees, except motions of procedure,
shall be reduced to writing, if required by a trustee, and the trustee who
proposed the motion shall be entitled to the floor.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 18))
Sec. 2-105. Withdrawal of motions.
After a motion or resolution is stated by the mayor, it shall be deemed to be
in possession of the board of trustees, but may be withdrawn by the movants at
any time before decision. (Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 19))
Sec. 2-106. Division of questions.
If any question under consideration contains several distinct propositions, the
board of trustees by a majority vote of the trustees present may divide such
question. (Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 20))
Sec. 2-107. Record of motions.
In all cases where a resolution or motion is entered in the minutes, the name
of the trustee moving and seconding the same shall be entered.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 21))
Sec. 2-108. Taking, entering of votes.
The "yes" or "no" or "present" upon any question shall be taken and entered in
the minutes. When the clerk has commenced to call the roll of the board of
trustees or the taking of a vote by "yes" or "no" or "present," all debate on
the question before the board of trustees shall be deemed concluded, and during
the taking of the vote, no trustee shall be permitted to explain his vote, but
shall respond to the calling of his name by the clerk by answering "yes" or
"no" or "present" as the case may be.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 22))
Sec. 2-109. Announcement and changes of votes.
The results of all votes by "yes" or "no" or "present" shall not be announced
by the clerk, but shall be handed by him to the mayor for announcement. No vote
shall be changed after the tally list has passed from the hands of the clerk.
(Code 1965, § 2-54(rule 23))
Secs. 2-110-2-125. Reserved.
DIVISION 4. LEGISLATION*
   *State law reference—Ordinances generally, 65 ILCS 5/1-2-1.
Sec. 2-126. Vote required; when mayor required to vote.
   (a)   All ordinances for whatever purposes, and any resolution or motion, to
create any liability against the village, or for the expenditure or
appropriation of its money, shall require the concurrence of four (4) votes,
unless specifically otherwise provided for by law in special cases.
   (b)   The mayor shall be required to vote on three (3) occasions:
      (1)   Where the vote of the trustees has resulted in a tie;
      (2)   Where one-half of the trustees elected have voted in favor of an
ordinance, resolution or motion, even though there is no tie vote; or
      (3)   Where a vote greater than a majority of the corporate authorities
is required by state law and/or by local ordinance to adopt an ordinance,
resolution or motion.
   (c)   In the latter situation, however, the mayor may not vote when a vote
is being taken to override his veto. The mayor can vote to break a tie when the
issue is the confirmation of an appointment made by him.
Sec. 2-127. Approval or veto.
   (a)   All ordinances passed by the board of trustees, before they take
effect, shall be deposited with the village clerk; and if the mayor approves
thereof, he shall sign the same; and such as he shall not approve, he shall
return to the board of trustees with his objections thereto in writing at the
next regular meeting of the board of trustees occurring not less than 5 days
after their passage. Such veto may extend to any one or more items or
appropriations contained in any ordinance making an appropriation, or to the
entire ordinance; and in case the veto only extends to a part of such
ordinance, the residue thereof shall take effect and be in force. In the case
the mayor shall fail to return any ordinance with his objections thereto by the
time aforesaid, he shall be deemed to have approved such ordinances, and the
same shall take effect accordingly.
   (b)   Upon the return of any ordinance by the mayor, the vote by which the
same was passed shall be reconsidered by the board of trustees. If, after such
reconsideration, two-thirds of all the trustees elected to the board of
trustees shall agree by "yes" and "no" to pass the same, it shall go into
effect notwithstanding the mayor may refuse to approve thereof.
Sec. 2-128. When publication required.
All ordinances imposing a penalty for any violation thereof, or making any
appropriation, shall be published as required by statute, either in the
newspaper or in pamphlet form (in which case, the ordinance and its pamphlet
shall be displayed for a reasonable period in a public place in the village
hall).
Sec. 2-129. Time of taking effect.
No ordinance which must be published to comply with section
2-128 shall go into effect until 10 days after it is so published unless a
statement of the urgency of the ordinance is contained in it, and it achieves
passage by a two-thirds vote of the members of the corporate authorities then
holding office. In all other cases, the ordinances shall go into effect upon
the passage thereof, as provided by law, even though the operation of the
ordinance may not take effect until a later date.
Sec. 2-130. Record of ordinances; publication.
   (a)   All ordinances passed by the mayor and board of trustees shall be kept
by the clerk in an ordinance book.
   (b)   If the ordinance requires publication, the clerk shall cause the same
to be duly published.
Secs. 2-131-2-150. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. OFFICERS AND EMPLOYEES
DIVISION I. GENERALLY
Sec. 2-151. Appointive offices specified; suspension, removal; filling
vacancies.
   (a)   The following appointive offices of the village are hereby created and
established:
      (1)   Village treasurer.
      (2)   Village collector.
      (3)   Water collector.
      (4)   Village prosecutor.
      (5)   Village engineer.
      (6)   Director of Public Works.
      (7)   Street department foreman.
      (8)   Building commissioner.
      (9)   Deputy building commissioner.
      (10)   Deputy code official.
      (11)   Registrar.
      (12)   Recycling director.
      (13)   Youth director.
      (14)   Chief of police.
      (15)   Deputy chief of police.
      (16)   Fire chief.
      (17)   Assistant fire chief.
      (18)   Recreation director.
      (19)   Director of citizen services.
      (20)   Deputy Director of Public Works/Streets.
      (21)   Animal control warden.
      (22)   Health officer.
      (23)   Community center facilities coordinator.
      (24)   Inspectors in all departments.
      (25)   Deputy Director of Public Works/Sewer & Water.
   (b)   All appointees may be suspended or removed from office by the mayor
and board of trustees, and all vacancies may be filled in the same manner as
original appointments.
Sec. 2-152. Qualifications of officers.
No person shall be eligible to hold any appointed village office unless he is a
resident of the village, unless waived by the board of trustees. These
requirements do not apply to the village treasurer, village engineer, village
attorney, village prosecutor, health officer or other officers who require
professional or technical training and certification.
Sec. 2-153. Qualifications of employees.
All village employees shall have the qualifications provided by law.
Sec. 2-154. Residency.
   (a)   All employees of the Village hired after March 1, 1998 shall establish
domicile within the Village no later than 24 months following their initial
employment. All employees of the Village hired after March 1, 1998 shall
continuously maintain domicile within the Village after establishing domicile
therein. Domicile within the Village must be continuously maintained after the
date 24 months following initial employment at the Village.
   (b)   All employees of the Village promoted after March 1, 1998 shall have
domicile within the Village. All employees of the Village promoted after March
1, 1998 shall continuously maintain domicile within the Village.
   (c)   All present employees of the Village who maintain domicile in the
Village on March 1, 1998 shall continuously maintain such domicile within the
Village.
   (d)   Failure of any employee to establish or maintain required domicile in
the Village shall constitute grounds for discharge.
   (e)   Domicile shall be established and maintained under the following
principles:
      (1)   a person can have only one domicile;
      (2)   once a domicile is established, it continues until a new one is
acquired;
      (3)   there must be actual abandonment of a former domicile with no
intent to return; and
      (4)   the new domicile must be acquired with the intent of making it a
true and permanent home.
   (f)   For the purpose of this section "employee" shall mean any officer or
employee of the Village except those requiring professional or technical
training such as the Village Treasurer, Village Engineer, Village Attorney,
Village Prosecutor; and except part-time employees in the Fire Department and
Police Department, and except employees covered by a collective bargaining
agreement which contains a provision on residency (however, promotion to a
supervisory position not covered by the collective bargaining agreement shall
require residency under the provisions of this section) or employees for whom a
collective bargaining agreement is being negotiated.
   (g)   In cases of special need of the Village, the Board of Trustees by
motion at a meeting may waive the requirements of this section.
(Ord. No. 18-2006 § 1, 4-17-06)
Sec. 2-155. Term of appointed officers.
All appointed officers of the village shall hold their offices until the first
Monday of May in each year following their appointments and until their
successors shall have been appointed and qualified.
Sec. 2-156. Oaths of officers.
Before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, all officers of
the village shall take the oath of office prescribed by law.
Sec. 2-157. Bonds of officers.
   (a)   The officers of the village shall give bonds in the sums and within
the time as provided by law. In all cases not specifically provided for, the
officers of the village shall give such bonds and within such time as the mayor
and board of trustees may require, or as may be required by law. Should good
cause exist in the judgment and discretion of the board of trustees, any
officer may be required from time to time to give additional bonds in such sum
and within such time as the board may by resolution direct.
   (b)   The bond of each officer shall be executed to the village with 2 or
more sureties conditioned for the faithful performance of the duties of his
office and the payment to the proper officer of all moneys coming into his
hands by virtue of his office. Each of such sureties shall be freeholders of
the county, and shall schedule real estate herein, clear of all encumbrances
and other legal obligations, in value not less than the penal sum of such bond,
which schedule shall be made separately by such sureties and sworn to before an
officer authorized to administer oaths, and attached to such bond. Any officer
of the village may procure as surety upon any bond he may be required to give
any responsible surety company or corporation. No member of the board of
trustees shall sign any bond in any case wherein the village is interested.
   (c)   The bonds of all village officers shall be subject to the approval of
the mayor and board of trustees. Upon approval, the clerk shall endorse thereon
the date thereof and file the same in his office, excepting, however, the bond
of the clerk, which shall be filed with the treasurer.
Sec. 2-158. Reserved.
Sec. 2-159. Officer or employee to surrender village property upon termination
of service.
Every officer or employee of the village, upon the termination of his term or
service for any cause whatsoever, shall deliver to the mayor or the department
head all property, equipment, badges, uniforms, identification cards, and
records within 5 days after termination.
Sec. 2-160. Inspection of records kept by officers and employees; reports.
All books, papers, vouchers, warrants, entries, accounts and memoranda of each
and every officer and employee of the village may be examined at any time by
the mayor. The mayor and board of trustees may, by resolution, call upon any
officer to make a report in writing of any subject matter which the board may
designate in such resolution and within such time as such resolution may
prescribe.
(Code 1965, § 2-12)
   State law reference—Authority of mayor to examine records, 65 ILCS 5/3-12-2,
5/3-11-3.
Sec. 2-161. Indemnification.
   (a)   The village shall, under the conditions imposed herein:
      (1)   Appoint counsel to appear and defend, or reimburse the fees of an
attorney who appears and defends; and
      (2)   Pay all judgments, verdicts, claims and costs resulting from any
claim or lawsuit;
on behalf of any officer or employee of the village or any former officer or
employee of the village.
   (b)   The appointment of counsel, reimbursement for costs of counsel, and
payment of all judgments, shall be a matter of right, but shall cover only
those duties or actions committed by the employee or officer within the course
of employment within the scope of his duties, or by the nature of the office or
employment held if all conditions herein are met. The appoint. ment of counsel
to defend or the reimbursement of other counsel shall be at the option of the
board of trustees.
   (c)   Any person desiring to avail themselves of the provisions of this
section must within five (5) days after receiving a notice of claim, or
summons, whichever occurs first, notify the mayor, board of trustees, and
attorney in writing of the possible claim. Only claims by individuals other
than village employees or officers are covered by this section. Without
limitation, this section does not cover any claim against the village by an
officer or employee, by the village against any officer or employee, or by any
fellow employee or officer against any officer or employee.
   (d)   No person shall be entitled to any of the benefits of this section if
any action or inaction on his part was done with malice or willful misconduct,
where there is a finding of "guilty" against him in a criminal or quasicriminal
action, or where there is a finding of malice or willful misconduct in any
civil action or civil rights action.
   (e)   The provisions of this section do not apply where there is insurance
coverage or where an insurance carrier appears and defends an action.
   (f)   No reimbursement for any attorney's fees shall be paid until the board
of trustees is satisfied that the action being defended falls within the
provisions of this section. Should attorney's fees he reimbursed and the
subsequent decision of a court result in the employee or officer not being
eligible under the conditions of this section, then such monies shall be paid
back to the village within thirty (30) days of a demand by the village. Any
rate or fees paid to an attorney shall have prior approval of the village, and
reimbursement shall only be made at such rate or fees as is approved by the
village.
   (g)   No person who makes any settlement, compromise or statement without
the knowledge of the village shall be eligible for any of the benefits of this
section.
   (h)   The provisions of this section shall apply to any lawsuit instituted
after the date of passage, or any claim or investigation instituted after the
date of its passage.
   (i)   Notwithstanding any of the above provisions, should the mayor or any
trustee be sued on account of any vote they have or have not made on any
action, motion, item, resolution or ordinance, then the official shall be
entitled to either hire counsel and have those attorneys' fees reimbursed at a
rate approved by the board of trustees or have the village attorney appear on
his behalf. That official shall also be entitled to the right of having the
village pay any and all judgments, verdicts, claims and costs provided there is
no court or jury finding that the official acted with malice or intentional
misconduct.
(Code 1965, § 2-91)
   State law reference—Local Governmental and Governmental Employees Tort
Immunity Act, 745 ILCS 10/1-101.
Secs. 2-162-2-180. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. VILLAGE ATTORNEY*
Sec. 2-181. Duties generally.
The village attorney shall be responsible for all legal matters pertaining to
the village and draw such ordinances, deeds, leases and other papers as may be
required of him by the mayor and board of trustees or any committee thereof.
(Code 1965, § 2-88)
Sec. 2-182. Legal opinions.
The village attorney shall give his opinion in writing to the board of trustees
or any committee thereof or the mayor, when requested, on legal questions
arising under or concerning any section of this Code or any ordinance of the
village, and on questions and subjects in which the village shall be legally
interested.
(Code 1965, § 2-89)
Secs. 2-183-2-200. Reserved.
*State law reference—Appointment of village attorney, 65 ILCS 5/3-7-3.
DIVISION 3. VILLAGE PROSECUTOR
Sec. 2-201. Office created.
There is hereby created the office of village prosecutor.
Sec. 2-202. Duties.
The duties of the village prosecutor shall include the prosecution of all
matters appearing on the regularly scheduled village court call.
DIVISION 4. VILLAGE CLERK
Sec. 2-216. Compensation of village clerk.
   (a)   The village clerk shall receive as annual compensation the sum of
$80,000.00 effective with the commencement of the term of office following the
2025 consolidated election. On May 1, 2026, and on each succeeding May 1
thereafter, the compensation to be paid to the village clerk shall be increased
by 2.0% over that paid in the previous period.
   (b)   The base salary of the village clerk shall also be increased for each
of the following certifications: (i) by the sum of $5,000.00 for Registered
Municipal Clerk, (ii) by the sum of $5,000.00 for Certified Municipal Clerk,
and (iii) by the sum of $7,500.00 for Master Municipal Clerk.
   (c)   Compensation shall be paid in installments in the same manner as for
other employees of the village. The above rate of compensation does not include
benefits or expenses currently provided to village clerk.
(Am. Ord. 25-2012 § 3, 9-4-12; Am. Ord. 8-2024 § 1, 2-5-24)
Sec. 2-217.    Duties.
The village clerk shall, in addition to the duties now imposed upon that
officer by statute, perform the following duties:
      (1)   Keep office in the village hall for the transaction of village
business during usual daily business hours.
      (2)   Issue notices of meetings to the mayor and members of the village
board, and when directed by that body, to the members of the different
committees of that body and to all persons whose attendance will be required
before that body or any such committee when so directed; he shall also issue
and cause to be served notices of such meetings.
      (3)   Attest all the licenses granted under the provisions of this Code
or ordinances of the village.
      (4)   Deliver to the officers of the village and to the various
committees, all bills, resolutions, communications and other documents
referring to such officers and committees.
      (5)   Deliver to the mayor all ordinances or resolutions which may
require approval or other action by the mayor with all papers and information
on which the same were founded.
      (6)   Perform such other duties as may be legally required.
      (7)   Keep the corporate seal and affix the seal to all papers which
require it.
      (8)   Keep all records and papers belonging to the village and attend all
meetings of the mayor and board of trustees, and keep a full record of its
proceedings in the journal.
      (9)   Make proper copies of all papers duly filed and make transcripts
from the journal and other records and files, certified under the corporate
seal.
Sec. 2-218. Notice to elected and appointed officers.
It shall be the duty of the village clerk, within 5 days after the canvass of
an election is
completed, to notify in writing all persons elected to office.
Sec. 2-219. Publication of annual treasurer's report.
The village clerk shall, within 6 months after the end of each fiscal year and
after having received a copy of the annual treasurer's report, publish a notice
in a newspaper advising of the availability of the annual report, and that the
same may be inspected or copied at the office of the village clerk.
Sec. 2-220. Petitions; communications.
All petitions, remonstrances, bids, bills or other communications addressed to
the village or board of trustees shall be received by the village clerk and
forwarded to the mayor and trustees for appropriate action.
DIVISION 5. VILLAGE TREASURER
Sec. 2-241. Compensation.
The compensation of the village treasurer shall be as prescribed by the mayor
and board of trustees from time to time.
Sec. 2-242. Duties generally.
   (a)   The village treasurer shall receive all moneys belonging to the
village and shall render at the end of each and every month, to the board of
trustees, showing the state of the treasury at the date of such account, and
the balance of the money in the treasury. Such statement shall set forth all
the moneys received by him, from whom, and on what account they shall have been
received; also all moneys paid out by him, and on what account they shall have
been paid. Such monthly report shall be under oath.
   (b)   The village treasurer shag keep by double entry a full and detailed
account of all village funds, general tax receipts and receipts from other
sources. He shall also keep a bond account, sinking fund account and forfeit
account in the village ledger. He shall keep auxiliary accounts with the clerk,
collector and with the county collector, showing all moneys received and
disbursed by the treasurer.
   (c)   He shall also keep books of account, in such manner as to accurately
show all moneys received by him, from whom, and on what account they shall have
been received; also all moneys paid out by him and on what account they have
been paid. Such books shall be kept in such manner as to be readily understood
and investigated; which books and all papers and files of the office shall at
all times be open to the examination of the mayor and board of trustees or any
member thereof.
Sec. 2-243. Special fund ledger.
The village treasurer shall keep a "special fund" ledger in which all special
funds shall be kept separately by numbers and names of the special funds,
showing the total amount of each fund and installment of same to be collected
and each account to show the total collections and disbursements on account of
same.
Sec. 2-244. Deposit of funds.
   (a)   All funds and money belonging to the village in the custody of the
village treasurer shall be kept on deposit with such bank as shall be
designated by ordinance as a depository for such funds and money. Such bank
shall not be qualified to receive funds or money of the village until it has
furnished the corporate authorities with two (2) copies of the last two (2)
sworn statements of resources and liabilities which the bank is required to
furnish to the commissioner of banks and trust companies or to the comptroller
of the currency, and such bank while acting as such depository shall furnish
the corporate authorities with a copy of all statements of resources and
liabilities which it is required to furnish to the commissioner of banks and
trust companies or to the comptroller of currency. The village treasurer shall
be discharged from responsibility for all funds or money which he deposits in
such bank while the funds and money are so deposited; provided, however, that
the amount of such deposits shall not exceed seventy-five (75) percent of such
bank's capital stock and surplus and the village treasurer shall be responsible
for funds or money deposited in such bank in excess of this limitation.
   (b)   Such funds or money shall be subject to withdrawal from time to time
upon checks or combination voucher-checks signed in person or by facsimile by
the village treasurer, the mayor of the board of trustees, and the village
clerk.
Secs. 2-245-2-260. Reserved.
DIVISION 6. VILLAGE COLLECTOR
Sec. 2-261. Village collector.
The village collector shall be appointed by the mayor with the advice and
consent of the board of trustees. The village clerk may hold the office of
village collector.
Sec. 2-262. Compensation of village collector.
The village collector shall receive as compensation the sum of $18,000 per year
effective May 1, 1997. Compensation shall be paid in installments in the same
manner as for employees of the village. If the village clerk is appointed the
village collector, the compensation for the village collector shall not be
increased or decreased during the term of office.
Sec. 2-263. Duties of village collector.
The village collector shall preserve all warrants and shall keep books and
accounts in the manner prescribed by the board of trustees. All of the village
collector's warrants, books and vouchers, and all papers pertaining to the
office, may be examined at any time by the mayor, village clerk or any member
of the board of trustees. Weekly, and oftener if required by the board of
trustees, the village collector shall pay over to the treasurer all money
collected from any source, taking the treasurer's receipt in duplicate and
filing one of the receipts immediately with the village clerk. At that time, or
on demand, the village clerk shall give the village collector a copy of any
receipts so filed.
Sec. 2-264. Reports of village collector.
The village collector shall make a written report to the board of trustees of
all money collected and the account on which collected.
Sec. 2-265. Possession of money by village collector.
The village collector is prohibited from keeping the money of the village in
his possession, or in the possession of any person for his use, beyond the time
prescribed for its payment to the village treasurer.
Sec. 2-266. Delinquent assessments; collection, receipt.
   (a)   The village collector shall have power and authority to collect all
special assessments, including delinquent installments.
   (b)   Upon receiving payment for such delinquent installments of special
assessments, interest, costs and penalties, the village collector shall issue
to the person paying the same a receipt of deposit for redemption, according to
law.
Sec. 2-267. Examination of books.
All the village collector's papers, books and vouchers may be examined at any
time by the mayor or any member of the board of trustees.
Secs. 2-268-2-285. Reserved.
DIVISION 7. DIRECTOR OF CITIZENS' SERVICES
Sec. 2-286. Position created.
There is hereby created the office of director of citizens' services.
Sec. 2-287. General duties.
It shall be the duty of the director of citizens' services to investigate such
programs as information services, transportation arrangements, nutrition
centers, discounts, social clubs, and specific village facilities for usage by
and in behalf of the senior citizens and the disabled in the village. After
such investigation and study, the director of citizens' services shall
recommend for adoption to the mayor and board of trustees such of the above
programs as he feels may be suitable for the senior citizens and the disabled
in the community.
Secs. 2-288-2-300. Reserved.
DIVISION 8. RECREATION DIRECTOR
Sec. 2-301. Office created.
There is hereby created the office of recreation director.
Sec. 2-302. Duties.
The recreation director shall be directly responsible to the mayor and board of
trustees of the village and shall, on a regular basis, submit reports to them
on the conduct of existing recreational and entertainment programs and the
proposal of new programs, which proposal shall contain his recommendation
regarding implementation, cost, feasibility, etc.
Secs. 2-303-2-309. Reserved.
DIVISION 9. INTERGOVERNMENTAL AND COMMUNITY RELATIONS ADVISOR
Sec. 2-310. Office created.
There is hereby established the office of Intergovernmental and Community
Relations Advisor which shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees.
Sec. 2-311. Duties.
The Intergovernmental and Community Relations Advisor shall have the following
duties:
      (1)   Represent the Village with respect to matters delegated by the
Mayor which involve other municipalities including the Southwest Conference of
Local Governments.
      (2)   Represent the Village with respect to matters delegated by the
Mayor which involve Cook County and the Metropolitan Water Reclamation District
of Greater Chicago.
      (3)   Represent the Village with respect to matters delegated by the
Mayor which involve legislation of the General Assembly of the State of
Illinois which have an effect on the Village.
      (4)   Represent the Village with respect to matters delegated by the
Mayor which involve legislation of the United States Congress which have an
effect on the Village.
      (5)   Represent the Village with respect to matters delegated by the
Mayor which involve residents and businesses, including the Chamber of Commerce
and EPSA, in the Village and the effect of Village ordinances and policies
thereon.
      (6)   Represent the Village with respect to matters delegated by the
Mayor which involve roads and highways within the Village under the
jurisdiction of the Illinois Department of Transportation.
Sec. 2-312. Reports.
The Intergovernmental and Community Relations Advisor shall act under the
jurisdiction of the Mayor and shall prepare such reports as requested by the
Mayor.
Secs. 2-313-2-320. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. FINANCE
Sec. 2-321. Fiscal year.
The fiscal year of the village shall begin on the first day of November of each
year and end on the thirty-first day of October of the year following.
Sec. 2-322. Annual independent audit of village accounts.
At the close of each fiscal year, the mayor and board of trustees shall cause
an independent audit of all accounts of the village to be made by an accountant
or accountants authorized to practice accounting under the laws of the state.
Sec. 2-323. Form of warrants; payment of checks, signatures.
The payment of village debts shall be authorized by resolution of the mayor and
board of trustees. Upon such authorization, the village treasurer shall cause
payment to be made thereof by checks upon the village treasury with the
signatures of any two (2) of the following three (3) officials: the mayor,
village clerk and village treasurer, the particular fund and appropriation to
which the same is chargeable and the person to whom the same is payable clearly
shown thereon. The signatures required may be made by the use of an approved
check-signing machine.
Sec. 2-324. Bidding of contracts.
All public improvement construction contracts not paid for by special
assessment or special taxation in the amount of one hundred thousand dollars
($100,000) or more shall be constructed by a contract let to the lowest
responsible bidder unless two-thirds (2/3) of the Mayor and Board of Trustees
waive any public bidding requirements. The provisions of this section shall not
apply to contracts constructed pursuant to an agreement with a federal, state,
or other governmental agency.
(Am. Ord. No. § 1, 4-4-11)
Sec. 2-325.    Emergency contracts.
The Mayor may authorize any contract or expenditure of funds in an amount not
to exceed one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) in case of emergency where
the public health, safety and welfare is in immediate danger. If such power is
exercised then the Mayor shall report the nature of the emergency wand the
contract at the next meeting of the Board of Trustees.
(Am. Ord. No. § 2, 4-4-11)
Secs. 2-326-2-345. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Secs. 2-346-2-360. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. BOARD OF FIRE AND POLICE COMMISSIONERS
Sec. 2-361. Adoption of state law, modifications.
   (a)   There is hereby adopted for the purpose of establishing the Board of
Fire and Police Commissioners, and the regulations and laws controlling such
Board, Article 10, Division 2.1 of the Illinois Municipal Code (65 ILCS 5/10-
2.1, et seq.). Notwithstanding the foregoing, the following provisions shall
not apply to the Board or the members of the Fire and Police Departments:
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-4
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-6
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-7
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-8 through 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-11
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-13 through 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-18
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-23 through 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-27
65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-29 through 65 ILCS 5/10-2.1-30
   (b)   The Board is hereby authorized to establish such rules as it
determines necessary in the performance of its duties concerning the
examination of applicants for original appointments, promotional examinations,
and discipline of members of the Fire and Police Departments.
   (c)   Any provision in Article 10, Division 2.1 of the Illinois Municipal
Code which is in conflict with the express or implied powers conferred on the
Board of Fire and Police Commissioners under the Evergreen Park Municipal Code,
including any rules adopted by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners, is
hereby declared to be of no force and effect in the Village.
Sec. 2-362 Original Employment - Police Department.
   (a)   Appointment. All original appointments of full-time sworn employees of
the Police Department shall be made by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners from the original eligibility register.
   (b)   Original Examination. All applicants for employment as a full-time
sworn patrol officer shall be subject to an original entrance examination by
the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners. The examination shall be public,
competitive, and subject to limitations as to age, health, habits, moral
character, and qualifications to perform the duties of the position of patrol
officer. Examinations may be written and oral; and shall include tests of
physical qualifications. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall
determine the method, manner and weight of examination and shall determine a
minimum passing grade for each component and the total examination. Upon
conclusion of the original entrance examination, the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners shall prepare an original eligibility register of candidates who
have attained the minimum passing grade for each component and the total
examination. Candidates shall be ranked by score. The original eligibility
register shall expire 2 years from its date subject to extension as provided
for in Sec. 2-367.
   (c)   Appointment Procedure. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall determine
that a vacancy exists in the rank of patrol officer such that an appointment
shall be made. In such event the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall
make an appointment from the top 3 names then on the original eligibility
register. Once an appointment is made, the applicant must pass a medical,
physical, background and drug test. In the event of failure, the applicant
shall be disqualified (without notice, hearing or appeal) and the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners shall appoint another person from the original
eligibility register.
   (d)   Lateral Hire. Notwithstanding the foregoing provisions of this
Section, the Mayor and Board of Trustees may appoint any person to the Police
Department who is certified under the Illinois Police Training Act as a full-
time law enforcement officer and has a minimum of two years' experience on a
municipal police department, or its equivalent, in the rank of patrol officer.
The applicant may be given preference in appointment over candidates on the
original eligibility roster established by the Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners. In such event, the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners may
conduct a background investigation, medical examination, psychological
examination, oral interview, polygraph examination and any other examination to
determine fitness for duty. The Board of Fire and Police Commissioners is
authorized, to adopt rules governing the qualification, application process and
examination process for applicants under this subsection. No candidate shall be
appointed until the Mayor and Board of Trustees determine that there is a
vacancy in the rank of patrol officer. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall
establish the level of compensation for the lateral hire.
(Am. Ord. No. 16-2022, § 1, 8-15-22)
Sec. 2-362.1. Promotions - Police Department.
   (a)   Appointment. All promotions of full-time sworn employees of the Police
Department shall be made by the Mayor with the advice and consent of the Board
of Trustees from a roster of eligible candidates provided by the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners. Promotions shall be made from the rank next below to
which the promotion is made except for the ranks of Chief and Deputy Chief.
   (b)   Promotional Examination. All applicants for promotion shall be subject
to a promotional examination by the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners.
Promotional examinations shall be competitive among such members of the next
lower rank as desire to submit to examination. Promotional examinations shall
test the ability, qualifications, judgment, and character of the applicant to
perform the duties of the rank. Examinations may be written and oral; and may
include tests of physical qualifications. The Board of Fire and Police
Commissioners shall determine the method, manner and weight of examination and
shall determine a minimum passing grade for each component and the total
examination. Upon conclusion of the promotional examination, the Board of Fire
and Police Commissioners shall prepare an promotional eligibility register of
candidates who have attained the minimum passing grade for each component and
the total examination. Candidates shall not be ranked by score. All candidates
listed on the promotional eligibility register shall be considered available
for placement on the promotion roster. The promotional eligibility register
shall expire 3 years from its date subject to extension as provided for in Sec.
2-367.
   (c)   Appointment Procedure. The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall determine
that a vacancy exists in any rank such that a promotion shall be made. In such
event the Board of Fire and Police Commissioners shall provide a promotion
roster of 5 names from the promotional eligibility register and the Mayor shall
make an appointment of one of the names from that roster. The Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners may place any 5 names on the roster.
Sec. 2-362.2.   Police Chief, Deputy Chief of Police, Fire Chief, and Assistant
Fire Chief.
   (a)   Appointment. The Police Chief, Deputy Chiefs of Police, Fire Chief and
the Assistant Fire Chiefs shall be appointed by the Mayor with the advice and
consent of the Board of Trustees. Appointments to these positions shall not be
limited to the next lower rank.
   (b)   Discipline. The Police Chief, Deputy Chiefs of Police, Fire Chief and
the Assistant Fire Chiefs are subject to suspension, demotion, removal,
reappointment and discipline (except that a person holding a classified service
rank can only be discharged through a hearing before the Board of Fire and
Police Commissioners) by the Mayor and Board of Trustees without notice and
hearing, and whose decision is final. In the event that the appointee is not
reappointed or demoted and also holds a classified service rank, the person
shall revert back to that rank.
Sec. 2-363. Demotions.
The board of fire and police commissioners shall have the power to demote a
person one (1) step in rank upon written charges and for cause, or upon its
finding that the performance of the person is not satisfactory and acceptable,
or upon its finding that there is some substantial shortcoming which renders
continuance in that specific rank detrimental to the discipline and efficiency
of the fire and police departments. It shall have no power to demote or remove
the chief in each department in that rank. It may, however, demote, remove or
suspend them in permanent rank.
Sec. 2-364. Probationary periods.
   (a)   Fire. All new members of the fire department shall serve a
probationary period of two (2) years of active duty for all new members whether
or not they have previously been certified by the state fire marshal as having
successfully completed an approved training course.
   (b)   Police. All new members of the police department shall serve the
following probationary period:
      (1)   One (1) year of active duty for all new members who were former
members of a regular police department of a municipality and who have been
certified by the Illinois Local Government Law Enforcement Officers Training
