P     Banquet party consumption on premises                   1      1,400.00
S     Government-owned sports facility                        1      25.00
 
   (b)   The number of licenses authorized in this section for all classes
shall remain at the number set forth in this section; provided, however, that
any license in such classes which is revoked, or not used because of the
termination of liquor business on the premises for which the license has been
issued, shall automatically reduce the number of authorized licenses of the
particular class by the total number of revoked or not used licenses in the
particular class and shall reduce the total number of licenses available.
(Ord. No. 21-2005 § 1, 7-18-05; Am. Ord. No. 36-2007 § 1, 10-15-07; Am. Ord.
No. 13-2008 § 1, 4-21-08; Am. Ord. No. 7-2010 § 1, 4-19-10; Am. Ord. No. 10-
2010 § 1, 5-17-10; Am. Ord. No. 14-2010, § 1, 11-15-10; Am. Ord. No. 15-2011 §
1, 10-17-11; Am. Ord. No. 6-2012 § 3, 3-5-12; Am. Ord. No. 7-2012 § 1, 3-19-12;
Am. Ord. No. 9-2012 § 2, 4-16-12; Am. Ord. No. 15-2013 § 1, 7-1-13; Am. Ord.
No. 19-2014 § 1, 9-2-14; Am. Ord. No. 21-2014 § 2, 9-15-14; Am. Ord. No. 22-
2014 § 1, 10-6-14; Am. Ord. No. 28-2014 § 2, 12-15-14; Am. Ord. No. 22-2015 §
2, 9-8-15; Am. Ord. No. 15-2016 § 2, 5-2-16; Am. Ord. No. 1-2017 § 1, 1-3-17;
Am. Ord. No. 13-2017 § 1, 6-5-17; Am. Ord. No. 14-2017 § 1, 6-19-17; Am. Ord.
No. 10-2018 § 1, 4-2-18; Am. Ord. No. 26-2018 § 1, 10-15-18; Am. Ord. No. 6-
2019 § 1, 3-18-19; Am. Ord. No. 25-2019 § 1, 10-7-19; Am. Ord. No. 26-2019 § 1,
11-4-19; Am. Ord. No. 9-2021 § 1, 7-19-21; Am. Ord. No. 3-2022, § 1, 2-7-22;
Am. Ord. No. 4-2022, § 1, 3-7-22; Am. Ord. No. 7-2022, § 1, 4-18-22; Am. Ord.
No. 6-2023 § 3, 3-6-23; Am. Ord. No. 17-2023 § 1, 9-5-23; Am. Ord. No. 26-2024
§ 3, 10-21-24)
Sec. 3-59. Temporary licenses.
   (a)   The local liquor control commissioner may issue temporary liquor
licenses for a period not to exceed 5 days for any special event. The type of
alcoholic beverages to be served, the place of service, and the hours of
service shall be established by the local liquor control commissioner. The fee
for a temporary liquor license shall be $25 per day.
   (b)   The local liquor control commissioner may extend the hours for opening
or closing any licensed premises for any special event, including but not
limited to Super Bowl Sunday, St. Patrick's Day, and other similar events, or
an event unique to a premises.
   (c)   The local liquor control commissioner may issue a caterer's license
for a period not to exceed 2 days to allow a commercial enterprise to bring and
sell alcoholic liquor onto a premises which are not licensed for sale and
consumption of alcoholic liquor. The fee for a caterer's license shall be $25
for every event not to exceed 2 days.
(Ord. No. 13-2008 § 1, 4-21-08)
Sec. 3-60. Location.
   No alcoholic beverage shall be sold, offered for sale, kept for sale,
displayed, advertised for sale at retail, or delivered to any person, except at
the location, place or premises described in a liquor license. All alcoholic
beverages shall be sold and consumed inside of the licensed premises and not
outside of any building on the licensed premises except where specific approval
has been obtained from the Local Liquor Control Commissioner for a "lanai" or
other similar outdoor seating area. If outdoor seating is allowed on the
sidewalk, public street, or public parkway, the licensee shall provide
liability and dram shop insurance naming the village as an additional insured.
(Ord. No. 13-2008 § 1, 4-21-08; Am. Ord. No. 9-2021 § 2, 7-19-21)
Sec. 3-61. Suspension or revocation.
   (a)   At all hearings, proceedings shall be taken and prepared by a
certified court reporter; and an appeal shall be limited to a review of the
certified official record of the proceedings of the local liquor control
commissioner. The village attorney shall act as law officer, ask questions to
clarify statements, advise the local commissioner on procedure and law, and
otherwise assist the local commissioner in the conduct of the hearings. He
shall not act as judge or jury or assist the local commissioner in making
findings and determinations.
   (b)   The local liquor control commissioner shall have the power to suspend
any license for a period of not to exceed 60 days. In the case of revocation of
any license, the local liquor control commissioner shall have the power to
allow the use of the premises for the sale of alcoholic liquors after 90 days
from the date of such revocation upon his determination that the public good
will be served.
   (c)   He shall also have the power to fine the licensee a sum not to exceed
$2,000 for each act of violation, and the costs of the proceedings, including
reasonable attorney's fees. The provisions of this subsection shall be
cumulative to other powers given the mayor.
   (d)   He shall also have the power to require a licensee and employees
thereof to complete the Beverage Alcohol Sellers and Servers Education and
Training (BASSET) program, whether or not a formal charge has been filed with
respect to a violation. Failure to complete the BASSET program as required by
the local liquor control commissioner shall be grounds for suspension or
revocation of a liquor license.
(Ord. No. 13-2008 § 1, 4-21-08)
Chapter 4
ANIMAL CONTROL
   Art. I.   Animals, Generally, §§ 4-1 - 4-19
   Art. II.   Dogs and Cats, §§ 4-20 - 4-29
   Art. III.   Dog Park, §§ 4-30 - 4-40
   *Cross references–Health, ch.
9; nuisances, ch.
14.
   State law references–Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6;
Animal Control Act, 510 ILCS 5/1 et seq.
ARTICLE I. ANIMALS, GENERALLY
Sec. 4-1. Definitions.
   The following words, terms and phrases when used in this chapter shall have
the following meanings:
   Administrator means as defined in the Animal Control Act.
   Animal means every living creature, domestic or wild, not including human
beings.
   Animal control warden means an agent or employee of the village with
authority and responsibility for the administration of this chapter.
   At-large means any dog on public property, or any private property without
permission, when not under restraint.
   Cat means Felis catus.
   Dangerous animal means any animal which, without provocation, attacks or
injures a person who is peaceably conducting himself in any place where he or
she is lawfully authorized to be present. Dangerous animals shall include any
animal which, because of its size, vicious propensity or other characteristics,
would constitute a danger to life if not restrained or kept in a safe manner.
Examples of dangerous animals include: lion, tiger, leopard, ocelot, jaguar,
cheetah, margay, mountain lion, lynx, bobcat, jaguarundi, bear, hyena, wolf or
coyote, or any poisonous or life-threatening reptile.
   Dangerous dog means (i) any individual dog anywhere other than upon the
property of the owner or custodian of the dog and unmuzzled, unleashed, or
unattended by its owner that behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would
believe poses a serious and unjustified imminent threat of serious physical
injury or death to a person or a companion animal or (ii) a dog that, without
justification, bites a person and does not cause serious physical injury.
   Deputy Administrator means as defined in the Animal Control Act.
   Dog means all members of the family Canidae.
   Domestic animal means any animal which is not wild, and is tame and owned as
a pet.
   Enclosure means a fence or structure of at least six (6) feet in height,
forming or causing an enclosure suitable to prevent the entry of young
children, and suitable to confine a vicious dog in conjunction with other
measures that may be taken by the owner or keeper, such as tethering of the
vicious dog within the enclosure. The enclosure shall be securely enclosed and
locked and designed with secure sides, top, and bottom and shall be designed to
prevent the animal from escaping from the enclosure. If the enclosure is a room
within a residence, it cannot have direct ingress from or egress to the
outdoors unless it leads directly to an enclosed pen and the door must be
locked. A vicious dog may be allowed to move about freely within the entire
residence if it is muzzled at all times.
   Farm animal means breeds of animals which can or may be used in and for the
preparation of meat or meat products for consumption by human beings or
animals, including but not limited to, cattle, chickens, ducks, geese, sheep,
swine, horses, mules, goats, and other fowl or livestock.
   Impounded means taken into the custody of the Village of Evergreen Park or
the County of Cook, as the case may be.
   Owner means any person identified as the owner of an animal on any license,
or having a right of property in an animal, or who keeps or harbors any animal,
or who has an animal in his or her care or control, or acts as its custodian,
or who knowingly permits an animal to remain on any premises occupied by him or
her.
   Person means any individual, firm, association, partnership, corporation, or
other legal entity.
   Physical injury means the impairment of physical condition.
   Potentially dangerous dog means a dog that is unsupervised and found running
at large with three (3) or more other dogs.
   Serious physical injury means a physical injury that creates a substantial
risk of death or that causes death, serious disfigurement, protracted
impairment of health, impairment of the function of any bodily organ, or
plastic surgery.
   Under restraint means: (i) under the control of the owner or other
responsible person by means of a leash, cord, rope, strap, chain, or lead held
by such owner or person, and securely fastened to the collar or harness
attached to the dog; or (ii) securely enclosed, confined, or restrained on
premises where the dog lawfully may be located, so as to be unable to enter
upon the public way or adjacent properties or to interfere with persons
lawfully using the public way or adjacent properties.
   Vicious dog means a dog that, without justification, attacks a person and
causes serious physical injury or death or any individual dog that has been
found to be a "dangerous dog" upon three (3) separate occasions.
   Wild animal means any naturally wild animals, including but not limited to
deer, feral cats, feral dogs, raccoons, skunk, opossum or coyote.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-2. Animal control warden.
   There is hereby created the position of animal control warden who shall have
the power, in addition to law enforcement personnel, to issue citations, take
complaints, make arrests, impound animals, and do all things necessary and
expedient to enforce the provisions of this chapter and/or the Animal Control
Act.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-3. Animal bites.
   The Evergreen Park Police Department shall investigate all reports of animal
bites.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-4. Animal care.
   Every owner of an animal shall provide to such animal:
   (a)   A sufficient quantity of good and wholesome food and water;
   (b)   Adequate shelter and protection from the weather;
   (c)   Veterinary care when needed to prevent suffering; and
   (d)   Humane care and treatment.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-5. Miscellaneous offenses.
   No owner shall permit or suffer an animal to:
   (a)   Molest persons or vehicles by chasing, parking or biting;
   (b)   Attack another animal;
   (c)   Damage property of another person;
   (d)   Bark, whine or howl excessively; or
   (e)   Create noxious or offensive odors.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-6. Dangerous animals..
   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, care for, act as
custodian of or maintain in his/her possession any dangerous animal in the
village.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-7. Farm animals.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, care for, act as
custodian of or maintain in his/her possession any farm animal in the village.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-8. Pigeons.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep, harbor, care for, act as
custodian of or maintain in his/her possession any pigeon.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-9. Feeding or attracting animals.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct an activity or create a
condition to attract any domestic or wild animal in a manner that causes damage
to property or creates a hazard to the health of others.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to feed any wild animal (other
than grain, seed, or bird feed purchased at a store).
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain one or more
feeder(s) for animals on his/her property having a combined total surface area
of more than one (1) square foot.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-10. Animals as door prizes or as attractions for trade.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to give away any live vertebrate animal
as a prize for, or as an inducement to enter any contest, game or other
competition, or as an inducement to enter a place of amusement, or to offer
such vertebrate as an incentive to enter into any business agreement whereby
the offer was for the purpose of attracting trade.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-11. Penalty and administration.
   (a)   Any person violating any provision of this article shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during on which a violation
occurs or continues.
   (b)   Violations of this article may be administered through the provisions
of Chapter 12, Miscellaneous Provisions and Offenses, Article X, Administrative
Adjudication of Non-Vehicular Regulations Violations, of the Evergreen Park
Municipal Code, or by any other means permitted by law. Nothing in this chapter
shall be interpreted to limit the remedies or penalties available to Village of
Evergreen Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Secs. 4-12 through 4-19. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. DOGS AND CATS
Sec. 4-20.   Number of dogs and cats.
   It shall be unlawful to keep or maintain more than three (3) dogs or three
(3) cats of two (2) months of age or older in any single-family residence,
building or lot or to keep or maintain more than one (1) dog or one (1) cat of
two (2) months of age or older in any family unit of a multifamily residence or
in a business establishment within the village. This section shall not apply to
licensed pet shops, animal hospitals, animal grooming establishments or
kennels.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-21.   Licenses.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any owner to keep or maintain any dog or cat
that is not licensed by the village.
   (b)   Every owner of a dog or cat in the village shall annually apply to the
Village Clerk for a license for each dog or cat. Applications for licenses
shall be submitted to the Village Clerk no later than May 31 of each calendar
year, and licenses shall be valid from May 1 through April 30. Applications
shall identify the name and address of the owner, and the name, breed, color,
sex and age of each dog or cat to be licensed. The owner shall also submit
proof of vaccination. An annual license fee of five dollars ($5.00) per dog or
cat shall be paid to the Village Clerk at the time of application. An
additional fee of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) shall be charged per
license purchased on or after June 1 of the year; provided, however, that such
penalty shall not be charged to applicants who apply for a license within
thirty (30) days after acquiring the dog or cat to be licensed.
   (c)   The Village Clerk shall issue to the owner of each dog and cat
licensed a durable tag, stamped with an identifying number and with the year of
issuance.
   (d)   The license tag shall be affixed to a collar firmly attached and
maintained around the neck of such dog or cat at all times.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-22.   Rabies vaccination.
   (a)   The owner of a dog or cat age four (4) months or older shall have such
dog or cat vaccinated against rabies by a licensed veterinarian with an
approved rabies vaccine, on an annual basis or as otherwise required by
Illinois law.
   (b)   The standard vaccination tag issued by such licensed veterinarian
shall be affixed to a collar firmly attached and maintained around the neck of
such dog or cat at all times.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-23.   Dog restraint.
   The owner of a dog shall keep his/her dog under restraint at all times.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-24.   Dogs running at large.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to suffer or permit any dog to run
at large in the village.
   (b)   Dogs found running at large in the village shall be apprehended and
impounded. The animal control warden shall utilize any existing or available
animal control facility or licensed animal shelter. A dog found running at
large a second or subsequent time must be sterilized within thirty (30) days
after being reclaimed.
   (c)   When a dog is apprehended and impounded, it shall be scanned for the
presence of a microchip and examined for other currently acceptable methods of
identification, including, but not limited to, identification tags, tattoos,
and rabies license tags. The examination for identification shall be done
within twenty-four (24) hours after the intake of each dog. The animal control
warden shall make every reasonable attempt to contact the owner as soon as
possible. The animal control warden shall give notice of not less than seven
(7) business days to the owner prior to disposal of the animal. Such notice
shall be mailed to the last known address of the owner. Testimony of the animal
control warden, or his or her authorized agent, who mails such notice shall be
evidence of the receipt of such notice by the owner. A mailed notice shall
remain the primary means of owner contact; however, the animal control warden
shall also attempt to contact the owner by any other contact information, such
as by telephone or email address, provided by the microchip or other method of
identification found on the dog. If the dog has been microchipped and the
primary contact listed by the chip manufacturer cannot be located or refuses to
reclaim the dog, an attempt shall be made to contact any secondary contacts
listed by the chip manufacturer prior to adoption, transfer, or euthanization.
Prior to transferring the dog to another humane shelter, pet store, rescue
group, or euthanization, the dog shall be scanned again for the presence of a
microchip and examined for other means of identification. If a second scan
provides the same identifying information as the initial intake scan and the
owner has not been located or refuses to reclaim the dog, the animal control
facility may proceed with the adoption, transfer, or euthanization.
   (d)   In case the owner of any impounded dog desires to make redemption
thereof, he or she may do so by doing the following:
      (1)   Presenting proof of current rabies inoculation, microchipping,
registration and licensure, if applicable;
      (2)   Paying for the rabies inoculation, microchipping, registration, and
licensure, if applicable; and
      (3)   Paying the pound for the board of the dog for the period it was
impounded.
   (e)   When not redeemed by the owner a dog must be scanned for a microchip.
If a microchip is present, the registered owner or chip purchaser, if the
purchaser was a nonprofit organization, animal shelter, animal control
facility, pet store, breeder, or veterinary office, must be notified. After
contact has been made or attempted, dogs deemed adoptable by the animal control
facility shall be offered for adoption, or made available to a licensed animal
shelter or rescue group. The animal may be humanely dispatched pursuant to the
Humane Euthanasia in Animal Shelters Act. An animal control facility or animal
shelter shall not adopt or release any dog to anyone other than the owner or a
foster home unless the animal has been rendered incapable of reproduction and
microchipped. Nothing herein shall prevent humane societies or animal shelters
from engaging in activities set forth by their charters; provided, they are not
inconsistent with provisions hereof. No animal shelter or animal control
facility shall release dogs to an individual representing a rescue group,
unless the group has been licensed by the Department of Agriculture or is a
representative of a not-for-profit out-of-state organization, animal shelter,
or animal control facility.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-25.   Potentially dangerous dogs; dangerous dogs; and vicious dogs.
   (a)   Administration. The determination of whether any dog is a potentially
dangerous dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog may be made by a hearing officer
upon the filing of a complaint by any person through proceedings administered
pursuant to Chapter 12, Miscellaneous Provisions and Offenses, Article X,
Administrative Adjudication of Non-Vehicular Regulations Violations, of the
Evergreen Park Municipal Code, or by any other means permitted by law. The
owner or custodian of the dog shall be given written notice of the complaint
and hearing, may be represented by an attorney, and shall have the right to
present evidence and testimony, and to cross-examine witnesses. All final
decisions and determinations of the hearing officer shall be subject to
administrative review in the Circuit Court of Cook County.
   (b)   Potentially dangerous dog.
      (1)   A dog found running at large and unsupervised with three (3) or
more other dogs shall be deemed a potentially dangerous dog by the hearing
officer. The designation of "potentially dangerous dog" shall expire twelve
(12) months after the most recent violation of this subsection.
      (2)   In addition to any fine that may be imposed, a hearing officer
shall order a potentially dangerous dog to be spayed or neutered and
microchipped within fourteen (14) days of reclaim. The expense of complying
with an order of the hearing officer shall be the responsibility of the owner.
      (3)   The owner shall present evidence to the animal control warden that
the order of the hearing officer has been complied with no later than fifteen
(15) days after the determination. Any potentially dangerous dog being kept or
maintained in violation of any lawful order of the hearing officer shall be
subject to impoundment.
   (c)   Dangerous dog.
      (1)   Any individual dog shall be deemed a dangerous dog by the hearing
officer if it:
         a.   Is found anywhere other than upon the property of the owner or
custodian of the dog and unmuzzled, unleashed, or unattended by its owner that
behaves in a manner that a reasonable person would believe poses a serious and
unjustified imminent threat of serious physical injury or death to a person or
a companion animal; or
         b.   Without justification, bites a person and does not cause serious
physical injury.
      (2)   A dog shall not be declared dangerous if the conduct of the dog was
justified because:
         a.   The threat was sustained by a person who at the time was
committing a crime or offense upon the owner or custodian of the dog or was
committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises or property
occupied by the owner of the animal;
         b.   The threatened person was abusing, assaulting, or physically
threatening the dog or its offspring;
         c.   The injured, threatened, or killed companion animal was attacking
or threatening to attack the dog or its offspring;
         d.   The dog was responding to pain or injury or was protecting
itself, its owner, custodian, or a member of its household, kennel, or
offspring; or
         e.   It is a guide dog for the blind or hearing impaired, support dog
for persons with a physical disability, or a sentry, guard, or police-owned
dog; provided, an attack or injury to a person occurs while the dog is
performing duties as expected. The exception for sentry or guard dogs shall
only be available if said dog is on the Administrator's categorized list of
exempt dogs and performing duties at the location of station.
      (3)   In addition to any fine that may be imposed, a hearing officer
shall order:
         a.   The dangerous dog to be spayed or neutered and microchipped
within fourteen (14) days;
         b.   The dangerous dog be kept under restraint and under the direct
supervision of an adult eighteen (18) years of age or older whenever the animal
is on public property or the property of others; and
         c.   The dangerous dog be muzzled whenever it is on public property or
the property of others in a manner that will prevent it from biting any person
or animal.
      The expense of complying with an order of the hearing officer shall be
the responsibility of the owner.
      (4)   The owner shall present evidence to the animal control warden that
the order of the hearing officer has been complied with no later than fifteen
(15) days after the determination. Any dangerous dog being kept or maintained
in violation of any lawful order of the hearing officer shall be subject to
impoundment.
   (d)   Vicious dog.
      (1)   Any individual dog that, without justification, attacks a person
and causes serious physical injury or death or any individual dog that has been
found to be a "dangerous dog" upon three (3) separate occasions, shall be
deemed a vicious dog by the hearing officer.
      (2)   A dog shall not be declared vicious if the conduct of the dog was
justified because:
         a.   The threat, injury, or death was sustained by a person who at the
time was committing a crime or offense upon the owner or custodian of the dog,
or was committing a willful trespass or other tort upon the premises or
property owned or occupied by the owner of the animal;
         b.   The injured, threatened, or killed person was abusing,
assaulting, or physically threatening the dog or its offspring, or has in the
past abused, assaulted, or physically threatened the dog or its offspring;
         c.   The dog was responding to pain or injury, or was protecting
itself, its owner, custodian, or member of its household, kennel, or offspring;
         d.   A professional trained dog for law enforcement or guard duties;
or
         e.   It is a guide dogs for the blind or hearing impaired, support dog
for persons with a physical disability, or a sentry, guard, or police-owned
dog; provided, an attack or injury to a person occurs while the dog is
performing duties as expected. The exception for sentry or guard dogs shall
only be available if said dog is on the Administrator's categorized list of
exempt dogs and performing duties at the location of station.
      (3)   In addition to any fine that may be imposed, a hearing officer
shall order: (i) the dangerous dog to be spayed or neutered and microchipped
within ten (10) days; and (ii) the vicious dog be subject to enclosure. The
expense of complying with an order of the hearing officer shall be the
responsibility of the owner.
      (4)   The owner shall present evidence to the animal control warden that
the order of the hearing officer has been complied with no later than eleven
(11) days after the determination. A vicious dog shall not be released to the
owner until an enclosure approved by the animal control warden has been
constructed on the property where the dog is kept. Any vicious dog being kept
or maintained in violation of any lawful order of the hearing officer shall be
subject to impoundment.
   (e)   Violations.
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to keep or maintain any
potentially dangerous dog, dangerous dog, or vicious dog in the village that is
not spayed, neutered, and microchipped or that is otherwise being kept or
maintained in violation of any lawful order of the Administrator, Deputy
Administrator, animal control warden, or hearing officer.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person to allow a dangerous dog to be
on public property unless under restraint (leash), muzzled, and under the
direct supervision of an adult eighteen (18) years of age or older.
      (3)   It shall be unlawful for any person to allow a vicious dog out of
its approved enclosure except:
         a.   When necessary for the owner or keeper to obtain veterinary care
for the dog;
         b.   In the case of an emergency or natural disaster where the dog's
life is threatened; or
         c.   To comply with the order of a court of competent jurisdiction,
provided that the dog is securely muzzled and restrained with a leash not
exceeding six (6) feet in length, and shall be under the direct control and
supervision of the owner or keeper of the dog.
      (4)   It shall be unlawful for any owner of a vicious dog to sell or give
away said vicious dog.
   (f)   Notification. The animal control warden shall notify the Administrator
or Deputy Administrator of Cook County of any potentially dangerous dog,
dangerous dog, or vicious dog.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-26.   Bites; rabies; observation period.
   Whenever any dog or cat bites a person, the owner shall immediately notify
the animal control warden, and the animal control warden shall notify the
Administrator or Deputy Administrator for Cook County. The Animal Control Act
shall govern the terms of the dog or cat's confinement and observation.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-27.   Authority to euthanize/deprivation of life.
   (a)   Any dog or cat found in a public way or public place within the
village and which, in the opinion of any police officer or the animal control
officer, appears to be injured or diseased beyond a reasonable likelihood of
recovery, and which is not being attended or properly cared for by the owner,
or which has not been removed to private property or to some place designated
by such officer, within one hour after being found or left in such condition,
may be deprived of life by such officer, or as he or she may direct.
   (b)   Any police officer, and any other person designated by the animal
control warden, shall be authorized to take the life of any dog or cat when
deemed necessary to protect any person or other animal from physical harm or
death.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-28.   Miscellaneous violations.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dog or cat off his/
her premises without license and vaccination tags securely affixed to its
collar.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to permit any dog or cat to enter
or remain upon the premises of another within the village without the consent
of the person owning, occupying or lawfully in control of such premises.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person to cause or permit a dog under his
ownership or control to be on any property, public or private, not owned by
such person, unless such person shall have in his or her possession a device
for the removal of any excrement which might be deposited by such dog.
   (d)   It shall be unlawful for any person who owns or controls a dog which
deposits excrement upon any property, public or private, to fail to promptly
remove such excrement to a public receptacle or a proper receptacle located on
property owned or possessed by such person. This provision shall not apply to
blind or physically handicapped persons while walking with their guide dog.
   (e)   It shall be unlawful for a cat owner to permit any cat excrement to
remain on any property, public or private, not owned by the cat owner, upon
notification to the cat owner by the person owning, occupying, or lawfully in
control of such property that the owner's cat has defecated on such property.
Upon such notification, the cat owner shall immediately remove the excrement
from such property to a public receptacle or a proper receptacle on property
owned or possessed by such cat owner.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-29.   Penalty and administration.
   (a)   Any person violating Sec. 4-24(a) shall, upon conviction thereof, be
fined as follows:
 
                            Animal being less than 40 pounds at time of
                             incident
First Offense                $250.00
Second Offense               $500.00
Third and Subsequent Offense $750.00
 
 
                            Animal being 40 pounds or more at time of incident
First Offense                $500.00
Second Offense               $1,000.00
Third and Subsequent Offense $1,500.00
 
If the dog cannot be weighed at or near the time the citation is issued, the
person issuing the citation shall mark on the citation the following
information: (i) an estimate of the weight of the dog; (ii) breed of dog; (iii)
sex of dog; and (iv) whether the dog is mature. The estimation of weight shall
be deemed prima facie true and correct.
   (b)   Any person violating any other provision of this article shall, upon
conviction thereof, be fined not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00)
nor more than two thousand dollars ($2,000.00) for each offense, and a separate
offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation
occurs or continues.
   (c)   The provisions of this article may be administered through the
provisions of Chapter 12, Miscellaneous Provisions and Offenses, Article X,
Administrative Adjudication of Non-Vehicular Regulations Violations, of the
Evergreen Park Municipal Code, or by any other means permitted by law. Nothing
in this chapter shall be interpreted to limit the remedies or penalties
available to Village of Evergreen Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
ARTICLE III. DOG PARK
Sec. 4-30.   Applicability.
   The provisions of this article shall pertain to and govern the operation of
the "Happy Bark" Dog Park located at 91st Street and California Avenue in the
Village of Evergreen Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-31.   Registration and vaccination.
   (a)   No animals other than dogs shall be permitted in the Dog Park.
   (b)   No dog shall enter or remain in the Dog Park unless registered and
licensed with the village.
   (c)   No dog shall enter or remain in the Dog Park unless vaccinated against
rabies.
   (d)   No dog shall enter or remain in the Dog Park unless said dog has a
current license tag and vaccination tag affixed to a collar firmly attached and
maintained around the neck of such dog at all times.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-32.   Fobs.
   (a)   No person shall enter the Dog Park or allow an animal to enter the Dog
Park without a current working fob.
   (b)   Fobs are registered to an owner and are not transferable and may not
be used by any person other than to whom registered, except that the fob can be
used by a spouse or other person of not less than eighteen (18) years of age
residing in the same household as the registered owner of the fob.
   (c)   Any person who operates a commercial dog walking service or is paid to
walk a dog is not eligible to register for a fob, but may use the fob
registered to the owner for that dog only provided that the person notifies the
village in writing and is authorized by the village.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-33.   Maximum dogs.
   No person shall allow more than three (3) dogs to enter or remain in the Dog
Park at one time.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-34.   Supervision.
   Dogs must be kept under supervision at all times. If dogs behave
aggressively, they must be leashed and removed from the dog area. Failure to
maintain supervision will result in suspension of registration and right to
enter the Dog Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-35.   Rules and regulations.
   No person shall violate any rule or regulation of the Dog Park. The Village
Clerk is hereby authorized to issue rules and regulations governing the
operation of the Dog Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-36.   Cleanliness.
   No food, alcoholic beverages, dog toys, treats, chews, rawhide or similar
items are allowed. Dog feces must be removed and disposed of by the owner. No
littering is allowed.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-37.   Age of dogs.
   All dogs must be at least four (4) months old to enter the Dog Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-38.   Dangerous dogs and vicious dogs prohibited.
   No dangerous dogs or vicious dogs shall be permitted in the Dog Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-39.   Prohibited persons.
   (a)   No person who is under the age of eighteen (18) shall be allowed to
enter the Dog Park unless accompanied by an adult with a fob.
   (b)   No person shall be allowed to enter the Dog Park unless that person
has a fob or is a spouse, child, grandchild, or resides in the same household
as the registered owner of the fob.
   (c)   No more than three (3) persons may accompany the registered owner of a
fob to enter or remain in the Dog Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)
Sec. 4-40.   Penalty and administration.
   (a)   The penalties for violation of any provision of this article shall be
as provided for in Section
1-9 of the Municipal Code of Evergreen Park.
   (b)   The provisions of this article may be administered through the
provisions of Chapter 12, Miscellaneous Provisions and Offenses, Article X,
Administrative Adjudication of Non-Vehicular Regulations Violations, of the
Evergreen Park Municipal Code, or by any other means permitted by law. Nothing
in this chapter shall be interpreted to limit the remedies or penalties
available to Village of Evergreen Park.
(Ord. No. 7-2023 § 1, 6-19-23)

Village with the following changes, additions or insertions:

Illinois Plumbing Code.”

determines.”

Village with the following changes, additions or insertions:

effective in the Village upon the date of applicability in the City of Chicago.

The Life Safety Code, as published by the National Fire Protection Association
in effect on May 1, 1996, is hereby adopted as the Life Safety Code of the
village. Any amendments to the Life Safety Code after May 1, 1996 shall be
effective in the village 30 days after promulgated by the NFPA.
Sec. 5-8. Property Maintenance Code.
   The "2021 International Property Maintenance Code" as published by the
International Code Council, Inc. is hereby adopted as the Property Maintenance
Code of the Village with the following changes, additions or insertions:
      Section 101.1, insert "Village of Evergreen Park."
      Section 102.3, Application of other codes, change to read "Repairs,
additions or alterations to a structure, or changes of occupancy, shall be done
in accordance with the procedures and provisions of the Building Code, Plumbing
Code, Mechanical Code, and Electrical Code adopted by the Village. Nothing in
this Code shall be construed to cancel, modify or negate any provision of the
zoning ordinance."
      Section 102.4, Existing remedies, add "The Village shall have the right
to cause the demolition, repair or enclosure of unsafe buildings as provided
for in the Illinois Municipal Code without following any of the procedures and
notice requirements of this Code."
      Section 103, Code Compliance Agency, delete in full.
      Section 104.1, Fees, add "The Building Commissioner shall be the code
official. The code official may designate any employee of the Village with the
enforcement of this code."
      Section 107, Means of Appeal, delete in full.
      Section 108, Board of Appeals, delete in full.
      Section 109.2, Inspections, change to read "The code official may serve a
notice of violation, but no such notice is a prerequisite to the existence of a
violation or to action by the Village to restrain, correct or abate such
violation."
      Section 109.3, Right of entry, change to read "The code official may
institute court proceedings to restrain, correct or abate any violation, or to
require the removal or termination of the unlawful occupancy of any structure,
or the order or direction of the code official. Any action taken on such
premises shall be charged against the real estate upon which the structure is
located and shall be a lien upon such real estate.
      Section 109.4, Violation penalties, change to read "Any person who
violates any provision of this Code shall be subject to a fine of not less than
$100 nor more than $750 for each violation thereof. Each day that a violation
occurs shall constitute a separate offense and violation."
      Section 110.4, Failure to comply, change to read "Any person who shall
continue any work after having been served with a stop work order, except such
work as that person is directed to perform to remove a violation or unsafe
condition, shall be subject to a fine of not less than $100 nor more than $750
for each violation thereof. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a
separate offense and violation."
      Section 111.1.1, Unsafe conditions, add "No structure may be boarded up
for more than 6 months. An unsafe structure includes any structure boarded up
for more than 6 months."
      Section 111.4.1, Unlawful structure, change to read "Whenever the code
official has condemned a structure or equipment, notice shall be sent by first
class mail to the taxpayer of record or the party responsible for paying any
water bill. The notice shall include a statement of the violations and a
deadline by which to correct the violations."
      Section 113.1, General, change to read "The code official may order the
demolition of any structure which is:
         1.   Dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human
habitation or occupancy.
         2.   A public nuisance.
         3.   Vacant or abandoned for more than 6 months.
         4.   Boarded up for more than 6 months.
         5.   Under construction where there has been a cessation of normal
construction activity for a period of more than 6 months.
         6.   Maintain in violation of the provisions of this code for more
than 6 months."
      Section 113.2, Notices and orders, change to read "A notice of order of
demolition shall be served as provided for in the Illinois Municipal Code."
      Section 201.6, Local Codes, add Section to read "Whenever reference is
made to the International Building Code, International Fire Code, International
Zoning Code, International Plumbing Code, or International Mechanical Code,
such reference shall be to the Building Code, Fire Code, Zoning Ordinance,
Plumbing Code, Mechanical Code, currently in effect."
      Section 301.3, Vacant structures and land, add "No structure shall be
maintained which is:
         1.   Dangerous, unsafe, unsanitary or otherwise unfit for human
habitation or occupancy.
         2.   A public nuisance.
         3.   Vacant or abandoned for more than 6 months.
         4.   Boarded up for more than 6 months.
         5.   Under construction where there has been a cessation of normal
construction activity for a period of more than 6 months.
         6.   In violation of the provisions of this code for more than 6
months."
      Section 302.4, Weeds, insert "8 inches" at the end of the first sentence.
      Section 304.3, Premises identification, add "Street numbers must be
attached to the structure (or light pole or mailbox) and may not be painted
thereon. Street numbers may not be painted on any stairway, stoop, sidewalk,
curb, or other area."
      Section 304.14, Insect screens, insert "May 1" and "October 1."
      Section 404.5, Overcrowding, add "If any room used for residential
purposes is overcrowded, the code official may order the number of persons
sleeping or living in said room to be reduced in order to conform to the
minimum area requirements of this Chapter. It shall be prohibited to use for
sleeping purposes any kitchen, hallway, closet, basement, storage room, public
area, dining room or living room (except that a living room may be used for
sleeping purposes of a guest for not more than 2 consecutive nights)."
      Section 602.3, Heat supply, insert "October 1" and "May 1." Delete the
Exception.
      Section 602.4, Occupiable work spaces, insert "October 1" and "May 1."
      Appendix A, Boarding Standard, is mandatory and shall be in effect.
      Appendix B, Board of Appeals, is deleted and shall not be in effect.
(Ord. No. 27-2006 § 1, 7-17-06; Am. Ord. No. 18-2007 § 2, 2-19-07; Am. Ord. No.
4-2010 § 1, 2-15-10; Am. Ord. No. 19-2012 § 1, 8-7-12; Am. Ord. No. 12-2016 §
1, 4-18-16; Am. Ord. No. 16-2018 § 1, 7-16-18; Am. Ord. No. 7-2021 § 1, 7-19-
21)
Sec. 5-9. Administration.
All provisions in this chapter shall be under the administration and direction
of the building commissioner. The building commissioner may direct other
officials or employees of the village to inspect or enforce the provisions in
this chapter.
Sec. 5-10. Plan review.
In addition to any building permit fees, an applicant shall be required to pay
any fees charged for review of plans made by the BOCA Plan Review Service upon
request of the building commissioner.
Sec. 5-11. Architectural and landscaping plans.
For any development which includes structures containing more than 10,000
square feet, the Building Commissioner shall have the right to approve the
architectural appearance and landscaping plans for the development. The
Building Commissioner shall be guided by the following standards:
   (a)   Public Good: All plans shall be so designed that the public health,
welfare, and safety will be protected. Plans shall not have buildings located
to cause traffic problems on adjacent streets.
   (b)   Property Value: The proposed development shall be such that it does
not cause substantial injury to the value of other property in the immediate
area.
   (c)   Protection of Conditions: All plans shall provide for protection of
both aesthetics and function of the natural environment.
   (d)   Appearance: All plans shall present a visually modern appearance that
projects a viable business image consistent with the image of the Village as a
modem retail center.
   (e)   Greenery: All plans shall incorporate landscaping and greenery to the
maximum extent consistent with the goals of the Village to protect the
environment and to present a uniform image along any major street.
Sec. 5-12. Construction Site Security.
   It shall be the responsibility of the property owner and the general
contractor to provide site security for any construction site where a new
building is being constructed or a building is being demolished. Construction
site security must include the following:
   (a)   Fencing.  No less an area than the building foundation area shall be
completely secured by a 6-foot chain link construction fence or plywood barrier
which shall be locked at all times that no construction personnel or security
personnel are on site until the building is secured with doors that are locked
and windows that are closed. All construction fencing and barriers shall be
securely anchored not less than 24 inches into the ground. The location of
fencing must be approved by the Building Commissioner. Fencing may only be
installed on the public right-of-way or prevent use of the public right-of-way
with the approval of the Building Commissioner.
   (b)   Lighting. The building shall be equipped from the inside from dusk to
dawn with a motion detector lighting system which shall be located in an area
which is not easily accessible to non construction personnel working on the
site. Lighting may be powered by a 110 volt source or a battery.
(Ord. No. 31-2007 § 1, 8-6-07; Am. Ord. No. 15-2008 § 1, 4-21-08 )
Sec. 5-13. Storage Containers and Refuse Dumpsters Prohibited.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a storage
container or refuse dumpster on the public right-of-way except pursuant to a
permit issued by the Village. A permit application shall be submitted to the
Building Department and shall be accompanied by a twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
fee. A permit shall be issued only when the refuse dumpster or storage
container is less than ten (10) feet in height and being used in conjunction
with the reconstruction of the residence or moving to or from the residence and
shall be limited to a period of thirty (30) consecutive days in any one (1)
calendar year and there is not room on the adjoining private property to locate
the same. The Building Department is authorized to extend the maximum thirty
(30)-day period in writing for circumstances beyond the control of the property
owner which were not anticipated and foreseen when the permit was originally
issued.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a storage
container on any private property except pursuant to a permit issued by the
Village. A permit application shall be submitted to the Building Department and
shall be accompanied by a twenty-five dollars ($25.00) fee. A permit shall be
issued only when the storage container is less than ten (10) feet in height and
being used in conjunction with the reconstruction of the residence or moving to
or from the residence and shall be limited to a period of thirty (30)
consecutive days in any one calendar year. The Building Department is
authorized to extend the maximum thirty (30)-day period in writing for
circumstances beyond the control of the property owner which were not
anticipated and foreseen when the permit was originally issued.
   (c)    It shall be unlawful for any person to place or maintain a refuse
dumpster on any residentially zoned or used private property for more than
thirty (30) days in any twelve (12)-month period. The Building Department is
authorized to extend the thirty (30)-day maximum for circumstances beyond the
control of the property owner which were not anticipated and foreseen when the
permit was originally issued.
   (d)   For the purposes of this section the term “refuse dumpster” shall mean
any garbage container in excess of a four (4)-yard capacity. The term “storage
container” shall mean any truck trailer, PODS container, freight container,
shipping container or similar container.
(Ord. No. 17-2009 § 1, 7-20-09; Am. Ord. 17-2009 (revised) § 1, 1-3-11)
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 5-41. Required.
A license shall be required before any person shall, within the limits of the
village, engage in the business of construction or demolition of buildings or
other structures, maintenance of buildings and grounds, including but not
limited to:
Aluminum contractors.
Building moving contractors. Burglar/security alarms contractors. Carpentry
contractors.
Catchbasin cleaners.
Concrete contractors.
Drywall or lathing contractors. Electrical contractors.
Excavator/demolition contractors. Fence contractors.
Fertilizer dispenser contractors. Fire alarm installation contractors.
Fire suppression equipment maintenance contractors.
Fire suppression systems installation contractors.
General contractors.
Insulation contractors.
Landscape contractors.
Landscape maintenance contractors. Lawn sprinkler contractors.
Masonry contractors.
Mechanical contractors.
Paving contractors.
Pipefitter contractors.
Plumbing contractors.
Roofing contractors.
Sewer contractors.
Sign installation/maintenance contractors. Snow removal contractors.
Structural steel/iron contractors. Swimming pool contractors.
Tree service contractors.
Window replacement/installation contractors.
Sec. 5-42. Contractor License Application and Fee.
Application for license shall be made upon forms provided by the Building
Commissioner. The annual fee for a general contractor's license shall be
$225.00 and the annual fee for all other contractors shall be $150.00.
(Ord. 5-2008 § 1, 2-18-08)
Sec. 5-43. Approval.
The building commissioner shall issue the license upon receipt of an approved
application and certificate of insurance. All licenses shall be issued for a
period of one year to commence on January 1 and terminate on December 31 of
that year.
Sec. 5-44. Revocation.
If, at any time after the granting of a license under this article, the
building commissioner shall certify to the mayor that any licensee hereunder
has failed to comply with any building requirements under this Code, such
license may be revoked by the building commissioner or mayor. Any licensee
whose license has been revoked shall have the right to appeal to the board of
trustees. The licensee must file the appeal within 5 days of revocation. The
board of trustees, or a committee thereof, shall conduct a hearing on the
matter being appealed and issue its decision within thirty 30 days of the
appeal.
Secs. 5-44-5-70. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. TECHNICAL STANDARDS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 5-71. Hours of construction.
Construction, alteration, repair, removal, demolition and excavation of
structures is allowed only during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 7:00 p.m. on Monday
through Saturday, provided that an owner of a single-family residential
structure may personally make repairs and construct additions from 9:00 a.m. to
6:00 p.m. on Sunday's and holidays. Emergency work during prohibited hours may
be permitted by the building commissioner. Interior decorating and remodeling
work during prohibited hours may be permitted by the building commissioner.
Sec. 5-72. Day Care Centers, Automatic Sprinkler Systems.
   (a)   For the purposes of this section, the phrase "day care center" means
any building or structure, other than the home of the person cared for,
occupied by 3 or more persons of any age who receive custodial or day care for
less than 24 hours by individuals other than parents or guardians, relatives by
blood marriage, or adoption. The term does not include a structure used for any
of the programs not included within the definition of day care center as
provided in the second sentence of 225 ILCS 10/2.09. All day care centers
licensed or regulated by the State of Illinois are within the definition of
"day care center", regardless of the number of persons receiving custodial or
day care.
   (b)   All buildings or structures used to for a day care center shall have
an automatic sprinkler system installed throughout in compliance with NFPA 13R.
(Ord. No. 32-2007 § 1, 8-6-07)
Sec. 5-73. Reserved.
Sec. 5-74. Satellite earth stations.
   (a)   For the purposes of this section, the phrase "satellite earth station"
means an antenna of any size, shape or description designed for receiving
communication or other signals from satellites. Such antenna may have a low-
noise amplifier (LNA) and be connected with coaxial cable to a television or
other receiver. A satellite earth station is also commonly referred to as an
earth station, a ground station, or a satellite dish.
   (b)   No person shall erect a satellite earth station without a permit
therefor.
   (c)   An application for such permit shall be on such forms as required by
the building commissioner and shall be accompanied by a current survey showing
the dimensions of the lot, the location of all buildings or structures thereon,
and the proposed location of the satellite earth station. In addition, plans
and specifications describing the earth station and its structural and
engineering components (the manufacturer's specifications) shall be attached.
The exact location, height and other proposed construction of the satellite
earth station shall not be varied without written approval of the building
commissioner.
   (d)   No satellite earth station shall be erected:
      (1)   In any front yard.
      (2)   In any side yard forward of the rear wall of the main structure
located on the lot.
      (3)   Within fifteen (15) feet of the side lot lines.
      (4)   In any required side yard.
      (5)   Within fifteen (15) feet of the rear lot line.
   (e)   All satellite earth stations shall meet the following construction
requirements:
      (1)   The dish shall not exceed fourteen (14) feet in diameter.
      (2)   Galvanized metal supports or equivalent must be used.
      (3)   Installations must conform to the provisions of the village
electrical code adopted in section
5-5.
      (4)   A concrete base or caisson extending not less than forty-two (42)
inches below the surface must be used to anchor the dish to the ground.
      (5)   The maximum height of the highest part of the dish shall not exceed
eighteen (18) feet above the ground on which it is constructed.
      (6)   The dish and structure shall be designed to withstand a wind force
of seventy-five (75) miles per hour without the use of supporting guy wires.
      (7)   No linkage, physically or electronically, shall be permitted to a
receiver not located on the same lot.
      (8)   Wiring to the satellite earth station shall be placed at least four
(4) inches beneath the surface of the ground.
      (9)   Any driving motor shall be limited to one hundred twenty-five-volt
maximum design voltage and be encased in protective guards. Grounding to a
grounding roof must be provided.
      (10)   Any dish may be mounted upon a roof of a primary or accessory
structure on the lot but shall not be mounted on chimneys, towers, trees,
poles, or spires. A roof-mounted dish shall be mounted directly to the part of
the roof not visible from the street immediately in front of the structure or
from the side street in case of a corner lot. Roof-mounted dishes may only be
mounted on the rear portion of any roof and not on the front or side of any
roof. Any roof-mounted dish must be designed to withstand a wind force of
eighty-five (85) miles per hour.
   (f)   The provisions of this section may be varied in cases of hardship or
impracticability by the board of trustees by the passage of a motion at a
committee meeting or regular meeting to that effect.
(Ord. No. 25-1990, § 1(7-23), 1-7-91)
Sec. 5-75. Parking lots.
   (a)   For the purpose of this section, the terms "parking lot" and "parking
area" shall mean any lot or parcel of property constructed or used, in whole or
in part, for the off-street parking of motor vehicles.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to construct and maintain or
operate any parking lot without first submitting a plan or other drawing to the
building commissioner showing that compliance will be made with the
requirements, specifications and restrictions set forth in section 25-167 of
this Code. If such plans show that the requirements, specifications and
restrictions as set forth herein are met, the building commissioner will
thereupon issue a permit.
(Ord. No. 25-1990, § 1(7-24), 1-7-91)
Sec. 5-76. Storage of building materials.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to deposit or store upon the
street, parkway, sidewalk or alley abutting upon or adjacent to the lot or
tract, upon which any building or structure is being erected, constructed,
altered or repaired, or upon any street, parkway, sidewalk or alley within the
village, any building materials, tools, apparatus, or structures designed or
intended to be used in the erection, construction, alteration or repair of
buildings. All such building materials, tools, apparatus or structures, when
first delivered, shall be placed entirely within the boundary lines of such lot
or tract, and shall so remain until the completion of such building or
structure or until finally removed from such lot or tract.
   (b)   In instances where it is not practical to store building materials and
equipment as stated in subsection (a) of this section, permission will be
granted to store the material/ equipment on village property for the purpose of
erection, construction, alteration or repair of buildings. Storage shall be
limited to one-third of the street pavement or alley width and shall not remain
overnight.
   (c)   Under no circumstances shall the storage allowed in subsection (b) of
this section be allowed on 87th Street, 91st Street, 95th Street, 99th Street,
103rd Street, Western Avenue, California Avenue, Kedzie Avenue, and Central
Park Avenue from 95th Street to 103rd Street within the corporate limits of the
village.
(Ord. No. 25-1990, § 1(7-25), 1-7-91)
Sec. 5-77. Air Conditioning Equipment
New and replacement central air conditioning equipment, including the
compressor unit, must be installed to the rear (as determined in the Evergreen
Park Zoning Code) of the principal building on all residential lots. The
location of central air conditioning equipment shall be subject to the approval
of the building commissioner.
The installation of central air conditioning equipment shall be performed by a
licensed heating and air conditioning contractor and wired by a licensed and
registered electrical contractor. A permit for the installation shall be
obtained from the building department.
Sec. 5-78. Uniformity of appearance.
No 2 single-family dwellings of identical front elevation or facade shall be
constructed of located on adjacent lots, nor shall there be constructed or
located more than 25% of single-family dwellings of the same elevation or
facade in any block. A change of front elevation or facade shag be deemed to
exist when there is substantial difference in roofline, type and location of
windows, and kind and arrangement of materials.
Sec. 5-79. Residential construction requirements.
   (a)   Single-Family Detached Dwellings. All single-family detached
residential dwelling units shall have exterior walls constructed of solid face
brick masonry or face brick veneer for the first ground level floor thereof
extending at least eight feet or to the underside of the roof soffit, whichever
is higher. If a floor is partially in the ground, then the exterior walls above
ground level shall also be constructed of solid face brick masonry or face
brick veneer extending to the underside of the level constructed on top of that
floor.
   (b)   Existing Single-Family Frame Detached Dwellings. Frame additions
without any type of brick masonry may be constructed to existing single-family
detached residential dwelling units where the existing exterior walls are not
constructed of solid face brick masonry or face brick veneer.
   (c)   Single-Family Detached Garages and Storage Sheds. Detached garages and
storage sheds for single-family residential dwelling units may be of frame
construction.
   (d)   Multi-Family Dwelling Units. All multi-family residential structures
shall have exterior walls constructed of solid face brick masonry and floors
constructed of precast concrete or poured concrete with a minimum fire
resistance rating of two hours. A townhouse multi-family dwelling unit (where a
separate dwelling unit is not located on top of another) may be constructed to
conform to the requirements for single-family detached dwellings provided that
a fire wall is constructed between dwelling units through the roof with a
minimum fire resistance rating of two hours.
   (e)   Multi-Family Detached Garages and Storage Sheds. Detached garages and
storage sheds for multi-family residential dwelling units shall have exterior
walls constructed of solid face brick masonry or face brick veneer.
Sec. 5-80. Elevator Required.
   The installation and operation of an elevator shall be required in any non-
residential structure which has three or more floors, and in any residential
building which has three or more floors where there is more than one dwelling
unit on each floor. Such elevator must service any basement and all floors of
the building.
(Ord. No. 32-2018 § 1, 12-3-18)
Secs. 5-81. Temporary Roof Coverings.
   No person shall place a tarp on a roof or any temporary roof covering on any
structure, including main structures and accessory structures, without first
obtaining a permit therefor. All tarps and temporary roof coverings shall be
fire resistant effective against light fire exposure. All permits issued shall
expire 30 days after the date of issuance, unless extended by the Building
Commissioner. The fee for a temporary roof covering permit shall be $25 for
each 30 days or part thereof. Applicants are required to post a $100 cash bond
as a prerequisite to obtaining such permit, which bond shall be returned to the
applicant upon removal of the temporary roof covering within the time frame
allowed by the permit. If a temporary roof covering is not removed by the
expiration date of the permit for such temporary roof covering, the village may
cause the removal of such temporary roof covering and use the cash bond to pay
for said removal.
(Ord. No. 19-2019 § 1, 8-19-19)
Secs. 5-82 – 5-105. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. BUILDING PERMITS
Sec. 5-106. Building plans.
The building commissioner shall not issue any permit authorizing the erection,
construction, alteration, addition or repair of any building or structure
unless the plans submitted for his approval clearly show that such building or
structure, with all of its appurtenances, foundations and attachments, can be
erected entirely within the limits of the lot or tract of land upon which it is
proposed to erect such building or structure. Except as provided by the
building code and zoning chapter of this Code. No permit to construct or alter
any building or structure shall authorize the use of any part of any public
highway or other public ground for the construction or maintenance of such
building or structure except as provided by this Code; nor shall any permit be
issued for the construction or maintenance of any balcony extending over any
public highway or other public ground unless permits therefore have been
obtained from the village board; nor, in the case of single-family residential
subdivisions where no alleys are provided to service the lot, shall a permit be
issued unless the building or structure is so constructed on the lot to provide
room for a side drive or a front drive accessing a garage.
Sec. 5-107. Alteration of plans.
It shall be unlawful to alter or in any way modify plans which have been
approved by the building commissioner. If, during the progress of such work, it
is desired to deviate, in any manner affecting the construction or other
essentials of the building, from the terms of the application or drawing,
notice of such intention to alter or deviate shall be given to the building
commissioner, and his written assent shall first be obtained before the
alteration or deviation may be made; provided however, that alterations in
buildings which do not involve any change in their structural parts, or of
their stairways, elevators, fire escapes or other means of ingress or egress,
or in lighting or ventilation or in plumbing or electric wiring, and that are
not in violation of any of the provisions of this chapter or the provisions of
the zoning chapter of this Code, may be made without the permission of the
building commissioner.
Sec. 5-108. Building permit fees.
   (a)   The fee for a building permit for any construction, including but not
limited to buildings, driveways, garages, sheds, fences, and equipment, shall
be a percentage of the total cost of construction as follows:
   (i)   Single family residential   1.5%
   (ii)    All other structures      2.5%
The minimum building permit fee shall not be less than $100, subject to
reduction by the Building Commissioner. At the time of making an application
for a building permit, payment of the building fee shall be made based upon the
estimated cost of construction. If the total cost of construction is different
than the estimated cost of construction used on the building permit
application, the fee for the building permit shall be adjusted accordingly and
paid within 10 days thereof. Every applicant shall submit a sworn contractor's
statement showing the total cost of construction upon demand of the Building
Commissioner.
   (b)   In addition to the building permit fee in paragraph (a) above, an
additional fee is charged for electrical, plumbing, and HVAC construction work.
Such fee shall be established by the Building Commissioner who shall publish a
schedule of permit fees and plan review fees for electrical, plumbing, and HVAC
construction work. The minimum plumbing permit fee shall be $250.00 for a
structure under 10,000 square feet, and the minimum plumbing permit fee shall
be $500 for a structure of 10,000 square feet or greater. The minimum
electrical permit fee shall be $250 for a structure under 10,000 square feet,
and the minimum electrical permit fee shall be $500 for a structure of 10,000
square feet or greater. The plumbing plan review fee for a non-residential
structure shall be $100. The electrical plan review fee for a non-residential
structure shall be $100. The fire sprinkler and fire alarm plan review fee for
a non-residential structure shall be $100. The minimum building plan review fee
for a non-residential structure under 10,000 square feet shall be $250. The
minimum building plan review fee for a non-residential structure of 10,000
square feet or greater shall be $500. Prior to receiving a building permit; all
building, electrical, plumbing, HVAC, water, sewer, license, and other fees and
bond require by the village shall be paid.
   (c)   A building permit shall be valid for a period of one year. Upon the
expiration of one year, a building permit renewal fee equal to 25% of the
original fee shall be paid. This subsection shall not apply to large
construction projects which cannot be completed within one year.
   (d)   The building permit fee for repair, remodeling, renovation or
installation of equipment (including but not limited to HVAC, fire sprinkler
systems, alarm systems or other life safety equipment) to existing structures
of institutions established and used solely for religious or educational
purposes shall be $1.00. This reduced building permit fee shall not apply to
any new construction involving the expansion of an existing church or school
structure.
(Ord. No. 6-2005, 2-21-05; Am. Ord. No. 5-2008 § 2, 2-18-08; Am. Ord. No. 8-
2015 § 1, 5-4-15)
Sec. 5-109. Demolition permit fees.
   (a)   The permit fee for a demolition of a structure under 11,000 square
feet shall be $1,500.
   (b)   The permit fee for the demolition of a structure 10,000 square feet or
greater shall be $3,000.
   (c)   The permit fee for the demolition of a residential garage or shed
shall be $100, subject to reduction by the Building Commissioner.
(Ord. No. 5-2008 § 3, 2-18-08; Am. Ord. No. 8-2015 § 2, 5-4-15)
Sec. 5-110. Bond Required.
   (a)   Cash Bond. A cash bond for permits; cash meaning currency, money
order, business check or cashier's check shall be deposited with the Village
before a building permit, electrical permit, or plumbing permit is issued. A
cash bond shall be refunded to the person making the deposit within 30 days
after the certificate of occupancy is issued unless a portion of the cash bond
is retained to insure that the public sidewalk or public street is properly
repaired where there has been a street cut or augering. The cash bond shall not
be refunded if work remains to be completed to meet the requirements of this
chapter. If work is not completed, the Village shall send written notice to the
permittee that work remains to be completed, and that such work must be
completed within 30 days. If the work is not satisfactorily completed within 30
days after notice, the Village may cause the work to be completed, with payment
for said work (including a 25 percent Village administrative fee) to be
deducted from the cash bond and any remainder refunded. If a cash bond is not
sufficient to cover the payment, the full amount of the cash bond shall be
forfeited and the permittee shall be billed for the difference. Any cash bond
remaining after 4 years of deposit shall be forfeited to the Village to cover
administrative costs.
   (b)   Single-Family Residences - New Construction. The amount of the cash
bond shall be $500 except in the following cases:
      (1)   Where a street is to be augered for sewer; or
      (2)   Where a street is to be open cut,
in which cases the bond shall be $1,500. An additional plumbing cash bond of
$500 and an additional electrical bond of $500 shall be required.
   (c)   Multiple-Family Buildings - New Construction. The amount of cash bond
shall be $500 per dwelling unit but not less than $1,500. An additional
plumbing cash bond of $500 and an additional electrical cash bond of $500 shall
be required.
   (d)   Commercial Buildings - New Construction. The amount of cash bond shall
be $20,000 for all commercial buildings which includes the plumbing cash bond
and electrical cash bond except where the cost of construction exceeds
$1,000,000 then a separate $5,000 plumbing cash bond and a $5,000 electrical
cash bond shall be required.
   (e)   Existing Commercial Buildings. The amount of the cash bond shall be
$10,000 which includes the plumbing cash bond and electrical cash bond.
   (f)   Existing Residential Buildings.
      (1)   Residential building is to be owner occupied. The amount of the
cash bond shall be $500 where the amount of construction work being permitted
is $5,000 or more. For work less than $5,000, the amount of the cash bond shall
be $250. An additional plumbing cash bond of $500 and an additional electrical
cash bond of $500 shall be required.
      (2)   Vacant residential building is to be non-owner occupied. The amount
of the cash bond shall be $10,000 and must be paid by the property owner for
any residential building which is being rehabilitated where the building has
been vacant just prior to acquisition thereof and the building will be non-
owner occupied after rehabilitation. An additional plumbing cash bond of $500
and an additional electrical cash bond of $500 shall be required. This category
covers buildings which are being substantially rehabilitated for sale or for
rent. A structure is "non-owner occupied" if the person or entity which
purchased the property and is making or contracting for the improvements does
not occupy the same as their principal residence for at least 12 months after
the certificate of occupancy is issued. Such structure must be entitled to a
homeowner's exemption from the Cook County Assessor for that entire 12-month
period in order to be owner-occupied.
   (g)    Building Demolitions. The amount of the cash bond shall be $1,000 for
single family residential buildings, $500 for residential garages and $5,000
for all other buildings.
   (h)    Refund. Any fees owed to the Village, including building permit fees,
inspection fees, professional fees and unpaid fines for violations incurred
during construction shall be deducted from the cash bond on deposit with the
Village before any refund is made.
   (i)    Payment. All cash bonds shall be paid by the property owner, except
that a cash bond required for electrical or plumbing work shall be paid by the
applicable contractor.
(Ord. No. 6-2005 § 2, 2-21-05; Am. Ord. No. 5-2008 § 4, 2-18-08; Am. Ord. 9-
2013 § 1, 6-3-13; Am. Ord. No. 8-2014 § 2, 4-7-14)
Sec. 5-111. Temporary Occupancy Permit.
In cases where weather or other circumstances prohibit the completion of work
to be performed on the public right-of-way, outside of the structure, or within
the structure; the Building Commissioner may issue a temporary occupancy permit
subject to the above work being completed by a certain date. A cash bond in the
amount of 125 percent of the cost of the work and improvements as determined by
the Village shall be posted prior to the issuance of the temporary occupancy
permit.
Sec. 5-112. Building Inspection Fees.
A residential inspection fee of $50.00 shall be paid for each separate
inspection (including building, plumbing, electrical, and HVAC) required by the
Village at the construction site. A commercial/industrial inspection fee of
$60.00 shall be paid for each separate inspection (including building,
plumbing, electrical, and HVAC) required by the Village at the construction
site. Inspection fees are in addition to permit fees.
(Ord. No. 5-2008 § 5, 2-18-08; Am. Ord. No. 8-2014 § 3, 4-7-14)
Sec. 5-113. Time Limitations for Building Permits.
A building permit shall be valid for a period of one year, except for large
construction projects where the building permit has initially been granted for
more than one year. If a building permit expires before being renewed within
its original period, as provided for in Section 5-108, the building permit
shall be null and void. In such event, a new building permit application shall
be submitted which will require the payment of a new building permit fee.
(Ord. No. 21-2016 § 1, 7-18-16)
Sec. 5-114. Elevator Inspection Fees.
An elevator inspection fee shall be paid for each separate elevator inspection.
The fee shall be equal to the amount charged to the Village by the elevator
inspection company plus an administrative charge of $25.00.
(Ord. No. 5-2008 § 6, 2-18-08)
Sec. 5-115. Penalty for Failure to Obtain Permit.
In the event that work is started on a project before a building permit is
used, or in the event that occupancy of a structure is made before an occupancy
permit is issued, a penalty of one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be
charged and shall be paid prior to the issuance of the building permit of the
occupancy permit.
(Ord. No. 6-2011 § 1, 5-16-11)
Secs. 5-116 – 5-135. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. ELECTRICITY
Sec. 5-136. Waiver of specific provisions of code.
The electrical inspector may waive specific provisions of this electrical code
relating to the installation, alteration, construction, sale and use of
electrical equipment only when such waiver appears to him to be justified and
when such waiver will not materially impair or affect the safety of the
electrical work being performed or installed.
Sec. 5-137. Permits.
   (a)   No electrical equipment shall be installed or altered within the
village unless a permit for such installation or alteration is first issued by
the electrical inspector.
   (b)   No permit for installation, alteration, and use of electrical
equipment shall be issued except pursuant to an application therefor made out
on a printed form, to be furnished by the electrical inspector or his duly
authorized deputy, and upon the payment of a fee.
   (c)   The application for each permit shall contain the name of the owner or
user of electrical equipment to be installed, altered or used; the location of
the premises where such installation or alteration is to be made by street and
number; and a detailed description of the work to be done.
Sec. 5-138. Reserved.
Sec. 5-139. Certificate of approval.
   (a)   The electrical inspector shall issue a certificate of approval after
each inspection in which the wiring or apparatus is found to be in compliance
with the terms of this chapter and with the rules adopted. A copy of such
certificate shall be sent to the building commissioner.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful to use or turn on power into or induce any
electrical current to flow through any wires or equipment hereafter installed
for which such certificate has not been issued.
Sec. 5-140. Periodic reinspections; correcting or disconnecting dangerous
conditions.
The electrical inspector may periodically make a thorough reinspection of the
installation in the buildings of all electric wiring, electric devices and
electric material now installed within the village, and when the installation
of any such wiring, devices or material is found to be in a dangerous or unsafe
condition, the person owning, using or operating the same shall be notified and
shall make the necessary repairs or changes required to place such wiring,
devices and material in a safe condition and have such work completed within 15
days, or any longer period specified by the electrical inspector in such
notice. The electrical inspector is hereby empowered to disconnect or order the
discontinuance of electrical service to such wiring devices or material so
found to be defective, until the installation of such wiring, devices and
