12-212(A)(4) on or before the first hearing date shall result in an increase of
the fine to $250. The fine shall be increased to $350 if it has not been paid
by the date scheduled to file a memorandum of judgment. In no event shall the
date to file a memorandum of judgment be sooner than 7 days after the first
hearing date.
(Ord. No. 6-2007 § 1, 2-5-07; Am. Ord. No. 21-2007 § 2, 3-19-07)
ARTICLE XI. SYNTHETIC DRUGS
Sec. 12-400. Definitions.
   For purposes of this section, the following definitions shall apply unless
the context clearly indicates or requires different meaning:
   (a)   A product containing a synthetic cannabinoid, synthetic stimulant, or
synthetic hallucinogen or product(s) means any product containing a synthetic
cannabinoid, synthetic stimulant, and synthetic hallucinogen as those terms
defined herein such as, but not limited to, the following examples of brand
names or identifiers: Spice, Chronic Spice, Spice Gold, Spice Silver, K2, K2
Sky, K2 Solid Sex, K2 Orisha, K2 Amazonian Shelter, K2 Thai Dream, K3, K3
Legal, Stinger, Red X Dawn, Spike 99, Spicylicious, Zohai, Serenity, Genie,
Yucatan Fire, Earthquake, Mystery, Black Mamba, Mr. Nice Guy, Skunk, Pulse,
Ivory Wave, Pure Ivory, Purple Wave, Vanilla Sky, Bliss, Meow Meow, Zoom,
Sextacy, Molly's Plant Food, Purple Monkey Plant Food, Buzz Grow, 4MMC, m-Cat
and Energy 1.
   (b)   Synthetic cannabinoid means any laboratory-created compound that
functions similar to the active ingredient in marijuana, tetrahydrocannabinol
(THC), including, but not limited to, any quantity of a natural or synthetic
material, compound, mixture, preparation, substance and their analog (including
isomers, esters, ethers, salts, and salts of isomers) containing a cannabinoid
receptor agonist, such as:
      (1)   JWH-007 (1-pentyl-2-methyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole);
      (2)   JWH-015 ((2-Methyl-1-propyl-1H-indol-3-yl)-1-
naphthalenylmethanone);
      (3)   JWH-018 (1-pentyl-3-(1-naphthoyl)indole);
      (4)   JWH-019 (1-hexyl-3-(naphthalen-1-oyl)indole);
      (5)   JWH-073 (naphthalen-1-yl-(1-butylindol-3-yl)methanone);
      (6)   JWH-081 (4-methoxynaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentylindol-3-yl)methanone);
      (7)   JWH-098 (4-methoxynaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentyl-2-methylindol-3-
yl)methanone);
      (8)   JWH-122 (1-Pentyl-3-(4-methyl-1-naphthoyl)indole);
      (9)   JWH-164 (7-methoxynaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentylindol-3-yl)methanone;
      (10)   JWH-200 (1-(2-morpholin-4-ylethyl)indol-3-yl)-naphthalen-1-
ylmethanone);
      (11)   JWH-203 (2-(2-chlorophenyl)-1-(1-pentylindol-3-yl)ethanone;
      (12)   JWH-210 (4-ethylnaphthalen-1-yl-(1-pentylindol-3-yl)methanone;
      (13)   JWH-250 (1-pentyl-3-(2-methoxyphenylacetyl)indole);
      (14)   JWH-251 (1-pentyl-3-(2-methylphenylacetyl)indole);
      (15)   JWH-398 (1-pentyl-3-(4-chloro-1-naphthoyl)indole);
      (16)   HU-210 ((6aR,10aR)-9-(Hydroxymethyl)-6,6-dimethyl-3-(2-
methyloctan-2-yl)-6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydrobenzo [c]chromen-1-ol);
      (17)   HU-211 ((6aS,10aS)-9-(Hydroxymethyl)-6,6-dimethyl-3-(2-
methyloctan-2-yl)-6a,7,10,10a-tetrahydrobenzo [c]chromen-1-ol);
      (18)   HU-308 ([(1R,2R,5R)-2-[2,6-dimethoxy-4-(2-methyloctan-2-
yl)phenyl]-7,7-dimethyl-4-bicyclo[3.1.1]hept-3-enyl] methanol);
      (19)   HU-331 ((3-hydroxy-2-[(1R,6R)-3-methyl-6-(1-methylethenyl)-2-
cyclohexen-1-yl]-5-pentyl-2,5-cyclohexadiene-1,4-dione);
      (20)   CP 55,940 (2-[(1R,2R,5R)-5-hydroxy-2-(3-hydroxypropyl)
cyclohexyl]- 5-(2-methyloctan-2-yl)phenol);
      (21)   CP 47,497 (2-[(1R,3S)-3-hydroxycyclohexyl]- 5- (2-methyloctan-2-
yl)phenol) and its homologues;
      (22)   WIN 55,212-2 ((R)-(+)-[2,3-Dihydro-5-methyl-3-(4-
morpholinylmethyl)pyrrolo [1,2,3-de)-1,4-benzoxazin-6-yl]-1-
nepthalenylmethanone);
      (23)   RCS-4 ((4-methoxyphenyl)(1-pentyl-1H-indol-3-yl)methanone);
      (24)   RCS-8 (1-(1-(2-cyclohexylethyl)-1H-indol-3-yl)-2-(2-
methoxyphenyl)ethanone).
   (c)   Synthetic stimulant means any compound that mimics the effects of any
federally controlled Schedule I substance such as cathinone, methcathinone,
MDMA and MDEA, including, but not limited to, any quantity of a natural or
synthetic material, compound, mixture, preparation, substance and their analog
(including salts, isomers, and salts of isomers) containing substances which
have a stimulant effect on the central nervous system, such as:
      (1)   3-Fluoromethcathinone;
      (2)   4-Fluoromethcathinone;
      (3)   3,4-Methylenedioxymethcathinone (other name: methylone, MDMC);
      (4)   3,4-Methylenedioxypyrovalerone (other name: MDPV);
      (5)   4-Methylmethcathinon (other names: mephedrone, 4-MMC);
      (6)   4-Methoxymethcathinone (other names: methedrone, bk-PMMA, PMMC);
      (7)   4-Ethylmethcathinone (other name: 4-EMC);
      (8)   Ethcatinone;
      (9)   Beta-keto-N-methylbenzodioxyolylpropylamine (other names: butylone,
bk-MBDB);
      (10)   Napthylpyrovalerone (other names: naphyrone, NRG-1);
      (11)   N.N-dimethylcathinone (other name: metamfepramone);
      (12)   Alpha-pyrrolidinopropiophenone (other name: alpha-PPP);
      (13)   4-methoxy-alpha-pyrrolidinopropiophenone (other name: MOPPP);
      (14)   3,4-mthylenedioxy-alpha-pyrrolidinopropiophenone (other name:
MDPPP);
      (15)   6,7-kihydro-5H-indeno(5,6-d)-1,3-dioxal-6amine) (other name:
MDAI);
      (16)   Any compound that is structurally derived from 2-amino-1-phenyl-1-
propanone by modification or substitution in any of the following ways:
         a.   In the phenyl ring to any extent with alkyl, alkoxy,
alkylenedioxy, haloalkyl, or halide substituents, whether or not further
substituted in the phenyl ring by one or more other univalent substituents;
         b.   At the 3-position with an alkyl substituent;
         c.   At the nitrogen atom with alkyl, dialkyl, benzyl, or
methoxybenzyl groups; or
         d.   By inclusion of the nitrogen atom in a cyclic structure.
   (d)   Synthetic hallucinogen means any compound that mimics the effects of
any federally controlled Schedule I substance, including but not limited to,
any quantity of a natural or synthetic material, compound, mixture,
preparation, substance and their analog (including salts, isomers, esters,
ethers and salts of isomers) containing substances which have a psychedelic/
hallucinogenic effect on the central nervous system and/or brain such as:
      (1)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxy-4-ethylphenyl)ethanamine(2C-E);
      (2)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxy-4-methylphenyl)ethanamine (2C-D);
      (3)   2-(4-Chloro-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-C);
      (4)   2-(4-Iodo-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-I);
      (5)   2-(4-Ethylthio)-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-I-2);
      (6)   2-(4(Isopropylthio)-2,5-dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-T-4);
      (7)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxyphenyl)ethanamine (2C-H);
      (8)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxy-4-nitro-phenyl)ethanamine (2C-N);
      (9)   2-(2,5-Dimethoxy-4-(n)-propylphenyl)ethanamine (2C-P).
(Ord. No. 1-2012 § 2, 1-3-12)
Sec. 12-401. Sale or delivery.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to sell, offer for sale or deliver any
product containing a synthetic cannabinoid, synthetic stimulant or synthetic
hallucinogen.
(Ord. No. 1-2012 § 2, 1-3-12)
Sec. 12-402. Possession.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to knowingly possess a product
containing a synthetic cannabinoid, synthetic stimulant or synthetic
hallucinogen with the intent of using the product for ingestion, consumption,
inhaling, or intravenous use. In determining intent under this subsection, a
trier of fact may take into consideration, among other things: the proximity of
the product to drug paraphernalia; the presence of the product on or within
drug paraphernalia; the proximity of the product to a different controlled
substance; and whether or not the individual in possession of the product is
exhibiting physical effects commonly associated with being under the influence
of a controlled substance.
(Ord. No. 1-2012 § 2, 1-3-12)
Sec. 12-403. Use.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to be under the influence of a synthetic
cannabinoid, synthetic stimulant or synthetic hallucinogen.
(Ord. No. 1-2012 § 2, 1-3-12)
Sec. 12-404. Conflict.
   It is recognized that State of Illinois may criminalize the sale, possession
or use of some or all synthetic cannabinoids, synthetic stimulants or synthetic
hallucinogens governed by this Article. To the extent the General Assembly
passes any criminal laws banning or prohibiting the sale, possession or use of
a specific substance governed by this Article, the violator shall be charged
under the State statute and that part of this Article shall superseded but only
to the extent the State statute governs the same conduct for the same
substance.
(Ord. No. 1-2012 § 2, 1-3-12)
Chapter 13
MOTOR VEHICLES AND TRAFFIC

ARTICLE 1. IN GENERAL
Sec. 13-1. Statutes adopted by reference.
   (a)   In lieu of using any section of or in addition to the regulations of
this chapter, the officer issuing the citation may issue a citation under any
of the sections of the Illinois Vehicle Code [625 ILCS 5/1-100 et seq.], from
time to time, which sections of the Illinois Vehicle Code, and all amendments
made from time to time, are hereby incorporated by reference as a part of this
chapter, and every numbered section in the Illinois Vehicle Code, shall be
referred to by the letters "EP" prefixing such section number. All citations so
issued shall be issued in the name of the village and referred to in the
uniform traffic ticket or complaint as an ordinance violation. The Illinois
Vehicle Code penalties for traffic violations shall apply to such ordinance
violations, unless modified or changed by this chapter.
   (b)   Any section in the Illinois Vehicle Code can be used in issuing
ordinance citations merely by using the IVC section and prefacing with the
letters "EP." For example, a school bus which does not have a signal device can
be cited as a violation of sec. EP 12-805, etc.
   (c)   Any section of the Illinois Vehicle Code for which a violation is
deemed a Class A misdemeanor shall be treated as a petty offense where such
offense has been designated as an ordinance violation under this chapter, and
any reference in the Illinois Vehicle Code to a “Class A Misdemeanor” shall be
deemed replaced by the words “petty offense” when written as an ordinance
violation under this chapter. Such violations shall be punishable by fine only
in an amount not to exceed $500.
(Am. Ord. No. 6-2018, § 1, 2-5-18)
Sec. 13-2. Traffic laws apply to persons riding animals or driving animal-drawn
vehicles.
Every person riding an animal or driving any animal-drawn vehicle upon a
roadway shall be granted all of the rights and shall be subject to all of the
duties applicable to the driver of a vehicle by this chapter, except those
provisions of this chapter which by their very nature can have no application.
Sec. 13-3. Application of chapter to public officers, employees.
   (a)   The provisions of this chapter applicable to the drivers of vehicles
upon the highways shall apply to the drivers of all vehicles owned or operated
by the United States, this state or any county, city, town, district or any
other political subdivision of the state, except as provided in this section
and subject to such specific exceptions as set forth in this chapter with
reference to authorized emergency vehicles.
   (b)   Unless specifically made applicable, the provisions of this chapter
shall not apply to persons, motor vehicles and equipment while actually engaged
in work upon a highway but shall apply to such persons and vehicles when
traveling to or from such work.
Sec. 13-4. Application of chapter to authorized emergency vehicles.
   (a)   The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle, when responding to an
emergency call or when in the pursuit of an actual or suspected violator of the
law or when responding to but not upon returning from a fire alarm, may
exercise the privileges set forth in this section, but subject to the
conditions herein stated.
   (b)   The driver of an authorized emergency vehicle may:
      (1)   Park or stand, irrespective of the provisions of this chapter.
      (2)   Proceed past a red or stop signal or stop sign, but only after
slowing down as may be required and necessary for safe operation.
      (3)   Exceed the maximum speed limits so long as he does not endanger
life or property.
      (4)   Disregard regulations governing direction of movement or turning in
specified directions.
   (c)   The exceptions herein granted to an authorized emergency vehicle,
other than a police vehicle, shall apply only when the vehicle is making use of
either an audible signal when in motion or visual signals meeting the
requirements of law.
   (d)   All-terrain vehicles owned and operated by village and used by its
police and fire departments shall be deemed authorized emergency vehicles, and
may be operated on any street within the corporate limits of the village,
without a registration.
   (e)   The foregoing provisions do not relieve the driver of an authorized
emergency vehicle from the duty of driving with due regard for the safety of
all persons, nor do such provisions protect the driver from the consequences of
his reckless disregard for the safety of others.
(Code 1965, § 20-2(b)—(d)) (Am. Ord. No. 6-2015 § 1, 5-4-15)
   State law reference—Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-205(b)—(e).
Sec. 13-5. Vehicle to be licensed.
It shall be unlawful for any motor vehicle to be driven in, upon, or use any
street, parkway, sidewalk, public way, public alley, public property,
semipublic property, park or school grounds without having a license issued to
such vehicle by the state.
(Code 1965, § 20-101)
Sec. 13-6. Unlicensed motor vehicle a nuisance.
It shall be unlawful for any person to have in his possession a motor vehicle
for use which cannot be licensed by the secretary of state. The possession of
such vehicle by any person is hereby declared to be a nuisance.
(Code 1965, § 20-106)
   Cross reference—Nuisances generally, ch.
14.
   State law reference—Vehicle licensing and registration, 625 ILCS 5/3-101 et
seq.
Sec. 13-7. Evergreen Plaza Shopping Center traffic regulations.
   (a)   Pursuant to ordinance approving the agreement between the village and
Evergreen Park Associates, a state limited partnership, for the regulation of
traffic within the Evergreen Plaza Shopping Center, recorded September 4, 1974,
as Docket Number 22839377, the village agrees to establish and enforce the
provisions of this section regarding motor vehicle movement, parking and
control within the shopping center.
   (b)   The village hereby agrees to establish and enforce the following
regulations regarding motor vehicle movement, parking and control within the
parking lot of the owners:
      (1)   Permanent stop signs shall be posted at all exits into a public
highway from the parking lot and the driver of a motor vehicle emerging from
the shopping center into a public highway shall first come to a complete stop
at such sign prior to proceeding into the public highway.
      (2)   All motor vehicle movement shall be within the designated traffic
lanes and where marked by arrow or posted "One Way" no motor vehicle movement
shall be in the opposite direction.
      (3)   No motor vehicle shall be stopped or parked on the roadway or
driveway which lies directly in front of the stores or buildings.
      (4)   The stopping, standing or parking of any motor vehicle within the
parking lot during the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 9:00 a.m. shall be prohibited,
except that any motor vehicle having affixed thereto on the windshield a decal
or sticker constituting a parking permit issued by the owners shall not be
subject to this restriction.
      (5)   The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle within the
shopping center by a person having no business to conduct with the business
establishments within the shopping center shall be prohibited.
      (6)   The stopping, standing or parking of motor vehicles by the
operators thereof for the purpose of congregating or meeting shall be
prohibited.
      (7)   No motor vehicle shall be so operated as to cause or produce
unnecessary loud, raucous, excessive or unusual noises by the playing of a
muffler cutout, by tire friction upon rapid turning or weaving or by spinning
of wheels from a standing or slow-moving position produced by sudden
unnecessary acceleration or by continuous unnecessary sound of a horn or other
noise or signal device.
      (8)   The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle within a
designated fire lane, traffic lane or safety lane shall be prohibited and no
motor vehicle shall be left standing, stopped or parked within twenty (20) feet
in any direction from a fire hydrant, wall hydrant, water standpipes or fire
exit door.
      (9)   The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle where so
marked with parking stripes shall be within the same and confined to such area.
      (10)   The stopping, standing or parking of a motor vehicle within five
hundred (500) feet of any fire or police vehicle that has responded to a call
or an alarm shall be prohibited.
      (11)   The operating of an unlicensed go-cart or other miniature vehicle
shall be prohibited.
      (12)   The maximum speed limit for any motor vehicle shall not exceed
fifteen (15) miles per hour.
      (13)   Any motor vehicle parked or abandoned during a snowstorm, flood,
fire or other public emergency, or found unattended in the parking area where
it constitutes an obstruction to traffic or where stopping, standing or parking
is prohibited shall be removed and stored by the village, and payment of
reasonable charges for such removal and storage shall be paid to the village by
the owner or operator of such vehicle.
   (c)   The Evergreen Plaza Shopping Center shall have the right to allow
parking of a vehicle bearing a special decal affixed to the windshield
identifying such vehicle as "Official Plaza Business" or "Plaza Employee,"
allowing parking in certain areas designated by the plaza.
   (d)   The Evergreen Plaza Shopping Center does hereby agree to erect and
post all necessary signs for the regulation of motor vehicle parking and
traffic as is necessary to carry out such regulations and does hereby agree to
bear the costs and expense of same and maintenance thereof.
(Code 1965, § 20-90)
Sec. 13-8. Violations.
It shall be unlawful for any person to violate any of the provisions provided
for in this chapter.
Secs. 13-9-13-35. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. ADMINISTRATION AND ENFORCEMENT
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 13-36. Police to direct traffic.
Members of the police department are hereby authorized to direct all traffic in
accordance with the provisions of this chapter, or in emergencies as public
safety or convenience may require. Except in case of an emergency, it shall be
unlawful for any person not authorized by the chief of police to direct or
attempt to direct traffic.
Secs. 13-37-13-55. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. TRAFFIC CONTROL SIGNS, SIGNALS, DEVICES AND MARKINGS*
Sec. 13-56. Existing devices ratified.
The location of all traffic control signs, signals, devices and markings as of
the adoption date of this Code is ratified and confirmed.
Sec. 13-57. Erection of signs; traffic engineer designated.
   (a)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall determine and
designate the character and location of all official signs which proport to
direct the manner of traffic. He shall post adequate signs where such signs may
be necessary for the effective enforcement of this chapter. All signs shall
conform to the state sign manual.
   (b)   The Director of the Department of Public Works shall act as the
traffic engineer to determine the installation and proper timing and
maintenance of traffic control devices, to conduct engineering analyses of
traffic accidents and to devise remedial measures, to conduct engineering
investigation of traffic conditions, to plan the operation of traffic on the
streets and highways of this village, to erect signs in conformance therewith,
and to cooperate with other village officials in the development of ways and
means to improve traffic conditions, and to carry out the additional powers and
duties imposed by this chapter and ordinances of this village.
Sec. 13-58. One-way streets.
The board of trustees may, from time to time, designate streets or parts of
streets on which traffic shall be permitted to move in one (1) direction only.
Whenever any such street is so designated or whenever the Director of the
Department of Public Works deems advisable that a street shall be one way, he
shall cause to be erected and maintained suitable signs, signals or markings
giving notice thereof.
Secs. 13-59-13-75. Reserved.
DIVISION 3. VIOLATIONS AND PENALTIES
Sec. 13-76. Penalties.
Unless another penalty is expressly provided for in this division, the
violation of any provision of this chapter shall be punished by a fine of not
less than $50.00 nor more than $500.00 for each violation. Each day that a
violation occurs or continues shall constitute a separate violation. In the
alternative, the village may ask specifically for a penalty, including
imprisonment for a period not exceeding 6 months.
Secs. 13-77.—13-90. Reserved.
DIVISION 4. TRAFFIC SAFETY COMMISSION
Sec. 13-91. Established.
The traffic safety commission of the village is hereby established.
Sec. 13-92. Composition; appointment.
The traffic safety commission shall consist of 4 members who shall be appointed
by the mayor by and with consent of the board of trustees; the mayor and the
chief of police of the village shall be ex officio members of the
commission.   
Sec. 13-93. Qualifications.
The members of the traffic safety commission shall possess the qualifications
of the other officers of the village and shall be subject to removal from
office as shall other officers.
Sec. 13-94.   Terms of office of members.
The term of office of each member of the traffic safety commission shall be one
(1) year commencing on May first and expiring on April thirtieth of the
following year. All vacancies occurring in the commission shall be filled by
appointment for the remainder of the unexpired term.
Sec. 13-95.   Compensation of members.
Each member of the traffic safety commission shall receive such compensation as
the mayor and board of trustees shall fix by ordinance or resolution for each
meeting he attends, but such compensation shall not be paid for more than 12
meetings in any given fiscal year.
Sec. 13-96.   Secretary.
The traffic safety commission may employ a secretary or may designate one (1)
of its members to act as such. The secretary shall keep the minutes of its
proceedings and shall be custodian of all of its papers.
Sec. 13-97.   Election of officers.
The members of the traffic safety commission shall elect a chairman and
secretary.
Sec. 13-98. Powers.
The traffic safety commission shall act as an advisory board to the mayor and
board of trustees and shall make whatever recommendations it deems advisable to
promote the traffic safety and general welfare of the inhabitants of the
village. It shall make such investigations and recommendations concerning any
traffic matter referred to it by the mayor and board of trustees. It shall
assist and aid any other official or agency of the village in any matter
relating to its jurisdiction with reference to traffic safety as may from time
to time be presented to it.
Secs. 13-99—13-155. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. RESERVED
ARTICLE IV. GENERAL RULES OF VEHICLE OPERATION
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 13-156. Careless driving.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate any vehicle upon a public way
or street negligently, heedlessly and without due caution or in a manner as to
endanger or likely to endanger any person or property.
Sec. 13-157. Obstruction of traffic.
   No vehicle shall be operated or allowed to remain upon any street in such a
manner as to form an unreasonable obstruction to the traffic thereon
Sec. 13-158. Driving off thoroughfare.
   No person shall ride or drive any vehicle for pleasure or business, on or
across any median strip or lawn where there is no regular approach to the same.
It shall be the duty of the owner or occupant of any premises or lot to
construct good and sufficient approaches to the sidewalk where the same is
necessarily crossed in gaining access to such premises or lot by any private
entrance
Sec. 13-159. U-turns prohibited on certain streets.
   It shall be unlawful for the operator of any vehicle to turn such vehicle on
non-one-way streets between Western Avenue and Maplewood Avenue so as to
proceed in the opposite direction.
Sec. 13-160. Gross weight limitation on village streets.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stand, park, drive or move a
vehicle if the maximum gross weight of the vehicle including load exceeds ten
thousand (10,000) pounds, upon any street in the village, except the following
arterial streets: 103rd Street; 95th Street; 87th Street; Western Avenue;
Kedzie Avenue and Pulaski Road.
   (b)   Vehicles in excess of the weight limitations set forth in subsection
(a) making pickups or deliveries shall remain on such restricted streets only
for such time as is reasonably necessary to make such pickup or delivery.
   (c)   Vehicles in excess of the weight limitations set forth in subsection
(a) making pickups or deliveries shall use the most direct route to and from
the arterial streets mentioned in subsection (a).
Sec. 13-161. Nonskid devices.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate upon any street any motor
vehicle equipped with any nonskid device so constructed that any rigid or
nonflexible portion thereof comes into contact with the pavement or roadway.
Secs. 13-162—13-180. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. SPEED
Sec. 13-181. Finding; prima facie limits.
   It is hereby determined upon the basis of a traffic investigation that the
speed permitted by state or county law outside of business and residence
districts as applicable upon the village streets, is greater than is reasonable
or safe under the conditions found to exist upon such streets. It is hereby
declared that the prima facie speed limit shall be twenty (20) miles per hour
as herein set forth on these streets or parts of streets herein designated at
the times herein specified when signs are erected giving notice thereof.
(Code 1965, § 20-21)
Sec. 13-182. Maximum limits generally; decrease of limits under hazardous
conditions.
   (a)   No person shall drive a vehicle upon any public highway in this
village at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper having regard to the
traffic and the use of the way or so to endanger of life or limb or injure the
property of any person. If the rate of speed of any motor vehicle operated upon
a public highway in this village where the same passes through the business
district exceeds thirty (30) miles an hour, or if the rate of speed of any such
motor vehicle operated on any public highway in this village where the same
passes through the residence district exceeds twenty (20) miles an hour, or the
posted speed limit, such rates of speed shall be prima facie evidence that the
person operating such motor vehicle is running at a rate of speed greater than
is reasonable and proper having regard to the traffic and use of the way or so
as to endanger the life or limb or injure the property of any person.
   (b)   The fact that the speed of a vehicle does not exceed the applicable
maximum speed limit does not relieve the driver from the duty to decrease speed
when approaching and crossing an intersection, when approaching and going
around a curve, when approaching a hillcrest, when traveling upon any narrow or
winding roadway, or when special hazard exists with respect to pedestrians or
other traffic or by reason of weather or highway conditions. Speed must be
decreased as may be necessary to avoid colliding with any person or vehicle on
or entering the highway in compliance with legal requirements and the duty of
all persons to use due care.
   (c)   In event of charge of violation of this section, the complaint, also
the summons or notice to appear, shall specify the speed at which the defendant
is alleged to have driven, also the prima facie speed applicable within the
district or at the location.
(Code 1965, § 20-22(a)—(c))
Sec. 13-183. Specific limits on specific streets.
Signs shall be posted describing the prima facie speed limits. The prima facie
speed limits on the streets within the village are as follows:

(Code 1965, § 20-22(d))
Secs. 13-184—13-200. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. STOPPING, STANDING OR PARKING*
   *State law references—Stopping, standing and parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301 et
seq.; authority to regulate standing or parking, 625 ILCS 5/11-208(u 1(11;
liability for parking violations, 625 ILCS 5/11-1305, 5/11-1306.
Sec. 13-201. Violation of article provisions—Impounding of vehicles.
Every vehicle parked in violation of this article is hereby declared to be a
nuisance which may be abated by any police officer by removing and conveying
such vehicle to the vehicle pound or pounds designated by the chairman of the
police and fire department committee. Before the owner or person entitled to
possession of any legally impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove the
same, he shall furnish evidence of ownership or right to possession, and shall
pay for the cost of towing or removal to the vehicle pound, and the cost of
storage for each day of fraction thereof in such pound.
(Code 1965, § 20-62)
   State law reference—Removal of vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1302.
Sec. 13-202. Same—Citation on illegally parked vehicle.
Whenever any motor vehicle without driver is found parked or stopped in
violation of any of the restrictions imposed by ordinance of this village or by
state law, the officer finding such vehicle shall take its registration number
and may take any other information displayed on the vehicle or radio call to
the station, which may identify its owner or user, and shall conspicuously
affix to such vehicle a traffic citation as provided for in this chapter. (Code
1965, § 20-63)
Sec. 13-203. Same—Presumption in reference to illegal parking.
In any prosecution charging a violation of any law or regulation governing the
standing or parking of a vehicle, proof that the particular vehicle described
in the complaint was parked in violation of any such law or regulation,
together with proof that the defendant named in the complaint was at the time
of such parking the registered owner of such vehicle, shall constitute in
evidence a prima facie presumption that the registered owner of such vehicle
was the person who parked or placed such vehicle at the point where, and for
the time during which, such violation occurred. The lessor of any vehicle,
whether or not a registered owner or user, shall be responsible for such
parking violation and subject to the penalty therefor.
(Code 1965, § 20-64)
   State law reference—Liability of lessors of vehicles for parking violations,
625 ILCS 5/11-1305 et seq.
Sec. 13-204. Lights on parked vehicles.
   (a)   Whenever a vehicle is parked or stopped on a street during the times
between sunset and sunrise, or at any other time when there is not sufficient
light to render clearly discernible any vehicle on the street from a distance
of two hundred (200) feet, there shall be displayed upon the vehicle a parking
light on the front of such vehicle and at the rear of such vehicle.
   (b)   Any lighted driving lamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or
dimmed. (Code 1965, § 20-53(a)(27))
   State law reference—Lights on parked vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/12-203.
Sec. 13-205. Tampering with standing vehicles.
No person other than a police officer shall start or cause to be started the
motor of any motor vehicle, or shift, change, or move the levers, brake,
starting device, gears or other mechanism of a standing motor vehicle to a
position other than that in which it was left by the owner or driver thereof,
or attempt to do so.
(Code 1965, § 20-53(b))
   State law reference—Moving parked vehicles, 625 ILCS 5/11-1303(b).
Sec. 13-206. Regulation of parking at specific locations.
   (a)   The board of trustees may from time to time designate areas in which
parking is prohibited, or prohibited during certain hours, or limited in time,
or otherwise regulated or restricted. It shall be the duty of the
superintendent of streets to erect, install and maintain suitable signs or
markings, giving notice of such regulations and restrictions. It shall be
unlawful for any person to violate or fail to comply with any such sign or
marking.
   (b)   This section shall not apply to the driver of any vehicle which is
disabled on the paved, improved or main traveled portion of a highway in such a
manner and to such extent that it is impossible to avoid stopping and
temporarily leaving such disabled vehicle in such position. (Code 1965, § 20-
52)
Sec. 13-207. Residential parking permit areas.
   (a)   The board of trustees may establish by motion or other action at a
meeting, areas to be designated as residential parking permit areas. Signs
shall be posted at the end of each block and in appropriate places in the
middle of the block stating that parking is allowed by residential permit only.
   (b)   It shall be illegal to park any vehicle in such area unless such
vehicle has a current residential parking permit displayed. The village shall
issue one (1) residential parking permit for each vehicle bearing an Evergreen
Park vehicle sticker and which is based from a residential unit on the street
designated residential parking permit area. Such permits shall be restricted to
use to the car for which it was issued.
   (c)   In addition, the village shall issue two (2) residential parking
permits for visitors to any residence in the residential parking permit area.
Any misuse of such permits shall render the same invalid and the same shall not
be issued to the person or household which originally held the same. Visitors'
parking is limited to the time that the person driving the visiting vehicle is
actually in the residence or on the property being visited.
   (d)   The provisions of this section shall not apply to any service or
delivery vehicle when used to provide services or to make deliveries to
residences within a residential parking permit area, provided that the parking
of such vehicle does not exceed the time the services or deliveries are being
made.
   (e)   The mayor is authorized to establish regulations to implement the
provisions of this section.
(Code 1965, § 20-65)
Sec. 13-208. Handicapped parking privileges.
   (a)   Any motor vehicle bearing registration plates, special decal or device
issued to a physically handicapped person pursuant to the Illinois Vehicle
Code, is exempt from any statute of the state or any ordinance of this village
imposing time limitations on parking, except limitations of one-half hour or
less, on any street or highway zone, or any parking lot or parking place which
are owned, leased, or owned and leased by the village, or in any village
parking facility, and such vehicle shall also be subject to the laws which
prohibit parking in "no stopping" and "no standing" zones in front of or near
fire hydrants, driveways, public building entrances and exits, bus stops and
loading areas, and such motor vehicle is prohibited from parking where the
motor vehicle constitutes a traffic hazard and the motor vehicle shall be moved
at the instruction and request of the law enforcement officer to a location
designated by such officer.
   (b)   Parking privileges granted by this section are strictly limited to the
person to whom the special registration plates, decal, or device were issued
and to qualified operators acting under his express direction while the
disabled person is present.
   (c)   Special decals shall be displayed on the front windshield and rear
window for easy visibility.
(Code 1965, § 20-61(e)—(g))
   State law reference—Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.1.
Sec. 13-209. Snow routes designated.
   (a)   At any time during which an accumulation of two (2) inches of snowfall
occurs within a twenty-four-hour period in the village then all vehicles in
such village shall be required to comply with the following plan:
      (1)   All vehicles shall be parked on the even side of the street on even
days and on the odd side of the street on odd days.
      (2)   For the purpose of definition of this section, even and odd sides
of street shall pertain to even and odd house numbers.
      (3)   For the purpose of definition of this section, the term "day" shall
mean that day during which the accumulation takes place by 7:00 a.m.
   (b)   In addition to the foregoing there shall be established snow routes
within the village as follows: At any time during which an accumulation of two
(2) inches of snowfall or more within a twenty-four-hour period as above
defined occurs, it shall be unlawful for any person to stop, stand, park or
leave unattended a vehicle on the streets designated by the village board,
which streets are hereby designated as "snow routes."
(Code 1965, § 20-70)
Sec. 13-210. On controlled access highway.
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police
officer or traffic control device, at any controlled access highway.
(Code 1965, § 20-53(a)(20))
Sec. 13-211. Unauthorized use of parking places reserved for handicapped
persons.
   (a)   It shall be prohibited to park any motor vehicle which is not bearing
registration plates or decals issued to a handicapped person, as defined by
section 1-159.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code [Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, 111-
159.1-625 ILCS 5/1-159.1], pursuant to section 3-616 or 11-1301.2 of the
Illinois Vehicle Code [Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, 11113-616, 11-1301.2-625 ILCS
5/3-616, 5/11-1301.2], or to a disabled veteran pursuant to section 3-609 of
the Illinois Vehicle Code [Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, ¶ 3-609-625 ILCS 5/3-
609], as evidence that the vehicle is operated by or for a handicapped person
or disabled veteran, in any parking place, including any private or public
offstreet parking facility, specifically reserved, by the posting of an
official sign as designated under section 11-301 of the Illinois Vehicle Code
[Ill. Rev. Stat. ch. 951/2, ¶ 11-301-625 ILCS 5/11-301], for motor vehicles
bearing such registration plates.
   (b)   Any person or local authority owning or operating any public or
private offstreet parking facility may, after notifying the police or sheriff's
department, remove or cause to be removed to the nearest garage or other place
of safety any vehicle parked within a stall or space reserved for use by the
handicapped which does not display handicapped registration plates or a special
decal or device as required under this section.
   (c)   Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this section
shall be fined fifty dollars ($50.00) in addition to any costs or charges
connected with the removal or storage of any motor vehicle authorized under
this section.
(Code 1965, § 20-61(a)—(d))
   State law reference—Similar provisions, 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.3.
Sec. 13-212. In median areas of divided highways.
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police
officer or traffic control device, in the area between roadways of a divided
highway, including cross-overs.
(Code 1965, § 20-53(a)(21))
Sec. 13-213. On parkways.
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police
officer or traffic control device on a parkway.
(Code 1965, § 20-53(a)(31))
Sec. 13-214. Parking within lanes.
In areas marked with lines indicating a lane, a vehicle shall be parked within
the lanes, except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in
compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device.
(Code 1965, § 20-53(a)(18))
Sec. 13-215. In alleys.
   (a)   No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle, except when necessary
to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a
police officer or traffic control device, in any public alleyway behind all
property zoned or used as commercial (C, C-1 or C-2).
   (b)   Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in
compliance with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device, it
shall be unlawful for an operator of any vehicle to park within a public alley
for a longer period than is necessary for the reasonable expeditious loading
and unloading of such vehicles, in making pickups and deliveries, and in
receiving or discharging of passengers; or in such manner or under such
conditions as to leave available less than 12 feet of the width of the roadway
for the free movement of vehicular traffic.
Sec. 13-216. Fire lanes.
No person shall stop, stand or park a vehicle except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of a police
officer or traffic control device within a lane marked as a fire lane, whether
on public or private property.
Sec. 13-217. Displaying vehicles, goods for sale.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to park any vehicle upon any street for the
purpose of displaying it for sale, or to park any vehicle upon which
merchandise is being offered to the public for sale.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle displaying
a for sale sign, or any sign indicating that the vehicle is available for
purchase, on any street, alley, or on any private property, except that a
resident of a residential structure may park one (1) automobile on the property
where he resides, provided that not more than two (2) automobiles are offered
for sale from that residential structure during any calendar year. This
subsection shall not apply to motor vehicles located on property licensed and
zoned for motor vehicle sales.
Sec. 13-218. Loading, unloading generally.
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance
with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device, it shall be
unlawful to park any vehicle, except a private passenger vehicle, with a
seating capacity of not more than 10 persons, on any street, for a longer
period than is necessary for the reasonably expeditious loading and unloading
of such vehicle making pickups and deliveries.
Sec. 13-219. Overtime parking generally.
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance
with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device, it shall be
unlawful for an operator of any vehicle, including a motor vehicle, motorcycle,
trailer, semitrailer, truck tractor, road tractor, road or construction
equipment to park for a longer time than indicated on the roadway of a street
where signs have been posted limiting the time or prohibiting parking.
Sec. 13-220. Stopping, Standing or Parking in Private Lots.   
   (a)   Definitions. For purposes of this section, the following definitions
shall apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires different meaning:
      Overnight shall mean at any time between the hours of 12:00 a.m. and 6:00
a.m. for at least one (1) hour.
      Owners shall mean actual legal owner, the trust officer of a banking
institution having the right to manage and control such property, or a person
having the legal right, through lease or otherwise, to manage or control the
property.
      Parking lot shall mean any area, or areas, of land near or contiguous to
a school, church, hospital building, shopping center, commercial or industrial
facility, apartment complex, condominium complex, but not the public highways
or alleys, and used by the public as the means of access to and egress from
such buildings and the stores and business establishments at a shopping center,
and for the parking of motor vehicles.
      Shopping center means any premises having one or more stores or business
establishments in connection with which there is provided on privately-owned
property near or contiguous thereto an area, or areas, of land used by the
public as the means of access to and egress from the stores and business
establishments on such premises and for the parking of motor vehicles of
customers and patrons of such stores and business establishments on such
premises.
   (b)   Regulations. The following stopping, standing and parking regulations
may be enforced by the Village upon the election and agreement of the owner(s)
of any school, church, hospital building, shopping center, commercial or
industrial facility, apartment complex, or condominium complex, which shall be
recorded in the Office of the Cook County Clerk:
      (1)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, in a parking lot
except within a designated parking space.
      (2)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, in a park space
reserved for persons with disabilities unless the vehicle is properly
displaying authorized disability license plates or decals and the person
operating the vehicle is the authorized holder of the disability license plates
or decals or transporting the authorized holder thereof.
      (3)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, within a parking
lot during prohibited hours as posted in the parking lot. Provided, however,
any motor vehicle having affixed on the windshield a decal or sticker
constituting a parking permit issued by the owners shall not be subject to this
restriction.
      (4)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, within a parking
lot for the purposes of congregating or meeting for personal reasons.
      (5)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, within a designated
fire line or traffic lane or within twenty (20) feet in any direction of fire
hydrant, wall hydrant, water standpipe or a fire exit door.
      (6)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, within an apartment
or condominium parking lot unless the occupants thereof are authorized guests
of the complex and the motor vehicle is parked in a designated "guest" parking
spot.
      (7)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, within a parking
lot of a shopping center if the occupants are not present conducting business
at an establishment to which the parking lot serves.
      (8)   It shall be unlawful for any person to stop, leave standing, or to
park a motor vehicle, or for any registered owner of a motor vehicle to permit
the stopping, standing or parking of his/her motor vehicle, in a parking lot of
a shopping center overnight.
      (9)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in a
parking lot of a shopping center in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour or
the applicable posted or marked speed limit, whichever is less.
      (10)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in
an aisle of a parking lot in a direction that is not in conformance with the
direction designated by signs, pavement markings, or the direction that will
permit entry into an adjacent parking space at an angle of less than ninety
(90) degrees.
      (11)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in
a parking lot of a shopping center in violation of posted signs or pavement
markings.
      (12)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motor vehicle in a
parking lot of a shopping center to fail to come to a complete stop or yield at
a location/intersection controlled by a stop or yield sign or marking, as
applicable, before proceeding past a stop/yield line and, if none, a crosswalk
and, if none, a point on a plane extended in the aisle controlled thereby that
corresponds to the location of the stop/yield sign or marking.
      (13)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motor vehicle in a
parking aisle of a parking lot to fail to yield to a motor vehicle being driven
in a main aisle of the parking lot.
      (14)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motor vehicle to
exit a parking space and fail to yield to a motor vehicle being driven in an
aisle of the parking lot.
      (15)   It shall be unlawful for any person operating a motor vehicle in a
parking lot of a shopping center to fail to yield the right-of-way to any
pedestrian or cyclist in said parking lot, whether in a crosswalk or otherwise.
      (16)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate a motor vehicle in
a parking lot of a shopping center without exercising due care to avoid
colliding with any pedestrian, cyclist, or other motor vehicle.
      (17)   It shall be unlawful for any registered owner of a motor vehicle
to permit the operation, driving, stopping, standing, or parking of his/her
motor vehicle in a parking lot of a shopping center in such a manner that would
be unlawful if operated, driven, stopped, left standing, or parked on a street
or highway as set forth in the Illinois Vehicle Code or the Municipal Code for
the Village of Evergreen Park.
      (18)   It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, drive, stop, leave
standing, or to park a motor vehicle in a parking lot of a shopping center in
such a manner that would be unlawful if operated, driven, stopped, left
standing, or parked on a street or highway as set forth in the Illinois Vehicle
Code or the Municipal Code for the Village of Evergreen Park.
   (c)   Penalty. Any person found to be in violation of any provision of this
section shall be guilty of petty offense and fined in accordance with the
schedule set forth in Section 13-388, Scheduling of Fines/Penalties. Provided,
however, any person found to be in violation of E.P.M.C. § 13-220(b)(2) shall
be fined in accordance with 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.3. Each day a violation occurs
or is permitted to continue constitutes a new and separate violation.
   (d)   Administration. Tickets issued for violating this section may be
administered through Chapter 13, Motor Vehicles and Traffic, Article X,
Administrative Adjudication of Violations of Traffic Regulations Concerning the
Standing, Stopping or Condition of Vehicles.
(Ord. No. 11-2011 § 1, 7-5-11; Am. Ord. No. 4-2025 § 1, 3-3-25)
Sec. 13-221. Parking of large vehicles prohibited.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to park any of the following vehicles between the
hours of 10:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day on any public street,
alley, parkway, or public property; or on any property zoned single family
residential district or multi-family residential district:
      (1)   Any bus or school bus.
      (2)   Any tow truck.
      (3)   Any truck with a snow plow attached.
      (4)   Any trailer, including house, boat, or camping trailers which are
not self-propelled.
      (5)   Any commuter van designed for carrying more than 10 persons.
      (6)   Any road tractor.
      (7)   Any semitrailer.
      (8)   Any special hauling vehicle.
      (9)   Any tank vehicle.
      (10)   Any truck tractor.
      (11)   Any medical transport vehicle including ambulances, medical
carriers and rescue vehicles.
      (12)   Any truck or second division vehicle with a license plate
registration higher than Class B.
      (13)   Any recreational vehicle including camping, trailer, motor home,
mini motor home, travel trailer, truck camper or van camper (except that not
more than one such vehicle registered to an owner of the residence may be
parked on private property behind the front line of the residence thereon).
      (14)   Any truck with a Class B or lower license plate registration
(except that not more than one such vehicle registered to an owner of the
residence may be parked at the residence or on the public street).
      (15)   Any limousine (except that not more than one such vehicle
registered to an owner of the residence may be parked at the residence or on
the public street).
   (b)   The burden of proof in establishing the exception in (13), (14), and
(15) above shall be upon the person claiming such exception.
   (c)   The Mayor or Village Clerk shall have the authority to issue a special
parking permit for a period not to exceed 48 hours (and not more than 2 times
per year) to allow parking prohibited by this Section in the event of
unreasonable hardship.
Sec. 13-222. Reserved.
Sec. 13-223. Street cleaning.
Except when necessary to avoid conflict with other traffic or in compliance
with the direction of a police officer or traffic control device, it shall be
unlawful to park any vehicle upon any side of the roadway of a street during
the day and hours such roadway is being swept or cleaned by the village.
Official signs shall be posted by the public works director at least 4 hours
before work is to begin and during the hours and day such parking is
prohibited. Such signs may be temporary in nature but shall sufficiently inform
the public of the prohibited time of parking. The public works director is
hereby authorized to remove, at the expense of the owner, any vehicle parked in
violation of this section.
Sec. 13-224. Reserved.
Sec. 13-225. Special parking regulations for Little Company of Mary Hospital.
   (a)   The following special parking regulations shall apply to the area in
the vicinity of Little Company of Mary Hospital as outlined hereinafter:
      (1)   A "No Parking Any Time" zone on the north side of 95th Street to
extend from a point thirty (30) feet east of the Moraine Valley driveway
curbline to a point thirty (30) feet west of the west curb of the Little
Company of Mary Hospital parking lot's most easterly exit.
      (2)   A "No Parking Any Time" zone on the north side of 95th Street to
extend from a point thirty (30) feet east of the east curb of the west entrance
of the Little Company of Mary Hospital's parking lot (east of California
Avenue) on 95th Street to a point thirty (30) feet west of the west curbline of
the westerly entrance of such parking lot.
      (3)   A "No Parking Here to Corner" zone on the north side of 95th Street
to extend from a point thirty (30) feet east of the existing stop-and-go signal
on the northeast corner of 95th Street and California Avenue to the northeast
corner of 95th Street and California Avenue.
      (4)   A "No Parking Any Time" zone on the east side of California Avenue
to extend from the south curbline of 91st Street to the north curbline of 95th
Street.
      (5)   A "No Parking Any Time-Tow Away" zone on the west side of
California Avenue to extend from the south curbline of 93rd Place to the north
curbline of 95th Street.
      (6)   A "No Parking Any Time" zone on the north side of 95th Street to
extend from the west curbline of California Avenue to the east curbline of
Francisco Avenue.
   (b)   No person shall park a vehicle in violation of this section when
public notice hereof shall be duly indicated by an official sign or signs
erected on the streets hereinabove designated. Nothing herein shall be
construed to prohibit a vehicle from standing in an area restricted pursuant to
the provisions of this subsection for such period of time as is necessary for
the reasonable expeditious loading or unloading of passengers, provided such
loading or unloading shall not consume more than three (3) minutes; neither
shall any such prohibition be construed to apply to any ambulance, police,
utility or emergency vehicle while the operator thereof is engaged in the
necessary performance of emergency or police duties; nor shall it be construed
to prevent any vehicle from being brought to a stop to avoid a collision or
standing in compliance with the orders of any public officer or the direction
of any public officer or the direction of any traffic-control signals.
Sec. 13-226. Specific street restrictions.
It is unlawful for any person to park a motor vehicle in any of the following
places:
   California Avenue from 87th Street to the alley south of 87th Street and
from Mozart Street to Fairfield Avenue, during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 9:00
a.m., except on Sundays and holidays.
   California Avenue from 87th Street to the alley south of 87th Street,
between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., except on Sundays and holidays.
   Central Park Avenue, east side, from 101st Street to a point 310 feet north
of 103rd Street between 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
   Central Park Avenue, west side, from 101st Street to 103rd Street, from 9:00
a.m. to 3:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
   Kedzie Avenue from 87th Street to 103rd Street, except in specifically
designated parallel parking zones.
   87th Street, within the improved portion, which limits more specifically are
approximately Central Park Avenue on the west and the Baltimore and Ohio
Chicago Terminal Railroad on the east, between 7:00 a.m. and 9:00 a.m., except
Sundays.
   87th Street from Mozart Street to Fairfield Avenue, between 7:00 a.m. and 9:
00 a.m., except on Sundays and holidays.
   91st Street, north side, from Kedzie Avenue to 125 feet east thereof. 91st
Street, north side, from Kedzie Avenue to 125 feet west thereof. 91st Street,
south side, from Kedzie Avenue to 30 feet east thereof. 91st Street, south
side, from Kedzie Avenue to 125 feet west thereof.
   95th Street, and on any side street within one hundred fifty (150) feet of
the south or north curb of 95th Street between the hours of 3:00 a.m. and 5:00
a.m., except vehicles of the first division.
   95th Street, north curbside, from Albany Avenue to Spaulding Avenue from 4:
00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.
   95th Street, north curbside, from Springfield Avenue to Pulaski Road from 4:
00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m.
   95th Street, south curbside, from Spaulding Avenue to Kedzie Avenue and from
Kedzie Avenue to Albany Street from 7:00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m.
   95th Street, south curbside, from Pulaski Road to Springfield Avenue from 7:
00 a.m. to 9:00 a.m.
   99th Street, north side, from a point one hundred twenty-five (125) feet
west of the west curbline of Kedzie Avenue to the northwest corner of 99th
Street and Kedzie Avenue.
   99th Street, south side, within one hundred twenty-five (125) feet of the
traffic light on the southwest corner of the intersection of 99th Street and
Kedzie Avenue.
   101st Street, south side, from Central Park Avenue to St. Louis Avenue,
between 9:00 a.m. and 3:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
   102nd Street, from Central Park Avenue to St. Louis Avenue between 9:00 a.m.
and 3:00 p.m., Monday through Friday.
(Code 1965, §§ 20-57, 20-57.1, 20-58, 20-59.1, 20-60)
Secs. 13-227—13-245. Reserved.
ARTICLE VI. MINIBIKES OR MOTOR BICYCLES
Sec. 13-246. Definition.
In this article "vehicle" means any motorcycle, bicycle with motor attached,
power cycles or power scooters with a motor which produces not to exceed five
(5) brake horsepower, or which cannot be licensed by the state.
(Code 1965, § 20-100)
   Cross reference—Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.
Sec. 13-247. Liability of parents and guardians.
It shall be the duty of all police officers on discovering that any person who
has violated any of the provisions of this article is a person under the age of
seventeen (17) years to inquire as to the name, age, and last residence of such
person and to promptly notify the parent, guardian, or custodian of such child
that the child has been detained for violation of the provisions of this
article and to report to the police station for the return of such child to his
custody. Whenever it is impractical to do so, the child may be returned
forthwith to his home but in no case shall the motor vehicle being used by such
child be returned to him at that time. It is the duty of the parent, guardian,
or custodian of such child to recover such motor vehicle.
(Code 1965, § 20-105)
Sec. 13-248. Impounding of vehicles; liability of owner or registered owner.
Every vehicle which shall have been used in violation of any of the provisions
of this article is hereby declared to be a nuisance and may be summarily abated
by any police officer by removing and conveying, or causing the removal and
conveyance of such vehicle to the vehicle pound or pounds designated by the
mayor. For this purpose, any area adjacent to a police station may be declared
to be a vehicle pound. Before the owner or person entitled to possession of any
legally impounded vehicle shall be permitted to remove the same, he shall
furnish evidence of ownership or right to possession and shall pay for the cost
of towing or removal to the vehicle pound and the cost of storage for each day
or fraction thereof in the pound.
(Code 1965, § 20-104)
Sec. 13-249. Parental responsibility.
It shall be unlawful for any parent, guardian, custodian, or other person to
knowingly permit a person to violate any of the provisions of this chapter. It
shall be presumed that such parent, guardian, custodian, or any person
knowingly permits the violation when such child has committed his second
offense for violating the provisions of this or any other traffic ordinance or
law, whether or not found guilty.
(Code 1965, § 20-105(b))
Sec. 13-250. Unlawful to use.
It shall be unlawful for any person to ride, drive or be a passenger upon a
vehicle. (Code 1965, § 20-100)
Sec. 13-251. Driving in certain zoned areas prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be driven or for a person to drive the
same upon any public or private property not properly zoned for the use to
which such vehicle is being put or which is not incident to the zoned use, or
legally recognized as one of the uses permitted on such property.
(Code 1965, § 20-102)
Sec. 13-252. Driving in certain places prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any vehicle to be driven upon any public property,
semipublic property, park, or school property, except in those parts of such
property improved as driveways and recognized portions of the premises devoted
for ingress and egress for motor vehicles or used for parking incident to the
principal uses permitted on such property.
(Code 1965, § 20-103)
Secs. 13-253—13-275. Reserved.
ARTICLE VII. RELOCATION OF VEHICLES
Sec. 13-276. Definitions.
   The following definitions shall apply in the interpretation and enforcement
of this article. Any term not defined herein shall have the meaning ascribed to
it in the Illinois Vehicle Code.
   Abandoned vehicle means:
      (1)   Any vehicle which has been left unattended on a public way for a
period of at least ten (10) hours in a state of disrepair rendering it
inoperable or capable of being driven in its condition;
      (2)   Any vehicle which has been left unattended on a public way without
state registration plates or a temporary state registration placard for two (2)
or more days; or
      (3)   Any vehicle that has not been moved or used for seven (7)
consecutive days or more and is apparently deserted.
   Apparently deserted means:
      (1)   A vehicle whose appearance is indicative of its possession being
disclaimed;
      (2)   A vehicle being found or parked in an area or location which is not
within one mile of its owner's residence; or
      (3)   A vehicle found in a condition which is not indicative of a
reasonable degree of care for the well-being of the vehicle or its contents.
   Expeditious repair means:
      (1)   The parts for repair have been ordered but are not yet available
for installation for reasons beyond the owner's control;
      (2)   The repairs to the vehicle shall be completed within thirty (30)
days; or
      (3)   The vehicle is inoperable because of a recent accident and the
owner is scheduled or intends to schedule the vehicle's repair and the vehicle
will be relocated off-premises for such repairs within thirty (30) days.
   Hazardous motor vehicle means any motor vehicle located on a public way
which by its condition or location constitutes a clear and present danger to
the safety of the public, an obstruction to the normal flow of traffic, an
obstruction to ingress/egress to/from any driveway, or which has been involved
in an accident and is disabled, or cannot be immediately moved by the owner of
the vehicle.
   Inoperable motor vehicle means any motor vehicle located on private property
and in public view for at least fourteen (14) days which cannot be driven
safely or legally due to the removal of the engine, wheels or other parts. An
inoperable motor vehicle shall not mean a vehicle that is temporarily
inoperable because repairs are under way provided that the repairs are
completed within fourteen (14) days. A motor vehicle that has not moved for
fourteen (14) consecutive days that is covered with a cover or tarp, or which
does not possess a valid and current motor vehicle license from the Village of
Evergreen Park, shall be presumed to be an inoperable motor vehicle.
   Owner means any person who holds legal title to the vehicle or a person
legally entitled to possess a vehicle as identified from the registration files
of the Illinois Secretary of State or other similar agency if registered
outside the State of Illinois.
   Public way means any public street or thoroughfare in the Village of
Evergreen Park.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-277. Immediate relocation of motor vehicles.
   (a)   Members of the police department are authorized to cause the immediate
removal of a motor vehicle from any public way under the following
circumstances:
      (1)   When a vehicle qualifies as a hazardous motor vehicle;
      (2)   When an unattended vehicle is parked illegally in an officially
designated and marked "tow zone";
      (3)   When an unattended vehicle is parked illegally in an area
designated for handicapped users;
      (4)   When the location of a motor vehicle constitutes an obstruction to
emergency snow removal or street or sewer maintenance;
      (5)   When a vehicle is in violation of any provision of the Illinois
Vehicle Code which authorizes or requires (see, e.g., 625 ILCS 5/6-101 and 625
ILCS 5/4-203) the immediate towing and impoundment for that violation;
      (6)   When a vehicle is reported as being stolen;
      (7)   When a vehicle is subject to immediate relocation or removal under
the Criminal Code of 2012;
      (8)   When an officer believes immediate relocation is necessary in the
performance of community caretaking functions such as the protection of the
vehicle from damage or theft; or
      (9)   When towing or removal is necessary as an incident to an arrest.
   (b)   Members of the police department, when practical, should attempt to
notify the owner by telephone, or through other means, in order to allow the
person the opportunity to request a preliminary hearing or to claim or remove
the vehicle so as to avoid the expenses associated with a police ordered
relocation.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-278. Relocation of other vehicles.
   Members of the police department are authorized to cause the removal of all
other motor vehicles from a public way under the following circumstances:
   (a)   When a vehicle qualifies as an abandoned vehicle;
   (b)   When a vehicle is parked in violation of any ordinance of the village
or any state law prohibiting the parking, standing or stopping in certain
places for a period of at least twenty-four (24) hours but is not located in a
designated "tow-zone", handicapped area, or does not otherwise qualify as being
abandoned or hazardous; or
   (c)   When the location of a motor vehicle constitutes an obstruction to
snow removal, street cleaning, or street or sewer maintenance, or another
planned event, and notice of such activities was posted in the vicinity for a
period of at least forty-eight (48) hours prior to the relocation.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-279. Inoperable motor vehicles.
   Members of the police department are authorized to cause the removal of
inoperable motor vehicles from private property provided pre-relocation notices
and the opportunity to request a pre-location hearing has been provided. Pre-
relocation hearings attending the removal of inoperable motor vehicles from
private property shall be afforded in accordance with the procedures set forth
in Section 13-281. Provided, however, an owner of an inoperable vehicle shall
have seven (7) days after the delivery of a pre-relocation notice by letter to
request a hearing. A request for hearing stays the relocation of the vehicle
pending the hearing and decision. At the hearing, if a vehicle is determined to
be inoperable, an owner may request an extension of time for the vehicle's
relocation to a date not beyond thirty (30) days. Said extension shall be
granted upon a showing that the vehicle is being held for sale or expeditious
repair. After the hearing, a date shall be set by which the vehicle shall be
disposed of or enclosed. All requests or findings attending an extension shall
be documented in the Chief of Police's or other supervising officer's written
decision. In the event the vehicle is not disposed of or enclosed by the date
identified, the vehicle shall be relocated without further prior notice or
hearing assuming the circumstances have not changed warranting an additional
hearing. All owners of inoperable vehicles which are relocated from private
property shall be afforded process as specified in Section 13-282. Nothing in
this section shall be interpreted to create a duty on behalf of the village to
give prior notice and a hearing to an owner of an inoperable motor vehicle
before its relocation from private property if the vehicle poses an immediate
threat to the health, safety and welfare of the public due to its location or
condition.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-280. Pre-relocation notice contents and service.
   When a vehicle is subject to relocation for being parked illegally,
abandoned, or being inoperable, the following pre-relocation notices shall be
provided:
   (a)   Sticker. A pre-relocation notice in the form of a sticker shall be
entitled "Notice of Intent to Tow", and shall be affixed to a window of the
vehicle which is proposed to be relocated. The sticker shall contain the date
and time of posting, the date and time at which the vehicle will be relocated,
the basis for the proposed relocation, the phone number of the police
department, and the owner's opportunity to request a preliminary hearing.
   (b)   Letter. A pre-location notice in the form of a letter shall be
delivered by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the address of the
owner of the vehicle as indicated in the most current registration list of the
Secretary of State. The notice shall advise the owner of the location of the
vehicle, the basis for the proposed relocation, the date and time at which the
vehicle will be relocated, the opportunity and manner in which a preliminary
hearing may be requested, and the location of the relocation facility operator
where the vehicle will be held if relocated.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-281. Pre-relocation hearing procedures.
   An owner of a vehicle to be relocated pursuant to this article shall have
the right to request a preliminary hearing before the date and time identified
for the relocation of the vehicle or, if the vehicle has already been
relocated, within seven (7) business days after any notice was post-marked.
   (a)   Request for hearing. The owner may make a request for a pre-relocation
hearing to the police department in person, in writing, or by telephone. The
Chief of Police or any supervising officer must conduct a hearing within
twenty-four (24) hours after the request for a hearing is received. Provided,
however, if the date for the hearing falls on a Saturday, Sunday, or legal
holiday, the pre-relocation hearing may be held on the next business day
following the Saturday, Sunday or legal holiday. Notice of the date, time and
location of the pre-relocation hearing shall be provided to the owner. If a
request for a pre-relocation hearing is received by the village before the date
and time at which the vehicle was proposed to be relocated, the vehicle shall
not be relocated until a hearing and a decision is rendered by the Chief of
Police or other supervising officer. Nothing herein shall deprive an owner of a
post-tow hearing or the right to contest the vehicle's eligibility for
relocation during that proceeding.
   (b)   Hearing. For purposes of this section, the following shall apply to
pre-relocation hearings:
      (1)   All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the pre-relocation hearing.
      (2)   The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and
hearsay testimony will be allowed, and will be admissible.
      (3)   The Chief of Police or supervising officer's decision shall be
based upon the preponderance of evidence.
      (4)   Neither the Chief of Police nor a supervising officer shall preside
over a hearing regarding the relocation of a vehicle if he/she played a part in
the decision to designate or authorized the designation of that vehicle as
being eligible for relocation.
      (5)   If, at the conclusion of the hearing, the Chief of Police or
supervising officer determines that the vehicle is not eligible for relocation
under this article, an oral and written decision shall be issued and the
vehicle shall not be relocated. If the vehicle has already been relocated, the
Chief of Police or supervising officer shall issue a release and no charge
order to the owner which shall be brought to the relocation service facility.
The relocation facility operator shall release the vehicle immediately at no
expense to the owner. If the vehicle has already been released to the owner,
the Chief of Police or other supervising officer shall issue a refund order
requiring the relocation facility operator to refund any monies previously paid
by the owner for the vehicle's release. A written decision of the Chief of
Police's or supervising officer's determination shall be sent to the owner by
first-class mail no later than three (3) business days following the hearing.
      (6)   If, at the conclusion of the hearing, the Chief of Police or
supervising officer determines that the vehicle is/was eligible for relocation,
he or she shall orally transmit his or her decision to the owner. A written
decision shall also be issued to the owner by first-class mail no later than
three (3) business days following the hearing. The owner shall be provided with
a reasonable period of time after the decision to relocate the vehicle at his
or her own expense. In the event the owner does not relocate the vehicle, the
Chief of Police or supervising officer shall order the vehicle's relocation.
      (7)   No vehicle shall be relocated prior to the date and time of
relocation identified in the pre-tow notice.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-282. Post-relocation hearing procedures.
   The following procedures shall apply to post-relocation hearings:
   (a)   Notice of hearing. Within twenty-four (24) hours after a vehicle is
relocated pursuant to this article, the village shall notify the owner of
record of the motor vehicle of such relocation, the location of the relocation
facility at which the vehicle is being held, instructions on how to obtain a
release of the vehicle, the ability to request a post-relocation hearing, and
the date, time and location of the post-relocation hearing where the owner may
contest the validity of the relocation. Such notice shall be mailed by
certified mail, return receipt requested, to the owner of record, as shown on
the records of the Secretary of State.
   (b)   Hearing. For purposes of this section, the following shall apply to
the owners hearing:
      (1)   Unless continued by order of the hearing officer, the hearing shall
be held within forty-five (45) days after the motor vehicle was seized.
      (2)   All interested persons will be given a reasonable opportunity to be
heard at the hearing.
      (3)   The formal rules of evidence will not apply at the hearing, and
hearsay testimony will be allowed, and will be admissible.
      (4)   The hearing officer's decision shall be based upon the
preponderance of evidence.
      (5)   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer
determines that the vehicle was not eligible for relocation under this article,
he or she shall issue a release and no charge order to the owner which shall be
brought to the relocation service facility. The relocation facility operator
shall release the vehicle immediately at no expense to the owner. If the
vehicle has already been released to the owner, the hearing officer shall issue
a refund order requiring the relocation facility operator to refund any monies
previously paid by the owner for the vehicle's release. A written decision of
the hearing officer's determination shall be sent to the owner by first-class
mail no later than three (3) business days following the hearing.
      (6)   If, after the conclusion of the hearing, the hearing officer
determines that the vehicle was properly relocated under the provisions of this
article, he or she shall issue a written determination of his or her findings
to the owner. The hearing officer's decision shall be sent by first-class mail
no later than three (3) business days following the hearing.
   (c)   Other process. When a person is issued a citation and he or she will
be afforded the opportunity to contest or challenge the propriety of a vehicle
relocation at an administrative hearing, the procedures established by the code
provisions governing the citation shall apply.
(Ord. No. 27-2023 § 1, 11-20-23)
Sec. 13-283. Release procedures.
   The following procedures shall apply for the release of relocated vehicles:
   (a)   Unless a vehicle is held pursuant to applicable state, federal or any
other law, or a court order or warrant that authorizes the continued
impoundment of the vehicle, the owner of a vehicle relocated under this article
may obtain the immediate release of the vehicle by paying the full amount of
all applicable towing and storage fees charged by the relocation facility
operator. Obtaining an immediate release of the vehicle through full payment
shall not affect an owner's right to contest the relocation.
   (b)   No vehicle shall be released to an owner by the relocation facility
operator before the village issues a release order. A release order may be
obtained from the Village of Evergreen Park Police Department upon a finding
that there is no other reason to delay the immediate release of the vehicle.
   (c)   No person shall be permitted to remove a relocated vehicle from the
