whenever the village determines that the original report was in error. A
certified copy of such notification shall also be given to the person named
therein upon request and at no additional charge.
(Ord. No. 23-2007 § 1, 4-2-07; Am. Ord. No. 6-2016 § 1, 3-7-16)
Sec. 13-511. Challenging the Accuracy of a Certified Report.
   (a)   If the Administrator provides a suspension notice and subsequently
makes a certified report to the Illinois Secretary of State, the vehicle owner
may challenge the accuracy of the certified report in writing.
   (b)   The vehicle owner shall submit to the Administrator a written
statement under oath, together with any supporting documentation, establishing
one of the following grounds for challenging the accuracy of the certified
report:
      (1)   That the person was not the owner or lessee of the subject vehicle
or vehicles receiving five or more automated traffic law violations on the date
or dates such violation(s) occurred; or
      (2)   That the person already paid the fine or penalty owing indicated on
the certified report.
   (c)   A statement challenging the accuracy of a certified report shall be
sent to the Administrator via certified mail, return receipt requested, or
hand-delivered to the Administrator within five days after the person receives
notice from the Illinois Secretary of State that the person's driver's license
will be suspended at the end of a specified period of time unless the secretary
is presented with notice from the village certifying that the fines or
penalties due and owing have been satisfied or that the inclusion of the
person's name on the certified report was in error.
(Ord. No. 6-2016 § 1, 3-7-16)
Sec. 13-512. Penalty.
   (a)   Any person violating Section
13-503 of this article shall be fined $100 for each offense.
   (b)   If a person fails to request a hearing and does not otherwise pay the
applicable fine indicated in the violation notice by the date specified (i.e.,
30 days after the violation notice date), or fails to pay the original fine
within 30 days after an administrative hearing, an additional penalty of $100
will be automatically assessed against the violator.
(Ord. No. 23-2007 § 1, 4-2-07; Am. Ord. No. 6-2016 § 1, 3-7-16)
Secs. 13-513 – 13-600.   Reserved.
ARTICLE XIV. RAILROAD OCCURRENCES
Sec. 13-601. Definitions.
   The following words, terms and phrases shall have the meanings ascribed to
them, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning:
   Highway-railroad grade crossing means the intersection of a railroad track
and a highway, street, roadway, sidewalk or other public way, or any
combination of the above, designated or intended for vehicle or pedestrian
traffic, at the same grade level.
   Railroad occurrence means: 1) the activation of a safety device at a
highway-railroad grade crossing, indicating the presence or impending presence
of railroad traffic, when no train is present and is not promptly anticipated
at the intersection (i.e., false activation); 2) the continued activation of
safety devices after a train has left the vicinity of a highway-railroad grade
crossing and no other train is present or impending immediate arrival at the
intersection; or 3) a train is present in the highway-railroad grade crossing
but has stopped moving.
   Railroad occurrence response expense means any expense for personnel and
equipment involved in responding to a railroad occurrence. Responses include,
but are not limited to, police and auxiliary services, and services performed
by other departments or by a private contractor responding to a railroad
occurrence at the request of the Village of Evergreen Park.
   Responsible party means any person or entity owning, controlling, using,
operating, maintaining, having custody over, or conducting any activity upon
any land, infrastructure, facility, equipment, safety device, vehicles, cars or
trains, causing or contributing to a railroad occurrence.
   Safety device means any gate, light, bell, warning, or other signals at a
highway-railroad grade crossing that is meant or designed to give warning of
impending or present railroad traffic.
(Ord. No. 6-2014 § 2, 3-3-14; Am. Ord. 2-2024 § 1, 1-16-24)
Sec. 13-602. Railroad occurrence response.
   In the event of a railroad occurrence, the Chief of Police, or his or her
designee, shall immediately attempt to contact a responsible party to advise of
the railroad occurrence. Thereafter, or in conjunction therewith, personnel,
vehicles, and equipment shall be dispatched to the highway-railroad grade
crossing that is the site of the railroad occurrence, and to nearby street
intersections affected or anticipated to be affected by the railroad
occurrence, to perform traffic control duties to alleviate traffic congestion
and redirect traffic. Village officials from other departments shall cooperate
with the police department to provide personnel, vehicles, and equipment deemed
reasonably necessary to the performance of such traffic control duties.
(Ord. No. 6-2014 § 2, 3-3-14; Am. Ord. 2-2024 § 1, 1-16-24)
Sec. 13-603. Responsible party liability.
   It shall be the duty of any responsible party to reimburse the Village of
Evergreen Park for its railroad occurrence response expenses no later than 20
days after the issuance of an invoice detailing said expenses. The liability of
a responsible party shall be joint and severable.
(Ord. No. 6-2014 § 2, 3-3-14; Am. Ord. 2-2024 § 1, 1-16-24)
Sec. 13-604. Railroad occurrence response expenses.
   The Village of Evergreen Park shall be reimbursed for its railroad
occurrence response expenses at the following hourly rates:$90 per hour, or any
portion thereof, for other motor vehicles, including police squad cars,
responding to the occurrence; and $60 per hour, or any portion thereof after
the first hour, for personnel. All other expenses shall be billed at their
reasonable and customary rate.
(Ord. No. 6-2014 § 2, 3-3-14; Am. Ord. 2-2024 § 1, 1-16-24)
Sec. 13-605. Administration.
   Any responsible party violating the provisions of Section
13-603 shall be subject to a judgment in the amount of the Village of Evergreen
Park's railroad occurrence response expenses. Violations of Section
13-603 may be administered through the provisions of
Chapter 12, Miscellaneous Provisions and Offenses, Article X, Administrative
Adjudication of Non-Vehicular Regulations Violations, of the Evergreen Park
Municipal Code, or by any other means permitted by law. Nothing in this Article
shall be interpreted to limit the remedies or penalties available to Village of
Evergreen Park.
(Ord. No. 6-2014 § 2, 3-3-14; Am. Ord. 2-2024 § 1, 1-16-24)
Chapter 14
NUISANCES*
   *Cross references—Animals, ch.
4; health, ch.
9; businesses not to be nuisances, § 11-1; unlicensed motor vehicle declared
nuisance, § 13-6; solid waste, ch.
20; water, sewers and sewage disposal, ch.
24.
   State law references—Powers of home rule units, Ill. Const. art. VII, § 6;
nuisances, 740 ILCS 55/221 et seq.
Sec. 14-1. General provision.
In all cases in this Code where no provision is made defining what are
nuisances and how the same may be removed, abated, or prevented, in addition to
what may be declared such in this Code, those offenses which are known to the
common law of the land and such other offenses as may be set out in other
sections of this Code and state law as nuisances may, in case the same exist
within the village limits, be treated as such, and proceeded against as it is
provided in this Code, or any other law.
(Code 1965, § 19-55)
Sec. 14-2. Notice to abate.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of the building commissioner, or any other
officer authorized by the village, to serve notice in writing upon the owner,
occupant, agent or person in possession or control of any lot, building or
premises in or upon which any nuisance may be found, or who may be the owner or
cause of any such nuisance, other than the nuisance specified in section
14-10, requiring him to abate the same in such manner as he shall prescribe
within a reasonable time. It shall not be necessary in any case for the
building commissioner or such other officer to specify in his notice the manner
in which any nuisance shall be abated unless he shall deem it advisable so to
do. Such notice may be given or served by any officer who is so directed. If
the person so notified shall neglect or refuse to comply with the requirements
of such order by abating such nuisance within the time specified, such person
shall be fined as set forth in this Code.
   (b)   The notices referred to in and required by this section shall be in
the following form: TO: (Party to be notified)
YOU ARE NOTIFIED THAT AS OF (Day, Month, Year) that you are maintaining a
nuisance in Violation of Paragraph 14 of the Evergreen Park Municipal Code, in
that (here specify condition which violates ordinance).
YOU ARE FURTHER ADVISED THAT UNLESS YOU REMOVE (remedy or repair) THE AFORESAID
VIOLATION BY (Day, Month, Year) (not less than 7 days from the date of service
of the notice) you shall be held responsible for the full penalty of the law.
Signed                
      Title
   (c)   It shall be the duty of the building commissioner or such other
officer to proceed at once upon the expiration of the time specified in such
notice to cause such nuisance to be abated. Whenever the owner, occupant,
agent, or person in possession or control of any premises in or upon which any
nuisance may be found is unknown or cannot be found, the commissioner shall
proceed to abate such nuisance without notice; in either case, the expense of
such abatement shall be collected from the person who may have created,
continued, or suffered such nuisance to exist, in addition to any penalty or
fine.
(Code 1965, § 19-53)
Sec. 14-3. Discretionary manner of abatement.
Whenever any nuisance shall be found on any premises within the village, the
building commissioner or such other officer as authorized is hereby authorized,
in his discretion, to cause the same to be summarily abated in such manner as
he may direct.
(Code 1965, § 19-54)
Sec. 14-4. Inoperable refrigerators, appliances, etc.
Any person who shall abandon or discard in any place accessible to children any
cardboard box, cardboard carton, wooden box, crate or objects of a similar
nature, refrigerator, icebox or ice chest of a capacity of one and one-half
(11/2) cubic feet or more which has an attached lid or door which may be opened
or fastened shut by means of an attached latch, or who, being the owner,
lessee, or manager of any place or premises knowingly permits such cardboard
box, cardboard carton, wooden box, crate or objects of a similar nature,
refrigerator, icebox or ice chest to remain there in such condition shall be
guilty of an offense under this chapter and such condition shall be a nuisance.
Every day such violation continues shall be deemed a separate and distinct
offense. This section shall not prohibit garbage cans or garbage receptacles,
nor shall it apply where the door or lid is removed or the same crushed.
(Code 1965, § 19-56(a))
Sec. 14-5. Vehicles, structures, yards, lots, etc., as a nuisance.
No vehicle, structure, receptacle, yard, lot, premises, or part thereof, shall
be made, used, kept, maintained or operated in the village if such use,
keeping, maintaining, or operating shall be the occasion of any nuisance, or
shall be dangerous to life or detrimental to health. (Code 1965, § 19-57)
Sec. 14-6. Existing in connection with business, labor.
No substance, matter or thing of any kind whatsoever, which shall be dangerous
or detrimental to health, shall be allowed to exist in connection with any
business, or used therein, or used in any work or labor performed in the
village.
(Code 1965, § 19-58)
Sec. 14-7. Animals or other matter or substance.
No person shall bring into the village or keep therein for sale or otherwise,
either for food or for any other purpose, any dead or live animal, nor any
matter, substance, or thing which shall be a nuisance or which shall occasion a
nuisance in the village, or which may or shall be dangerous or detrimental to
health.
(Code 1965, § 19-59)
Sec. 14-8. Factory, yard, rendering establishment which becomes nauseous, foul
or offensive.
Any factory, yard, building or structure of any kind or rendering establishment
which shall become nauseous, foul or offensive is hereby declared a nuisance.
The person owning, maintaining or in possession or control of any such factory,
shop, yard, house, building, or structure shall be guilty of an offense under
this chapter. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during
or on which a violation occurs or continues or is permitted to continue.
(Code 1965, § 19-60)
Sec. 14-9. Junk and rodents, unsightly yard, etc.
It shall be unlawful for any person to store or keep any old articles or
materials which may be classified as junk adjacent to or in close proximity to
any schoolhouse, church, public park, public grounds, business building or
residence without first providing proper and tight buildings for the storage of
the same. The storing or accumulating of unsightly material of any kind,
including but not limited to garbage, metal, junk of every kind and character,
nonfunctioning motor vehicles, trash of every kind and nature on any property
or lot within the village is hereby prohibited. The storing or accumulation of
any condition which may or can become breeding grounds or harborage for or
attraction to insects, rodents, or other possible disease-carrying animals on
any property or lot within the village is prohibited.
(Code 1965, § 19-43)
Sec. 14-10. Weeds.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any owner, user, lessee or occupant or any
agent, servant, representative, custodian or employee of such owner, user,
lessee or occupant, of any lot or part of a lot to:
      (1)   Allow or maintain on such lot or part thereof any growth of weeds
(except noxious weeds) to a height of over eight (8) inches; and
      (2)   The growth of noxious weeds, as defined in section 2(5) of the
Illinois Noxious Weed Law [505 ILCS 100/2(5)], to any height.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of every owner to cut all noxious weeds at his
own expense. If such owner refuses or neglects to cut them, the village may
provide for the cutting of them, collect the reasonable cost thereof from the
owner, and file a lien as provided for in section 11-20-7 of the Illinois
Municipal Code [65 ILCS 5/11-20-71.
(Code 1965, § 19-104)
Chapter 15
PARKS AND RECREATION*
Art. I.    In General, §§ 15-1-15-25
Art. II.   Park Board, §§ 15-26-15-50
Art. III.   Park Rules, §§ 15-51-15-66
   *Cross reference—Director of recreational services, § 2-301 et seq.
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 15-1—15-25. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. PARK BOARD*
   *Cross reference—Boards and commissions generally, § 2-346 et seq.
Sec. 15-26. Created.
A park board is hereby created for the village, which board shall be known as
"The Park Board of the Village of Evergreen Park."
(Code 1965, § 21-1)
Sec. 15-27. Composition; appointment; qualifications of board.
   (a)   The park board shall consist of five (5) members, one (1) of which
shall be chairman. The mayor and the chairman of the plats, public grounds and
buildings committee of the board of trustees shall be members ex officio.
   (b)   The members of the park board shall be appointed by the mayor and
board of trustees voting jointly, and the mayor and board of trustees shall
appoint one (1) of such members as chairman of such board. No member shall be
eligible to be a member of the park board unless he shall be a resident of the
village and such members, except the chairman, shall have residence as follows:
      (1)   One (1) member in the area north of 95th Street and east of Kedzie
Avenue.
      (2)   One (1) member in the area north of 95th Street and west of Kedzie
Avenue.
      (3)   One (1) member in the area south of 95th Street and east of Kedzie
Avenue.
      (4)   One (1) member in the area south of 95th Street and west of Kedzie
Avenue.
   (c)   Should a member of the board cease to be a resident of the village,
his office shall become vacant.
(Code 1965, § 21-2)
Sec. 15-28. Terms of members.
The members of the park board shall be appointed to serve for terms of five (5)
years, and until their successors are appointed and qualified.
(Code 1965, § 21-3)
Sec. 15-29. Vacancies.
Any member of the park board may resign from his office. If a vacancy in office
occurs by reason of death, resignation or removal from office, the vacancy
shall be filled by appointment by the mayor and board of trustees voting
jointly for the remainder of the term of the office which has become vacant.
(Code 1965, § 21-4)
Sec. 15-30. Meetings.
Meetings of the park board shall be held in the village hall and shall be held
at such time or times as the board may prescribe, provided that meetings shall
be held not less often than once in each quarter.
(Code 1965, § 21-5)
Sec. 15-31. Compensation of members.
Each member of the park board shall receive such compensation as the mayor and
board of trustees shall fix by ordinance or resolution, and the chairman of the
board shall receive such compensation as the mayor and board of trustees shall
fix by ordinance or resolution, but such compensation shall not be paid for
more than twelve (12) meetings in any given fiscal year.
(Code 1965, § 21-7)
Sec. 15-32. Duties.
The park board authorized by this chapter shall have the power and duty:
      (1)   To prepare and recommend to the mayor and board of trustees a plan
for the acquisition, conduct, equipment and maintenance of park sites for the
village.
      (2)   To prepare and recommend to the mayor and board of trustees from
time to time, plans for specific improvements for park sites.
      (3)   To prepare and recommend to the mayor and board of trustees, not
later than June first of each year, a budget showing estimated cost of
equipment and maintenance of park sites for the fiscal year.
      (4)   To perform and carry out such duties and functions as shall he
assigned to them by the mayor and board of trustees by resolution.
(Code 1965, § 21-6)
Secs. 15.33—15-50. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. PARK RULES
Sec. 15-51. Scope.
Except as stated otherwise, the provisions of this article apply to public
parks and public playgrounds.
Sec. 15-52. Permit required.
   (a)   Whenever any group, association, organization or individual desires to
use any park facilities, including but not limited to tennis courts, football
fields or other recreational facilities for use such as picnics, parties,
theatrical or entertainment performances, the individual or in the alternative
if a group, a representative of such group, association or organization shall
first obtain a permit from the department of recreation for such purposes. The
mayor and board of trustees may adopt an application form to be used by the
department of recreation for such situations. Such permits shall be restricted
to residents of the village, if an individual, or to local groups, associations
or organizations, if the applicant is a group, association or organization.
   (b)   The department of recreation shall grant the application if it appears
that the individual, group, association or organization will not interfere with
the general use of the park by the individual members of the public and if the
individual, group, association or organization meets all other conditions
contained in the application. The application may contain a requirement for an
indemnity bond to protect the village from any liability of any kind or
character and to protect village property from damage.
Sec. 15-53. Weapons; missiles.
Persons are forbidden to carry firearms or other unlawful weapons as defined by
state law, or to throw stones or other missiles within any park or public
playground of the village.
Sec. 15-54. Hawking, peddling; other sales.
No person shall expose any article or thing for sale within any public park or
public playground, nor shall any hawking or peddling be allowed therein without
permission so to do in writing from the board of trustees.
Sec. 15-55. Disorderly conduct.
No threatening, abusive, insulting or indecent language shall be allowed in any
part of a public park or public playground; nor shall any conduct be permitted
whereby a breach of peace may be occasioned; nor shall any person play any game
of chance at or with any table or instrument of gaming; nor shall any person
commit any obscene or indecent act therein.
Sec. 15-56. Posting bills, etc.
No person shall paste or otherwise affix any bill, notice or other paper upon
any structure or thing within any park or public playground nor upon any of the
gates or enclosures thereof.
See. 15-57. Permit for use of musical instrument.
No person shall play upon any musical instrument within any park or public
playground without a permit from the mayor of the village, in writing.
Sec. 15-58. Bonfires.
No person shall light, make or use any bonfire in any park or public
playground.
Sec. 15-59. Protection of grass, shrubs, etc.
No person shall be allowed to play ball or other games likely to injure the
grass, lawn, turf or shrubbery in any of the village parks, except in such
places as may be provided for that purpose; nor shall any person cut, break or
in any way injure or deface, trees, shrubs, plants, turf or any of the
buildings, fences or other structures or property contained in any park or
public playground.
Sec. 15-60. Being intoxicated; selling liquors.
No intoxicated person shall enter, be or remain in any public park or
playground, nor shall any person bring into, sell, give away or drink any
intoxicating liquors in any public park or playground.
Sec. 15-61. Closing hours.
No person shall be in any public park or public playground after the hour of
10:00 p.m. or after the posted hour of closing, whichever is earlier, and
before 5:00 a.m. of the following morning.
Sec. 15-62. Glass containers prohibited in parks.
No person shall possess any glass container or glass bottle in any public park
or public playground.
Sec. 15-63. Entry into ponds prohibited.
   (a)   No person shall swim in any pond located on property owned by the
Village.
   (b)   No person shall enter into any pond located on property owned by the
Village.
   (c)   No person shall use any flotation device in any pond located on
property owned by the Village.
   (d)   No person shall fish in any pond located on property owned by the
Village.
   (e)   No person shall throw any object (including food) into any pond
located on property owned by the Village.
   (f)   No person shall use any raft, boat, float or other similar device on
any pond located on property owned by the Village.
(Ord. No. 16-2005 § 1, 6-6-05)
Sec. 15-64. Feeding prohibited.
No person shall feed any animal, bird, fowl, or fish on any property owned by
the Village.
(Ord. No. 16-2005 § 1, 6-6-05)
Sec. 15-65. Bicycles, skateboards, and roller blades prohibited.
No person shall bicycle, skateboard, roller blade, roller skate or use a
scooter on any property owned by the Village except in areas designated for
such use. Unless an area is paved and allowed for such use, then any person
performing a prohibited act shall be subject to forfeiture of the bicycle,
skateboard, roller blade, roller skate or scooter.
(Ord. No. 16-2005 § 1, 6-6-05)
Sec. 15-66. Motor vehicles prohibited.
No person shall drive or operate any vehicle (including cars, trucks,
motorcycles, motor scooters, motor vehicles, motorized pedal cycle, and go
carts) except in parking lots designated for such use on any property owned by
the Village. Nothing herein shall prohibit the use of a motorized wheelchair by
a person with disabilities.
(Ord. No. 16-2005 § 1, 6-6-05)
Chapter 16
PEDDLERS, SOLICITORS, ETC.
Art. I. In General, §§ 16-1-16-25
Art. II. Peddlers, §§ 16-26-16-75
   Div. 1. Generally, §§ 16-26-16-45
   Div. 2. License, §§ 16-46-16-75
Art. III. Solicitation Generally, §§ 16-76-16-100
Art. IV. Commercial Solicitors and Canvassers, §§ 16-101-16-150
   Div. 1. Generally, §§ 16-101-16-115
   Div. 2. Permit, §§ 16-116-16-150
Art. V. Charitable Solicitations, §§ 16-151-16-176
   Div. 1. Generally, §§ 16-151-16-170
   Div. 2. Permit, §§ 16-171-16-176
Art. VI. Non-Solicitation, §§ 16-180-16-182
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 16-1—16-25. Reserved.
ARTICLE II. PEDDLERS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 16-26. Definition.
For the purposes of this article, every person who shall sell or offer for
sale, barter or exchange at retail when traveling from place to place on, along
or upon the streets or alleys of the village, or who shall sell and deliver
from any vehicle going from place to place, or who shall sell or vend from
automatic vending machines in stores, warehouses, shops, factories or other
places of business, any books, tickets for games, shows or sports, pictures,
photographs, goods, wares or merchandise, wood, vegetables, fruits, fruit
juices or other similar beverages, soft drinks, ice cream, candy, nuts, or
other confections, bakery goods, sandwiches, butter or country produce in the
village shall be deemed a peddler.
Sec. 16-27. Exemptions.
The provisions of this article shall not be construed to apply to any person
selling vegetables, fruits, berries, poultry or other products of his own farms
or premises, or to the sale of tickets for charitable purposes.
Sec. 16-28. Registration.
It shall be unlawful for any person to peddle at retail from place to place
within the village unless such person shall have registered within one (1) year
in a registration book provided for the purpose in the police department his
name and address, the address of the firm or corporation, if any, which he
represents, the names and addresses of not less than two (2) references as to
his moral character, honesty and integrity, together with a brief description
of the nature of the business in which he is engaged, and the kinds of goods or
property to be sold or solicited for, if any; and shall have submitted to the
department of police at least two (2) photographs, size one (1) inch by two and
one-half (2/2) inches and shall have permitted the police department to
fingerprint him. Each person so registered shall be provided with a card
bearing his name and address and a brief description of himself, signed by the
chief of police, which card he shall carry with him as evidence of his
registration.
Sec. 16-29. Identification of vehicles used by peddlers of food products.
Every wagon or vehicle used by peddlers of food products shall have displayed
upon each side thereof in plain print the name and address of the owner and the
kind of goods for sale.
Sec. 16-30. Assistants on vehicles.
Upon each vehicle used by any peddler, there shall be permitted only one (1)
helper or assistant to the driver or operator of such wagon or vehicle.
Sec. 16-31. Fraud and misrepresentation.
It shall be unlawful for any peddler to be guilty of any fraud, cheat,
misrepresentation or imposition or to violate, neglect or refuse to comply with
any of the provisions of this article.
Secs. 16-32—16-45. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. LICENSE
Sec. 16-46. Required; term.
Every person desiring to engage in or conduct business as a peddler shall,
before engaging in such business, obtain a license so to do. Such license shall
begin on May first of the year for which such license is issued and shall
terminate on April thirtieth the next year.
Sec. 16-47. Application generally.
Every person who desires a license as a peddler shall make application in
writing therefor to the village collector, setting out in such application the
full name and residence of the applicant and whether he desires to be licensed
as a peddler of vegetables, fruits, fruit juices or other similar beverages,
soft drinks, ice cream, candy, nuts or other confections, bakery goods,
sandwiches, or commodities from a basket or other like receptacles carried by
or maintained and operated by himself; to sell or barter any tickets for games,
shows or sports, or any thing of value; or to solicit orders for any such
articles. Such application shall also state in what commodity, article, thing
of value or merchandise such peddler intends to deal.
(Code 1965, § 26-4)
Sec. 16-48. Approval of application for food vendor's license.
The application for a license of every peddler of bakery goods, prepared foods,
confections, ice cream, beverages, fruit juices, butter, eggs and food or drink
of similar nature shall first be passed upon and a permit given for the
issuance of each license by the department of health. (Code 1965, § 26-5)
Sec. 16-49. Issuance.
Upon receipt of the application referred to in section
16-47 of this Code and the payment by such applicant to the village collector
of the license fee fixed for the particular form of license issued, the mayor
shall issue or cause to be issued to such applicant a license attested by the
village clerk authorizing such applicant to engage in and carry on the business
of a peddler of the kind stated in such application.
(Code 1965, § 26-6)
Sec. 16-50. Inspection prerequisite for vending machines used to dispense food.
No license to install vending machines for the automatic sale of foods and food
products shall be issued until after the machines and goods which they are to
contain and the premises in which such machines are to be used have been
inspected and approved by the department of health and a permit to procure a
license has been issued by the department of health.
(Code 1965, § 26-7)
Sec. 16-51. Fees for license to peddle from wagon or other vehicle.
The fee to be charged for a license to peddle from a wagon or other vehicle
propelled by mechanical power shall be seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per annum.
For each additional wagon or other vehicle used in and about his business, such
licensee shall pay an annual license fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
(Code 1965, § 26-9)
Sec. 16-52. Fee for ticket dealers.
The fee for a person selling, bartering or exchanging any tickets for games,
shows or sports, or other things of value, shall be twenty-five dollars
($25.00) per annum. (Code 1965, § 26-10)
Sec. 16-53. Photographs; approval of police department prerequisite to granting
of license.
Every peddler shall be required to furnish two (2) satisfactory photos, size
one (1) inch by two and one-half (2 1/2) inches, of himself at the time the
license is applied for. Before any such license shall be granted, the applicant
therefor shall secure the written approval of the department of police, and one
(1) of the photos of the applicant shall be permanently filed in the records of
the department of police, and the other shall be carried by the applicant at
all times while transacting business in the village; provided, however, that no
wagon peddler shall be required to furnish photos in order to procure a
license.
(Code 1965, § 26-11)
Sec. 16-54. Badge.
Each peddler shall receive from the village, when his license is granted, a
badge bearing the license number, which badge shall be worn and conspicuously
displayed by the peddler on his outer garment at all times while engaged in
business in the village.
(Code 1965, § 26-12)
Sec. 16-55. Revocation.
Any license may be revoked by the village president for violation by the holder
thereof of any of the ordinances of the village or of any state or federal law
or whenever it appears that such licensee is guilty of either fraud or
misrepresentation under section
16-31. (Code 1965, § 26-17)
Secs. 16-56—16-75. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. SOLICITATION GENERALLY
Sec. 16-76. Definitions.
The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have
the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly
indicates a different meaning:
   Soliciting shall mean and include any one (1) or more of the following
activities:
      (1) Seeking to obtain orders for the purchase of goods, wares,
merchandise, foodstuffs, services of any kind, character or description
whatever, for any kind of consideration whatever.
      (2)   Seeking to obtain prospective customers for application or purchase
of insurance of any type, kind or character.
      (3)   Seeking to obtain subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals,
newspapers and every other type or kind of publication.
      (4)   Seeking to obtain gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any
other valuable thing for the support or benefit of any religious, charitable or
nonprofit association, organization, corporation or project.
   Solicitor shall mean any person who engages in the activity of soliciting.
(Code 1965, § 26-50)
   Cross reference—Definitions and rules of construction generally, § 1-2.
Sec. 16-77. Village policy.
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the board of trustees that the
occupants of the residences in this village shall make the determination of
whether solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective
residences.
(Code 1965, § 26-51)
Sec. 16-78. Notice regulating.
Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by this
article shall comply with this section. Notice of the determination by the
occupant of giving invitation to solicitors, or the refusal of invitation to
solicitors, to any residence, shall be given in the manner following:
      (1)   A weatherproof card, approximately two (2) inches by four (4)
inches in size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the
residence, indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the words:
"NO SOLICITORS."
      (2)   The letters shall be at least one-half inch in height. For the
purpose of uniformity, the cards shall be provided by the village clerk to
persons requesting, at the cost thereof.
      (3)   Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice to any
solicitor of the determination by the occupant of the residence of the
information contained thereon.
(Code 1965, § 26-52)
Sec. 16-79. Duty of solicitor to examine notice; depart when requested.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of every solicitor upon going into any premises
in the village upon which a residence is located to first examine the notice
provided for in section
16-78 if any is attached, and be governed by the statement contained on the
notice. If the notice states "no solicitors invited" or "no solicitors," then
the solicitor, whether registered or not, shall immediately and peacefully
depart from the premises.
   (b)   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether
invited or not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when
requested to do so by the occupant.
(Code 1965, § 26-53)
Sec. 16-80. Uninvited solicitors prohibited; nuisance; trespass.
It is unlawful and shall constitute a trespass and a nuisance for any person to
go upon any premises and ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any
sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant
of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant
thereof and engage in soliciting as herein defined, in defiance of the notice
exhibited at the residence in accordance with the provisions of section
16-78.
(Code 1965, § 26-54)
Sec. 16-81. Time restrictions.
All solicitors shall be governed by the time restriction set forth in section
16-101. (Code 1965, § 26-55)
Secs. 16-82—16-100. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. COMMERCIAL SOLICITORS AND CANVASSERS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 16-101. Times when allowed; where operations allowed; penalty.
No person shall solicit or canvass, with or without a permit, except during the
hours of 11:00 a.m. through 7:00 p.m. on Monday through Friday, and during the
hours of 11:00 a.m. through 6:00 p.m. on Saturday. No soliciting or canvassing
is permitted anytime on a Sunday or a state holiday. All canvassing and
soliciting shall be carried on only at the front entrance of the premises.
(Code 1965, § 26-31(a)) (Ord. No. 29-2008 § 1, 12-15-08)
Sec. 16-102. Consent of occupants necessary to enter or remain on premises.
It shall be unlawful to enter any residential premises, or to remain therein,
for the purpose of selling or taking orders for any commodity or service or for
soliciting contributions or memberships of any nature, without the express or
implied consent of the occupant of such premises.
(Code 1965, § 26-26)
Sec. 16-103. Persons afflicted with contagious disease not to act as solicitors
or canvassers.
No person afflicted with, or a carrier of, any epidemic or contagious disease
shall act as solicitor or canvasser within the village.
(Code 1965, § 26-27)
Secs. 16-104—16-115. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 16-116. Registration, permit required; scope of permit.
It shall be unlawful for any person to go in or upon any private residence,
apartment or premises in the village for the purpose of soliciting from the
occupants thereof, or to canvass orders for future delivery of goods, wares,
merchandise or services to be performed of any kind, character or description,
or for the purpose of offering to give or furnish or giving or furnishing any
goods, wares, merchandise or services to any such occupants to induce or invite
such orders, whether or not such person has, carries or exposes for sale a
sample of the subject of such sale, or whether he is collecting advance payment
on such sales or not and, further, whether or not such person for himself, or
for another person hires, leases, uses or occupies any building, structure,
tent, motel room, lodginghouse, apartment, shop, or any other place within the
village for the sole purpose of exhibiting samples or taking orders for future
delivery, without having first registered and applied for and received from the
chief of police a permit to do so. Only one (1) person shall solicit or canvass
under the terms of any permit provided for in this division, and no other
person shall solicit or canvass under the same permit as copartner, agent or
otherwise.
(Code 1965, § 26-20)
Sec. 16-117. Application.
Any person desiring to obtain such permit shall, prior to engaging in such
activity, register and make application therefor, over his signature, in
writing under oath to the chief of police on a form provided by the village in
which he shall give the following information:
      (1)   Name and address.
      (2)   The name and address or the person by whom he is employed or with
whom he is associated.
      (3)   The length of such employment or association.
      (4)   The place of residence and nature of employment of registrant
during the preceding twelve (12) months.
      (5)   The nature of the commodities, articles or services registrant is
selling or offering for sale or the purpose for which such registrant purposes
to canvass in the village.
      (6)   An estimate of the length of time and a statement of the part of
the village in which registrant will pursue his activities.
      (7)   The names and addresses of three (3) persons who have known
registrant for at least one (1) year and from whom registrant is willing that
inquiry be made to verify the facts stated by him.
      (8)   The personal description and complete identification of registrant
together with marks of physical identification, if any.
      (9)   The date or dates when he last engaged in activity as solicitor or
canvasser within the village, including the name and address of the person by
whom he was employed or with whom he was associated during such activity within
the village.
(Code 1965, § 26-21)
Sec. 16-118. Applicant to furnish evidence of character, photographs,
fingerprints, bond.
The application for a permit under this division shall be accompanied by such
credentials and other evidence of the good moral character and identity of the
applicant as may be reasonably required by the chief of police. In addition
thereto, such applicant shall furnish two (2) satisfactory photographs, size
one (1) inch by two and one-half (2'12) inches, of himself at the time the
permit is granted, and shall also furnish his fingerprints to the police
department at the time registration and application is made for the permit; and
such application shall be accompanied by a bond in the penal sum of five
hundred dollars ($500.00), executed by a surety company or by two (2)
responsible freeholders residing within the village, conditioned that all
goods, wares, merchandise or articles sold by such applicant shall be as
represented by him and that he will refund the purchase price of any goods,
wares, merchandise or articles sold by him which are not as represented. Any
person aggrieved by the action of any such applicant shall have the right of
action on the bond for the recovery of the money or damages or both.
(Code 1965, § 26-22)
Sec. 16-119. Verification of registration.
The chief of police shall promptly cause to be made such verification of the
facts stated by the registrant as the circumstances require, and shall complete
such verification in not more than fourteen (14) days after the filing of the
registration statement.
(Code 1965, § 26-23)
Sec. 16-120. Waiting period after registration.
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage as a solicitor or canvasser
within the village until a period of fourteen (14) days has elapsed from the
date on which he has registered and furnished the information required by this
article, unless prior to the expiration of such fourteen-day period the chief
of police advised the registrant that the facts stated by him in compliance
with the registration requirements in this division shall have been
sufficiently verified.
(Code 1965, § 26-24)
Sec. 16-121. Fee; expiration.
Before a permit shall be issued, the applicant shall pay to the Village Clerk a
permit fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Each permit shall expire thirty (30) days
after its issuance.
(Code 1965, § 26-33) (Am. Ord. No. 18-2018 §1, 7-16-18)
Sec. 16-122. False information in application.
It shall be unlawful for any person to engage as a solicitor or canvasser
within the village if any of the information furnished by him as required by
this division, which is material to his character and responsibility or to the
activity he proposed to engage in, has been falsely stated.
(Code 1965, § 26-25)
Sec. 16-123. Carrying, exhibition of permit; display of badges.
   (a)   Each permit issued under this division shall be carried at all times
by the applicant to whom issued, when soliciting or canvassing in the village,
and shall be exhibited by such applicant whenever he shall be requested so to
do by any police officer or by any person solicited or canvassed.
   (b)   A badge in which the village shall have inserted one (1) of the
photographs furnished by the applicant shall be worn and conspicuously
displayed by the solicitor on his outer garments at all times when engaged in
such activity within the village.
(Code 1965, § 26-28)
Sec. 16-124. Use of photographs.
The chief of police shall file one (1) of the photographs of the applicant
permanently in the records of the police department. The other shall be
inserted in the badge to be furnished by the village, bearing the word
"SOLICITOR," which badge shall be worn by the applicant as hereinbefore
provided.
(Code 1965, § 26-29)
Sec. 16-125. Assignment, transfer of permit or badge.
Permits or badges issued pursuant to this division shall not be assigned or
transferred, nor shall they be used by any person other than the person to whom
they were issued. (Code 1965, § 26-30)
Sec. 16-126. Revocation.
Any permit issued under this division may be revoked by the mayor or the chief
of police for violation by the holder thereof of any of the ordinances of the
village, or of any state or federal law, or whenever the holder of such permits
shall cease to possess the character and qualifications required by this
division for the issuance of such permit.
(Code 1965, § 26-32)
Secs. 16-127—16-150. Reserved.
ARTICLE V. CHARITABLE SOLICITATIONS
DIVISION 1. GENERALLY
Sec. 16-151. Consent of occupants necessary to enter or remain on premises.
It shall be unlawful to enter any residential premises, or to remain therein,
for the purpose of selling or taking orders for any commodity or service or for
soliciting contributions or memberships of any nature, without the express or
implied consent of the occupant of such premises.
(Code 1965, § 26-43)
Sec. 16-152. Solicitation on highways.
   (a)   No person shall stand on a highway within the village for the purpose
of soliciting contributions from the occupant of any vehicle except as
specifically provided by this article. Solicitation on highways within the
village shall be allowed only at intersections where all traffic is required to
come to a full stop. In addition, the soliciting agency shall be:
      (1)   Registered with the attorney general as a charitable organization
as provided by the Solicitation for Charity Act [225 ILCS 46010.01 et seq.], as
amended.
      (2)   Engaged in a statewide fundraising activity.
      (3)   Liable for any injuries to any person or property during the
solicitation which is casually related to an act of ordinary negligence of the
soliciting agent.
   (b)   Any person engaged in the act of solicitation as provided in this
article shall be sixteen (16) years of age or more and shall be wearing a
highly visible vest. No person shall stand on or in the proximity of a highway
for the purpose of soliciting the watching or guarding of a vehicle while
parked or about to be parked on a highway.
(Code 1965, § 26-35(b))
Secs. 16-153—16-170. Reserved.
DIVISION 2. PERMIT
Sec. 16-171. Required.
No persons shall solicit funds from the general public upon the street,
sidewalk or public ways of the village, unless such solicitation is for a
charitable, civic, education or religious purpose which will serve or benefit
the entire village, and a permit has been issued by the village clerk
authorizing such solicitation.
(Code 1965, § 26-35(a))
Sec. 16-172. Application required by this division.
   (a)   An application for a permit required by this division shall be made
upon forms provided by the village. Such application shall be sworn to and
filed with the village clerk at least fifteen (15) days prior to the time for
which the permit is desired, and shall contain the following information, or in
lieu hereof a detailed statement of the reason or reasons why such information
cannot be furnished:
      (1)   The name and address or headquarters of the applicant.
      (2)   If the applicant is not an individual, the names and addresses of
the applicant's principal officers and managers and a copy of the resolution,
if any, authorizing such solicitation, certified to as a true and correct copy
of the original by the officer having charge of applicant's records.
      (3)   A specific statement, supported by reasons and, if available,
figures showing the need for the contributions to be solicited.
      (4)   The names and addresses of the persons by whom the receipts of such
solicitations shall be disbursed.
      (5)   The name and address of the persons who will be in direct charge of
conducting the solicitation and the names of all individuals connected or to be
connected with the proposed solicitation.
      (6)   An outline of the method or methods to be used in conducting the
solicitation and the time when it is desired to make such solicitation.
      (7)   A financial statement of the last preceding solicitation from the
public in the village by the applicant, giving the date of the solicitation,
the amount of money then raised, the expense of the solicitation and the final
distribution thereof.
      (8)   A statement to the effect that if a permit is granted it will not
be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the village or by any
department or officer thereof.
      (9)   Such other information as might be reasonably required by the mayor
in order for him to determine the kind and character of the proposed
solicitation and whether it is in the interest of, and not inimical to, the
public welfare.
   (b)   If, while any application is then pending, there is any change in
fact, policy or method that would alter the information given in the
application, the applicant shall notify the village clerk in writing thereof
within twenty-four (24) hours after such change.
(Code 1965, § 26-36)
Sec. 16-173. Investigation of applications.
The village clerk shall cause such investigation to be made of the application
and the applicant as he deems necessary in order for him to perform his duties
under this division.
(Code 1965, § 26-37)
Sec. 16-174. Standards for issuance.
The village clerk shall issue a permit whenever he shall find the following
facts to exist:
      (1)   That the purpose for which the solicitation is to be made is a
legitimate charitable, educational, civic or religious one which will affect,
serve or benefit the entire village.
      (2)   That the solicitation from the general public is reasonably
required for the financing of such purpose.
      (3)   That the officers and managers of the applicant and the person who
will be in direct charge of or connected with the solicitation are all
responsible and reliable persons of good character or reputation for honesty
and integrity.
      (4)   That the method and time of the solicitation proposed are
reasonably designed and planned so as not to inconvenience the general public
using the streets, sidewalks and public ways of the village.
      (5)   That neither applicant nor any of its officers, managers or members
connected with the solicitation has engaged in any fraudulent transaction or
enterprise, and that the solicitation will not be a fraud upon the public.
      (6)   That the cost of raising the funds will be reasonable and that the
solicitation is prompted solely by a desire to finance the cause described in
the application and not for any private profit.
      (7)   That the statements made in the application are true.
(Code 1965, § 26-38)
Sec. 16-175. Contents of permit; transferability.
Permits issued under this division shall bear the name and address of the
person by whom the solicitation is to be made, the number of the permit, the
date issued, the date on which the solicitation is permitted, and a statement
that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the village or by any of
its departments, officers or employees of the purpose or of the person
conducting the solicitation. All permits must be signed by the village clerk.
They shall be nontransferable.
(Code 1965, § 26-40)
Sec. 16-176. Credentials; solicitation for persons without permit.
   (a)   All persons to whom permits have been issued under this division shall
furnish proper credentials to their agents and solicitors for such
solicitation. Such credentials shall include the name of the permit holder, the
date, a statement describing the holder's charitable activity, a description of
the purpose of the solicitation, the signature of the permit holder or the
holder's chief executive officer, and the name, address, age, sex and signature
of the solicitor to whom such credentials are issued and the specific period of
time during which such solicitors are authorized to solicit on behalf of the
permit holder. A copy of such proposed credentials must be approved by the
village clerk as conforming to the requirements of this section before such
permit is issued. No person shall solicit under any permit granted hereunder
without the credentials required by this section and a facsimile copy of such
permit in his possession. Such credentials and facsimile copy of the permit
must be shown upon request to all persons solicited and to any police officer
of the village.
   (b)   No agent of a solicitor shall solicit contributions for any
charitable, civic, educational or religious purpose for any person in the
village unless such person has been granted a permit under the provisions of
this division.
(Code 1965, § 26-41)
ARTICLE VI. NON-SOLICITATION
Sec. 16-180. Definitions.
The following words shall have the meanings ascribed to them for the purposes
of this Article:
   (a)   Occupant means any person who lives, dwells, or resides at any real
estate. It shall be sufficient for purposes of this article that one occupant
of any real estate take an action, and nothing herein shall require or imply
that all occupants of any real estate must take an action.
   (b)   Owner means any person having any legal or equitable title to all or a
portion of any real estate. It shall be sufficient for purposes of this article
that one owner of any real estate take an action, and nothing herein shall
require or imply that all owners of any real estate must take an action.
   (c)   Person has the meaning ascribed to it in the Criminal Code of 1961, as
amended (720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.).
   (d)   Real Estate has the meaning ascribed to it in the Real Estate License
Act of 1983, as amended (225 ILCS 455/1 et seq.).
   (e)   Solicit means any communication with any owner or occupant of
residential real estate which is carried out by means of:
      (1)   in-person contacts at the real estate; or
      (2)   written material mailed or delivered at the real estate, such as
direct mail, leaflets or pamphlets; or
      (3)   telephonic contacts at the real estate; or
      (4)   electronic mail or other communications transmitted through
telephone lines such as facsimile transmissions and e-mail.
Sec. 16-181. Solicitation Prohibited.
It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit the owner or occupant of any
residential real estate at the residence of the owner or occupant after a non-
solicitation notice has been sent by the Village Clerk and received by that
person. This is an absolute liability offense which means that a person may be
guilty even though not acting with intent, knowledge, recklessness, or
negligence.
Sec. 16-182. Non-solicitation Notice.
Upon the request of any owner or occupant of residential real estate, the
Village Clerk shall prepare a non-solicitation notice advising that
solicitation at a specific residential real estate is prohibited. Such notice
shall be sent by certified mail, return receipt requested, to the person whose
solicitation the owner or occupant wishes to prohibit. If the certified mail is
returned not delivered, then notice shall be sent by regular mail. A notice
received by any person at the address shall be adequate notice to the person to
whom the notice is addressed.
Chapter 17
PLANNING AND DEVELOPMENT
Art. I.   In General, §§ 17-1--17-25
Art. II.   Business District, §§ 17-26--17-50
Art. III.   Condominiums, §§ 17-51--17-69
Art. IV.   Façade improvement program, § 17-70 - 17-73
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Sec. 17-1. House numbering.
Each house in the village shall be designated by a house number, which number
shall be visible in the front thereof and be of such size and clarity as to be
easily seen from the curbline of the street. A number shall be assigned to each
house by the building commissioner and shall be determined in accordance with
the numbering system currently prevailing in the City of Chicago, being merely
an extension thereof. The owner of any house or building in the village who
does not ascertain and post his house number in accordance with the provisions
of this section shall be guilty of a misdemeanor.
Sec. 17-2. Habitation of trailers and temporary structures; use prohibited;
exceptions.
It shall be unlawful for any person to use, occupy, habitate, operate or
maintain any temporary building, mobile home, house trailer, truck trailer,
trailer, recreational vehicle, prefabricated building, modular building, travel
trailer, motor home, relocatable building, trailer house, or any structure
mounted on wheels or supports or capable of being mounted on wheels or supports
which is movable by its own power or can be transported by another vehicle. The
following exceptions shall not be unlawful:
      (1)   Use for a temporary construction office during the period of actual
construction.
      (2)   Use as a replacement structure for a single-family residence
destroyed or damaged by fire, casualty, or act of God, but not for a period in
excess of one year.
      (3)   Use by a governmental agency or school district.
ARTICLE II. BUSINESS DISTRICTS
Sec. 17-26. Designation.
The Board of Trustees by ordinance may designate an area of the Village as a
business district when it finds and determines that such a designation will
facilitate the development of an area with sound and stable commercial growth
in order to promote the tax base of the Village and the enhancement of
employment opportunities.
Sec. 17-27. Powers.
In carrying out development or redevelopment within a business district, the
Board of Trustees shall have the following powers:
      (1)   To approve a business district plan.
      (2)   To approve all development and redevelopment proposals and
agreements for a business district.
      (3)   To exercise the use of eminent domain for the acquisition of real
and personal property.
      (4)   To acquire, manage, convey or otherwise dispose of real and
personal property.
      (5)   To apply for and accept capital grants and loans from the United
States and the State of Illinois, or any instrumentality of the United States
or the State.
      (6)   To borrow funds, make loans and make grants.
      (7)   To enter into contracts with any public or private agency or
person.
      (8)   To sell, lease, trade or improve real property.
      (9)   To employ all such persons as may be necessary for the planning,
administration and implementation of the business district.
      (10)   To expend such public funds as may be necessary for the planning,
execution and implementation of the business district.
      (11)   To establish procedures for the planning, execution and
implementation of the business district.
      (12)   To establish a tax increment finance district.
      (13)   To provide relocation benefits.
      (14)   To enter into intergovernmental cooperation agreements.
      (15)   To exercise such other powers as deemed necessary as a home rule
unit under Article VII of the Illinois Constitution.
ARTICLE III. CONDOMINIUMS
Sec. 17-51. Definitions.
The definitions in the Condominium Property Act (765 ILCS 605/1, et seq.) apply
to this article.
Sec. 17-52. Applicability.
This article shall apply to all divisions of land or property into residential
and commercial condominium units.
Sec. 17-53. Processing of condominium plat.
A plat for a proposed condominium development shall be processed
administratively and shall not require any public hearing, but shall require
approval of the Mayor and Board of Trustees.
Sec. 17-54. Plat approval, recordation.
No condominium plat shall be recorded without the prior approval of the
village; nor permits issued for the construction or conversion of the same
without such approval. No plat of a condominium shall be recorded without
complying with the requirements of this article.
Sec. 17-55. Condominium development specifications.
All new condominium developments shall comply with the following provisions:
      (1)   No unit in any condominium may be sold or transferred unless a
certificate of inspection has been issued by the Building Commissioner that
such condominium unit with respect to the conversion elements complies with the
provisions of this section. For that purpose, the applicant shall submit "as-
built" drawings of the architect and site development certified by a registered
architect.
      (2)   No certificate of inspection shall be issued, no sale of a unit
shall be made, and no condominium plat approved where the requirements of any
ordinance of the Village concerning any zoning, building, or subdivision
provision are not currently in compliance by the building located on the
property and by the common area.
      (3)   No building or land previously granted a variation to any zoning,
building, or subdivision ordinance shall be converted into condominiums unless
the current requirements of the applicable ordinance are met.
      (4)   All condominiums shall comply with the current regulations,
including open space and parking requirements, for the land use zone in which
they are located. Conversion of an existing building into condominiums shall
not require additional parking spaces to meet the current regulations, provided
that the use of the building is not intensified.
      (5)   All residential condominiums shall contain a minimum storage space
of 320 cubic feet for each efficiency or one-bedroom unit, plus an additional
storage of 160 cubic feet for each additional bedroom. All storage areas are to
be located in other than the condominium unit.
      (6)   A separate gas, electric, and water meter and shutoff valve shall
be provided for each unit. In a residential condominium a common water meter
may be provided for each building. Each unit shall have a separate hot water
heater, furnace and if provided, air conditioning system.
      (7)   All walls, ceilings, and floors separating units shall be
soundproof.
      (8)   Common garbage and trash disposal containers shall be provided in a
location screened from view in an area to avoid a minimum of noise and smell.
Pickup shall be at least twice weekly for all structures containing 12 or more
units.
      (9)   All residential condominium buildings shall provide a recreational
or assembly area of not less than 800 square feet for four units or less and an
additional 100 square feet for each unit over four.
      (10)   The Condominium Property Act (765 ILCS 605/1, et seq.).
The Mayor and Board of Trustees shall have the right to waive any of the above
requirements for new condominium developments.
   For conversion of existing buildings into condominiums, many of the above
requirements will not be physically or economically feasible. The Building
Commissioner shall make a report on compliance with the above specifications,
and the Mayor and Board of Trustees shall have the right to waive any such
requirements.
Sec. 17-56. Common elements.
All condominium associations shall be responsible for traffic and parking
control, snow removal, signing, sewers, water lines, and lighting. The village
shall have the right of easement to enter such common areas for the purpose of
emergency for fire, police, and enforcement of its ordinances and the plat
shall so provide. Such common area shall remain the property of the condominium
and the village shall not accept a dedication of these elements or the
responsibility of maintenance. The association shall maintain the public area
and parkway in a clean condition, free of debris, leaves and trash.
Sec. 17-57. Certificate of inspection.
Once a certificate of inspection has been issued, no new certificate of
inspection need be secured for the resale of any unit for which a certificate
of inspection has been previously issued, or for the sale or resale of any unit
which was originally designed and sold under the Condominium Property Act (766
ILCS 605/1, et seq.) if a certificate of occupancy has been issued with respect
thereto, unless one is requested by an owner of the village.
Secs. 17-58 - 17-69. Reserved.
ARTICLE IV. FAÇADE IMPROVEMENT PROGRAM
Sec. 17-70. Façade Improvement Grant Program-95th Street TIF District.
   (a)   A façade improvement grant program is hereby implemented within the
95th Street TIF District to promote the continued use and maintenance of
commercial buildings in the Village and to provide for grants to business
property owners for façade improvements to existing buildings. The façade
improvement grant program shall be administered as follows:
      (1)   Grant Eligibility. To be eligible for a façade improvement grant, a
building must be used in whole or in part for retail or other commercial
purposes. Business property owners, or lessees with a term of not less than 5
years remaining on the lease, must propose to make at least $10,000 in eligible
improvements to be eligible for a façade improvement grant.
      (2)   Limit and Nature of Grant Award.
         (A)   Façade improvement grants will be issued to qualifying
applicants in a maximum amount not greater than 50% of the actual cost of the
eligible improvements, but not to exceed $100,000, as determined by the Mayor.
Façade improvements will only be reimbursed if made to the front of the
building facing 95th Street or to any side of the building the majority of
which is visible from 95th Street. The style and design of any proposed
improvement shall be subject to the approval of the Village.
         (B)   Façade improvement grants shall be in the form of a
reimbursement for such costs already incurred by the owner for the eligible
costs. Prior to receiving reimbursement, the owner must submit to an inspection
by the Building Commissioner of all eligible costs and must provide proof of
paid receipts, contractor and subcontractor sworn statements, and all
applicable lien waivers.
      (3)   Eligible Costs: The following façade improvement costs are eligible
for reimbursement from the façade improvement grant:
         (A)   Installation, repair, and replacement of exterior exit doors to
provide public access, meet current building and fire codes, or improve the
overall appearance of the building;
         (B)   Exterior cleaning of brick or stone;
         (C)   Repair, replacement, or addition of exterior shutters and
awnings, except for backlit or plastic awnings;
         (D)   Repair, replacement, and installation of exterior stairs,
porches, railings, and exit facilities;
         (E)   Tuckpointing or repair of exterior bricks;
         (F)   Repair of windows, frames, sills, glazing, replacement of glass,
and installation of new windows;
         (G)   Repair of cornices in order to replicate the building's original
façade;
         (H)   Repair, installation, replacement, or addition of any other
improvement the Building Commissioner deems appropriate in order to create a
uniformity of appearance throughout the 95th TIF District; or
         (I)   Landscaping and streetscape improvements including, but not
limited to brick pavers, lighting, and furnishings.
      (4)   Ineligible Costs. The following improvement costs are not eligible
for reimbursement from the façade improvement grant:
         (A)   Building permit fees and related costs;
         (B)   Extermination of insects, rodents, vermin and other pests;
         (C)   Title reports and legal fees;
         (D)   Acquisition of land or buildings;
         (E)   Air conditioning and heating facilities;
         (F)   Installation or repair of signs;
         (G)   Architect's fees; or
         (H)   Newly constructed or additions to existing buildings.
(Ord. No. 9-2007 § 1, 2-19-07; Am. Ord. No. 25-2022 § 1, 12-5-22)
Sec. 17-71.   Application; Required Submittals.
   (a)   Property owners shall submit the following application materials:
      (1)   One completed and original application form which shall include:
         (A)   Property owner’s name, address, and contact information;
         (B)   Common address and property identification number;
         (C)   Legal description of subject property;
         (D)   Current use of the property;
         (E)   Improvement information, including, without limitation:
            1.   Contractor information;
            2.   Cost estimate;
            3.   Façade area;
            4.   Requested amount of grant;
            5.   Proposed improvements;
            6.   Copies of the drawings of the proposed work, to scale and
preferably in color; and
            7.   Brief narrative description of the project;
         (F)   Pictures of façade and particular areas to be enhanced; and
         (G)   Proof of ownership of property.
(Ord. No. 9-2007 § 1, 2-19-07)
Sec. 17-72. Approval.
   (a)   The Building Commissioner shall review the application to determine
its completeness with the above requirements. If an application is deemed
complete, he shall submit a report to the Mayor detailing the facts, proposed
improvements, and requested assistance.
   (b)   In the event that the Building Commissioner finds that an application
is incomplete or that the proposed scope of improvements are ineligible or
partially ineligible for reimbursement under the façade improvement grant
program, he shall inform the applicant in writing of any such deficiency.
   (c)    Not later than 45 days after receipt of a completed application the
Building Commissioner shall issue a recommendation to the Mayor with respect to
the approval or denial thereof.
   (d)   The Mayor shall act upon the recommendation within 10 days thereafter
and determine the maximum amount of the façade improvement grant.
   (e)   Provided that the applicant completes all of the proposed façade
improvement work, pays for the same, submits paid contractor invoices, submits
waivers of lien, submits sworn contractor statement, and fulfills all
requirements of the Building Commissioner, the grant amount shall be paid to
the property owner for reimbursement of costs within 180 days after final
approval of the Building Commissioner, provided that there are adequate moneys
in the Special Tax Allocation Fund for the 95th Street TIF District.
(Ord. No. 9-2007 § 1, 2-19-07)
Sec. 17-73.   Repayment of Grant.
   (a)   In the event that the property which is the subject of a façade
improvement grant is sold within four years after payment of the grant, all or
a portion of the façade improvement grant shall be repaid to the Village based
upon the following schedule:
      (1)   Sale within 1 year               100% repayment
      (2)   Sale between 1 year and 2 years         75% repayment
      (3)   Sale between 2 years and 3 years         50% repayment
      (4)   Sale between 3 years and 4 years         25% repayment
      (5)   Sale after 4 years               0% repayment
   (b)   Acceptance of a façade improvement grant shall be deemed authority to
the Village to record a memorandum of the required repayment of façade
improvement grant under the provisions of this section.
(Ord. No. 9-2007 § 1, 2-19-07)
Chapter 18
POLICE
Art. I.   In General, §§ 18-1-18-25
Art. II.   Police Department, §§ 18-26-18-75
Art. III.   Auxiliary Police Officers, §§ 18-76-18-100
Art. IV.   Special Police, §§ 18-101-18-104
Art. V.   Part-Time Police, §§ 18-120-18-123
ARTICLE I. IN GENERAL
Secs. 18-1—18-25. Reserved
ARTICLE II. POLICE DEPARTMENT
Sec. 18-26. Created.
The police department of the village is hereby created and shall consist of
such officers and employees as determined by the mayor and board of trustees.
Sec. 18-27. Police personnel.
   (a)   The classified service ranks and maximum number of full-time sworn
police officers in each rank is established as:
      Sergeant (17) including the Chief of Police, 2 Deputy Chiefs, 3 Captains,
and 7 Lieutenants)
      Patrol Officer (46)
   (b)   The number of personnel shown in (a) above are the maximum and not the
minimum number required to be employed. In the event that a person leaves the
services of the Police Department or is promoted, a vacancy shall not exist in
any rank, and no employee shall be hired or promoted, until such time as the
Mayor and Board of Trustees authorize the vacancy to be filled.
(Ord. No. 19-2008, § 1, 6-16-08; Am. Ord. No. 31-2008, § 1, 12-15-08; Am. Ord.
No. 19-2009, § 1, 9-8-09; Am. Ord. No. 11-2010, § 1, 8-16-10; Am. Ord. No. 10-
2014, § 1, 4-7-14)
Sec. 18-28. Village officials designated special police officers.
The following officials of the village are hereby designated as special police
officers: mayor, trustees, village clerk, village attorney, village prosecutor,
fire chief, building commissioner, health inspector and animal control warden.
Sec. 18-29. Rules, regulations.
The chief of police may adopt rules and regulations to govern the operation and
conduct of the police department.
Sec. 18-30. Removal, discharge and discipline.
   (a)   The chief of police and deputy chief of police are subject to removal,
discharge or discipline by the mayor, which removal, discharge or discipline
shall not be effective if overridden by a majority vote of the board of
trustees.
   (b)   Employees in the rank of sergeant and patrol officer are subject to
removal, discharge or discipline by the chief of police and the board of fire
and police commissioners under the provisions established in this Code.
   (c)   All duty assignments such as captain, lieutenant, detective, juvenile
officer, tactical officer, firearm training officer and arson investigator
shall be made by the Chief of Police. There is no property right in any duty
assignment.
(Am. Ord. No. 31-2008, § 2, 12-15-08; Am. Ord. No. 11-2010, § 2, 8-16-10)
Sec. 18-31. Certification prerequisite to employment.
   (a)   The village hereby elects to participate in the program provided for
in the Illinois Police Training Act [50 ILCS 705/1, et seq.].
   (b)   Before an individual may commence regular employment as a police
officer, he must have been certified by the Illinois Local Government Law
Enforcement Officers Training Board, as having successfully completed an
approved training course as provided in such act.
   (c)   Such basic training must be completed by the trainee within his
probationary period of 12 months.
Sec. 18-32. General duties and powers of police force.
   (a)   The several members of the police force of the village, including the
chief of police, shall devote their time and attention to the discharge of
their duties, according to the sections of this Code and ordinances and the
rules and regulations which the mayor and board of trustees and the board of
fire and police commissioners may adopt and prescribe.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of each member of the police force of the village
to preserve order, peace and quiet, and enforce the law, sections of this Code,
and ordinances throughout the village.
   (c)   It shall be the duty of every police officer to report to the chief of
police at such times and places as he may require, and at all times to obey the
orders and instructions of the chief of police.
(Code 1965, § 23-3)
Sec. 18-33. Intern program.
   (a)   Upon recommendation of the chief of police and approval by the mayor
and board of trustees, from time to time there shall be appointed certain
personnel as law enforcement interns who shall be individuals who are currently
undertaking studies at accredited universities, colleges or technical schools
in law enforcement work, and whose principal place of residence, other than
school residence, shall be the village. It shall be understood, however, that
this residence requirement may be waived by the mayor and board of trustees.
   (b)   The intern personnel shall be appointed for a period not to exceed one
(1) full school semester and shall be assigned to a section or department of
the police department of the village which will enable the intern to come into
contact with the overall facet of police function and police work. It shall be
understood that the term "school semester" shall constitute that period of time
which represents a semester in the school to which the intern has been a full-
time student.
   (c)   Intern personnel shall act as observers only and shall not be allowed
to engage in any police work or functions on behalf of the village. In addition
thereto, such interns shall be no less than eighteen (18) years of age and
shall provide the village with a total hold harmless agreement wherein they
shall hold the village harmless from any and all injuries or liabilities
sustained by them as a result of their internship with the village. In addition
thereto, the hold harmless and indemnification agreement shall further be
secured from the university, college or technical school which the intern is
attending. In addition, such intern personnel shall not receive remuneration
from the village during such internship.
   (d)   Upon completion of their internship, interns shall be given a
certificate of completion of internship together with a qualification report
submitted by their immediate supervisor and the chief of police during the
course of their internship. Such report shall be forwarded by the chief of
police to the university, college or technical school at which the intern is a
student. (Code 1965, § 23-36)
Sec. 18-34. Chief to prescribe uniform and badge.
The chief of police shall, with the consent of the mayor and board of trustees,
prescribe the proper uniform and badge for all regular and special police
officers, and shall make suitable regulations, under which they shall be
required to wear an appropriate uniform and badge, by which they may be known
and designated at all times.
(Code 1965, § 23-5)
Sec. 18-35. Seizure, custody of property.
   (a)   It shall be the duty of all police officers of the village to deliver
to the chief of police all property seized or found by them immediately after
the same shall come into their possession, which property, with the date of
delivery, a description of the same, and the name of the officer, shall be
entered into records to be kept for the purpose by the chief of police.
   (b)   The chief of police shall be the official custodian of all property
coming into the control and possession of the department.
(Code 1965, § 23-12)
Sec. 18-36. Reports by chief.
The chief of police shall make a full and complete report of the activities of
the police department to the village board and the board of fire and police
commissioners annually or as directed from time to time.
(Code 1965, § 23-20)
Secs. 18-37—18-75. Reserved.
ARTICLE III. AUXILIARY POLICE OFFICERS
Sec. 18-76. Appointment; number.
The mayor, with the advice and consent of the board of trustees, may appoint
auxiliary police officers in such number as the corporate authorities shall
from time to time deem necessary. Auxiliary police officers shall not be
conservators of the peace.
(Code 1965, § 23-39) (Ord. No. 36-2006 § 1, 11-20-06)
Sec. 18-77. Status; identification symbols; supervision.
   (a)   Status. Auxiliary police officers shall not be considered to be
members of the regular police department of the village and shall not
supplement members of the regular police department of the village in the
performance of their assigned and normal duties, except as otherwise provided
herein.
   (b)   Identification symbol. Identification symbols worn by the auxiliary
police officers shall be different and distinct from those used by the regular
police department.
   (c)   Supervision. Auxiliary police officers shall at all times during the
performance of their duties shall be subject to the direction and control of
the chief of police of the village. (Code 1965, § 23-40)
Sec. 18-78. Carrying firearms.
Auxiliary police officers shall not carry firearms except with the permission
of the Chief of Police on designated assignments while in uniform, and then
only if such officer has completed the required training promulgated by the
Illinois Law Enforcement Training and Standards Board.
(Code 1965, § 23-41) (Ord. No. 36-2006 § 1, 11-20-06)
Sec. 18-79. Powers and duties.
Auxiliary police officers shall have the following powers and duties when
properly assigned and on duty:
      (1)   To aid or direct traffic.
      (2)   To aid in control of natural or man-made disasters.
      (3)   To aid in case of civil disorder.
      (4)   To aid in crowd control.
      (5)   To assist in the observation and detention of prisoners.
      (6)   To patrol and guard public facilities and grounds.
(Code 1965, § 23-42) (Ord. No. 36-2006 § 1, 11-20-06)
Sec. 18-80. Training; fingerprinting; connection of certain crimes.
   No person shall be hired as an auxiliary police officer who has not been
